PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 12.30 p.m., and read prayers.
Motion (by Mr Brereton) proposed:

That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent order of the day No. 12, private members business, namely resumption of debate on the second reading of the Sydney Airport Curfew (Air Navigation Amendment) Bill 1995, being called on and for the question—that the bill be now read a second time—to be put forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I do not intend to detain the House for very long but I feel it appropriate that there should be some remarks on the record about the procedures which the government is adopting. We will not propose a division in respect of this procedural motion but it is worthy of note that it appears that this motion is being moved by the government so as to dispose from the Notice Paper a private member's bill—the Sydney Airport Curfew (Air Navigation Amendment) Bill 1995—presented by the Leader of the Opposition, the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard).

PARA.TAB: As you would appreciate, Mr Speaker, the substantive issues which this bill canvasses go to the fact that there has been a failure by the government over a period of 12 1/2 years to do anything at all to entrench the curfew at the Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport. The bill presented by the member for Bennelong attempts to remedy the government's chronic failure in that regard.

As you would be aware, Mr Speaker, as a result of a private member having a bill before the House, there is the opportunity for a private member to effectively ask another private member—in this case, a most dignified one, being the member for Bennelong—a question about the progress of that bill for which he or she is responsible. Mr Speaker, when you and I first came into this place such a question was a rare one.

If you go back over House of Representatives Practice you will find that there might have been one or two examples. House of Representatives Practice was carefully worded so as to constrain the nature of the question and particularly to constrain the extent of the response from the person to whom the question was put. As practice has developed, it is now the case—as you remarked in September this year when a number of questions were put to the Leader of the Opposition—that a reasonable amount of latitude is given to the person in charge of the bill to respond.

I want to make the point that this portrays a development in the practice of the House which is important to acknowledge. When I first came into the place, for all the politicisation of the parties, question time went for about 45 minutes. On average, we had 15 or 16 questions per question time and answers were two or three minutes in duration.

Over the years—I must say, over the Labor years—it is true that the number of questions being asked by the opposition has been significantly curtailed. In Malcolm Fraser's time the number of questions asked in one year averaged 18 or 19 questions in 45 minutes. There was such a fuss about this a few years ago that the government, under public pressure, agreed to a system of seven questions.

We now find that we are lucky to get through seven questions from our side—a total of 14—in about an hour or 1 1/4 hours. That was really unheard of when we first arrived back at the beginning of 1985. These lengthening answers have been accompanied by a change in the nature of the answers to the extent that, more and more, ministers believe that the House is just a forum for the most base party politics as opposed to the longstanding conventions and practices of the House that question time should be a time at which ministers, in particular, must account to the House for their actions.

I did not come down in the last shower. Obviously there will be a fair amount of reference to party political matters in question ttime. I am not saying that there should not be. But it has now come to pass that, from the point of view of an objective observer of the proceedings of the parliament, there is nothing untoward in the opposition also being given a chance during question time to get up and tip a bucket in return on the government.

I say to you, Mr Speaker—and this is my remark, if you like—that the reason why that has now come to pass is that, quite frankly, the way in which we now conduct question time has been so debased that people find that this is an entirely acceptable way in which the parliament should run. As I say, it is therefore really not exceptional that a question should be asked of the Leader of the Opposition because, from the public's point of view, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is dishing it out day in and day out, so why should not the opposition also be given a reasonable turn?

I do not think I would have said this 10 years ago. I must say that, for the future, I am not sure that that really is the best way for the parliament to be run. In fact, I would have to say to you, Mr Speaker, that I do not think that, generally speaking, question time should be used entirely and completely in the party political way that it is now. When we first arrived, it was common place for private members to ask their own questions. Rarely is that the case now.

The whole thing has to be managed. We have to manage it because that is the politics of the situation. The government has to manage it because that is the politics of the situation from its perspective. But we have arrived at this new low in the way in which the parliament is run.

Do not let those who have a different point of view criticise me for being naive about politics. I am fully cognisant of the political pressures. That is why we acquiesce in what is happening. But it should not be allowed to pass unremarked that these changes have evolved over a period of time; so much so that the idea of the opposition regularly asking the Leader of the Opposition a question is not unremarked nor unremarkable. Page 514 of House of Representatives Practice states:

SPEECH.PARA: Standing Order 143 provides that questions may be put to a Member, who is not a Minister or an Assistant Minister, relating to any bill, motion or other public matter connected with the business of the House, of which the Member has charge.

The government is removing the bill because it is a nuisance to have the member for Warringah (Mr Abbott) asking the Leader of the Opposition a question. It irks the Prime Minister considerably to have the Leader of the Opposition standing here and giving as good as he gets. It irks the Prime Minister a lot. As a result, he is removing this bill from the Notice Paper.

PARA.TAB: We all know that, in the past, many a private member's bill has just sat on the Notice Paper and that is all there is to it. It disappears effectively with the effluxion of time with the dissolution of the parliament. If we look at the House Magazine we see that it is full of private members' bills—particularly in the Senate—that are just sitting there and going nowhere. No-one moves to remove them from the list. Why? The real reason this bill is being removed is the political embarrassment for the government on the issue of the Leader of the Opposition properly taking the opportunity provided by the standing orders and the conventions of standing up and answering reasonable questions about his proposals.

In my view, the remedy to what I believe are the inadequate circumstances into which the House has now fallen is not so much a change in the standing orders but that the government of the day more properly respect the former conventions and traditions of this place. That starts with the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister at the start of question time should say to his ministers, `When you are asked a question, I expect you to answer the question and be accountable. Question time should fulfil its proper purpose.'

That is exactly what will happen when we are in government. We will abolish this rotten roster system which is used to allow ministers to have a rostered day off twice a week. It is unbelievable that ministers have days off. It is not as though they are not here in the building, as we have seen in many divisions which are called straight after question time. Take the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence). She would not be here in question time to answer a few basic questions about her responsibility for the health care of millions of Australians but, as soon as there is a division after question time, all of a sudden she is here. She puts down her cup of tea and walks into the House.

It is not as though this system was devised so ministers could get out and be in touch with the Australian community; it was devised as a political ploy to protect ministers. The roster system will be abolished by us. As the Leader of the Opposition has made very clear, we will require ministers to front every day and answer questions. In fact, I reckon it is not too much for the public to ask—that in the 22 weeks or thereabouts of the year that parliament sits ministers should be there on duty, should be responsible, should be accountable and should be ready to answer questions.

Whilst on that topic, I must say that one of the other many aspects which have resulted in the diminution of the standing of the parliament is that these people changed the hour of question time knowing that the ABC prefer to run Sesame Street rather than question time in the House of Representatives, thereby ensuring that the House of Representatives question time is not broadcast concurrently with the happenings in the House. That is wrong. When you think about it, it is an amazing thing that the proceedings of the House in question time—the most important time of the day—are not broadcast in Australia because the Prime Minister changed the time so they would clash with Sesame Street and the ABC would then give priority to Sesame Street over the functionings of our parliament.

It is not because we want to be on TV, I can tell you. I am entirely casual about that from a personal point of view. The point is that the public are entitled to know what is going on. They are entitled to see what is happening in their own parliament. They pay for it. This is a democracy. In a democracy, freedom of choice for people is little choice if it is not an informed choice. You might say that this is only a small matter. The Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) is sighing. It is a matter of complete indifference to him.

The reason they changed that timing of question time in parliament was that the Prime Minister and his advisers did not want anybody to see his conduct in the House. So the Prime Minister made sure that question time was not televised. That is basically what has happened. People should know that. It is one of the many things along the way which cumulatively have affected the way in which the parliament operates and question time in particular. I must say that it is to the disadvantage of the standing of this parliament in the Australian community.

With those few words, we will not specifically call for a division on this procedural matter, but it does highlight the way in which this government treats the parliament—the contempt with which it treats it. On the substantive matter, it highlights its embarrassment, after 12 1/2 years, of failing to act on this aspect of the curfew at Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise frequently to speak on these issues because, quite clearly, and I think I have demonstrated it over time, I have a commitment to this parliament and its responsibility to the people of Australia. This particular motion is just another example of the arrogant treatment of this parliament by this executive, typified of course by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) when he told us that question time was a courtesy extended to the parliament or to the opposition by the executive. In other words, he did not even believe in that most fundamental of Westminster principles, that there should be a question time, whilst all responsible commentators around the world have made the point time and time again—and the WA Inc. royal commissioners spent quite a considerable part of their report on the fact—that question time is the time when the public is entitled to information and the opposition of the day is entitled to test the government on its policies and its probity.

PARA.TAB: The standing orders also provide, quite correctly, in that process that should a member, not of the executive—and I repeat that, a member not of the executive; in other words, a backbencher in the government ranks or any person in the opposition ranks—propose a private member's bill to the parliament, then they have the right to respond to questions from the members in that regard. Those questions might assist them in promoting their bill. They might be questions that identify great weaknesses in the bill, but it is all part of the function of parliament.

When we see this government come scurrying in here with its tail between its legs wanting to wipe this particular piece of legislation off the Notice paper, it can only indicate that, firstly, this is a continuation of their disregard for the Westminster system and the conduct of this parliament and, more importantly, how terrified they are of giving the opportunity to the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, to stand in this place and demonstrate his political skills, his clear understanding of issues, and his determination to represent the interests of the people of his electorate and the people of New South Wales, more particularly Sydney, in terms of the difficulties this government has created in regard to the Sydney airport debacle.

This has been a debacle ever since this government came into office. At first they had no solution, so we saw the ridiculous situation of aircraft being stacked up in the sky for hours. We saw tonnes of fuel and tonnes of gas emissions being extruded, if you like—certainly coming from aircraft—as aircraft waited at the end of the runway for their turn to take off. Then we saw them arrange for a parallel runway which everybody called the third runway—and I repeat that, the third runway. The Prime Minister and others have referred to it in recent times as the third runway, but then they turned around and made it the second runway. Then they did not even have their particular control processes in place to ensure that it would be run properly. They seemed unable to use Botany Bay in a way that would reduce the noise. They are still trying to make up their minds as to approach levels, notwithstanding that air navigation experts have told them there are better ways to bring aircraft into airports of this nature.

This has been an administrative disaster which has never even included any formalisation of the curfew arrangements. So, when the Leader of the Opposition brings forward such a proposal by the appropriate mechanism of a private member's bill, we find the government running around trying to produce the same bill but wanting to make it look different. That is ludicrous, and that is what this gets down to. When you get the allegation that what you are doing is silly, when you will not accept a very appropriate proposition because the people presenting it are in opposition, you are not governing the country properly. That is what has happened. There has been the embarrassment, on two occasions, of questions being put to the Leader of the Opposition. Having heard the arguments in crystal clarity from one of the best parliamentary operators in this country, the government has a little meeting, the executive gets together, and they say, `This is causing us harm; the people are listening and believing.'

The Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) throws his head around. If you don't believe that, why are you pulling it off the Notice Paper via this mechanism? The reason is that it is hurting, you are embarrassed and you know that the Leader of the Opposition is right. Please do not confect yawns and all these other things because, if it is not and was not having an effect—if it was not embarrassing you—you would not be doing what we are doing now: you would be getting on with your legislation, which may be of more importance to the people.

The previous speaker, the shadow minister for employment and industrial relations, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), made the point quite clearly that all of this has built up over a period of time to demean the parliament. Would you not think a government that makes so many outrageous claims as to its ability to manage and to govern would be delighted to be on direct television at question time? Would you not think it would be proud of that? Why does it hide it away and ensure that question time is not seen until 1 o'clock in the morning? It is the government's question time. Why is it necessary to ban the rebroadcast of points of order, a fundamental process in question time, a fundamental part of the parliamentary process? Why would the government do that other than because it causes it some embarrassment? It might highlight to the people that the questions that it receives as a government are not properly answered.

We went through a process a little while ago where the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) either could not remember or refused point blank to give an answer that was in any way relevant to the question she had been asked. Of course she did not want that to be shown on television by direct broadcast. Of course those opposite did not want a direct broadcast that would ensure that those points of order so properly taken, so frequently referring the government to the fact that it was not answering the question—which would in most cases have had considerable interest to the general community of Australia—were seen by members of the community.

The simple solution was, first, to ban the rebroadcasting by any means on television of points of order, and, more importantly, to make sure that the whole process of the federal House of Representatives question time was relegated to 1 o'clock in the morning. By conducting question time at the usual hour of 2 o'clock, it would have been broadcast direct on the ABC, and many people who have discussed that time with me would be watching.

The issue is that the standing orders provide for this mechanism. The standing orders provide for a private member's bill for all members of this House. It is not appropriate to have justice in the numbers, to wipe a bill out by this mechanism. It indicates a government in great fear of the skills of the Leader of the Opposition, of the legislation he has proposed and of the fact that he might respond to a further question coming from some part of this parliament.

I point out to the minister that, as far as I know—and I have not studied the standing orders—there is nothing to stop him asking the Leader of the Opposition about his legislation. Surely the minister can pick some holes in it with all his political skills. If he cannot, it must be very good legislation. Why is he not asking the Leader of the Opposition a question and using the proper forms of this House to expose the weakness that might exist? It does not; it is just something the government should have done years ago. That has been made patently clear. As a consequence, the government is embarrassed.

I put it to you, Mr Speaker, that consequently this is an outrageous proposition. It is totally unnecessary and it is certainly not something that a good government should be frightened of. The government should be able to handle it with facts, not with insults and things that we have to hide from the Australian people by not putting question time on direct telecast. We hide all that and then also, as has been pointed out, have a situation where, if a minister gets an embarrassing question, the minister is not present the next day to allow the opposition to follow it up. The whole thing is seen as a perception of never giving a sucker a break. This is all about the `game' of politics; it has nothing to do with the rights of the millions of Australians out there who would like to be reassured that their country is being properly managed, that the managers of the finances are honest and capable and that we are not getting too far into debt—all those things that arise.

It is through private members' bills of this nature that frequently a member is able to demonstrate beyond doubt that they have a commitment to certain issues of which the community is concerned. It is almost unbelievable that a government would be so frightened and so embarrassed that it has to come in here and spend the time of the House going through a process simply to remove an embarrassment from the Notice Paper. If you are big enough, strong enough and good enough, there is no need whatsoever, but you have demonstrated that there is a need. You have only one response to the nationwide, and certainly New South Wales-wide, criticism of your handling of the Sydney airport affair: to ensure that there is no opportunity to talk about it in any serious way through this sort of private member's bill.

It is a problem and one that brings no credit to this government at all. It is unnecessary if you were any good. The fact that you are not is why you are so embarrassed by the existence of this particular piece of legislation and the opportunity it gives to the Leader of the Opposition to answer questions properly put to him.

PARA.TAB: The proposal to remove the bill is because it has already been enacted with a great number of enhancements—enhancements brought about as a result of the very timely intervention of the member for Lowe (Mrs Easson), who sought to have the private member's bill referred to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, a committee which reported on a good number of measures that would strengthen the effect of curfew. This was music to the ears of government, particularly as the proposal put forward by the Leader of the Opposition proposed nothing other than to legislate the existing regulations—that is, every rule and every regulation that was already in place and being given effect to every day in the procedures adopted at the airport.

As a result of the work of the standing committee and as a result of the government's bill subsequently introduced, the bill is greatly enhanced with the reduction in quotas for international passenger movements during the curfew shoulder periods, not included in the private member's bill; greatly enhanced with the measures which propose that on Saturday and Sunday we will see aircraft operations between six and seven in the morning and 10 and 11 at night required to take off and land over the bay unless weather and traffic density prevent safe operations over the water; enhanced to the extent that all departures after 10.45 p.m. will be required to take off over Botany Bay to ensure that aircraft are well clear of residential suburbs by 11 o'clock; enhanced with the new provisions that larger propeller-driven aircraft over 34,000 kilograms, maximum take-off weight, will no longer be allowed to operate during the curfew; enhanced as a result of the more comprehensive consultation procedures which now require full community input into all curfew decisions with a requirement for full public scrutiny of any proposals to amend the legislation; and enhanced again with the provisions that increased penalties for breaches of the curfew will rise from $25,000 to $100,000.
