DEBATE.TITLE: SYDNEY AIRPORT CURFEW (AIR NAVIGATION AMENDMENT) BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 30 June, on motion by Mr Brereton:
That the bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the negative.
Consideration resumed from 27 September.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brereton The Hon L.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BRERETON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Transport)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Airports Bill provides for major reforms to the operation, development and regulation of federal airports. It is a bill founded upon the significant investment made in Australia's airports in recent years. Indeed, since 1988, the Federal Airports Corporation has greatly enhanced most of the airports it presently operates. In this period, the most notable changes have been capacity increases at Sydney's Kingsford Smith Airport, international terminal improvements at Sydney and Melbourne, new terminals for Alice Springs and Darwin, supporting work for domestic terminal improvements around Australia and, most recently, a grand new international terminal at Brisbane airport.

PARA.TAB: The FAC has completed all these works on a commercial basis, without any recourse to budget funding. As a result of their completion, FAC airports are better placed to meet both current demand and forecast increases in this demand. They are well set for the next phase of their operation under private leasing arrangements.

With much of the infrastructure enhanced, the government announced in Working Nation last year that it would develop a new regulatory regime for airports and conduct a scoping study into the possible sale of the corporation's airports. Following endorsement of those plans at last year's ALP National Conference, the government decided to proceed with sales by way of 50-year leases, with options for a further 49 years. The bill requires government approval for the issuing of these options. It also dictates that each lessee be a company set up to operate the airport, and that there be only one company assuming each lease. Where a group owns more than one airport the separate airport companies may have a common holding company.

The decision to lease the airports underlines the strategic importance of the airports managed by the FAC, and the public interest considerations associated with them. The use of long-term leases means that the Commonwealth will maintain ownership of the airports and that leased airports remain Commonwealth places. It also supports continuation of Commonwealth regulatory control of the airports.

In the budget this year the government announced its leasing strategy. That strategy opted for the leasing of FAC airports in two stages, with the four major airports—Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth—leased in the first phase, a phase in which Sydney will be jointly leased with the new airport at Badgerys Creek, Sydney West airport. The latter decision reflected the outcome of market testing and overseas experience which suggested that multi-airport systems were far more successful when developed on a complementary rather than competitive basis.

The government's intention is for the first stage to be completed by the end of 1996, with the second stage involving the remaining FAC airports taking place throughout 1997-98. This timetable is now jeopardised by coalition threats to excise Sydney from the first phase of the leasing process. Such threats amount to economic blackmail, pure and simple. Worse still, they are nothing short of economic lunacy on the part of the opposition.

The leasing strategy was designed to ensure maximum bidding and price tension, and therefore return to the taxpayer, by putting all the most attractive assets on the block first. If the most attractive asset, Sydney, was withheld, cross-ownership restrictions would ensure that bids would either not occur or would be far below the real value of Perth, Melbourne and Brisbane airports.

For that reason, if the present leasing strategy, a strategy recommended to the government by the best expertise of outside consultants and recommended on the basis of feedback from potential bidders, is blocked by the Senate, the entire leasing process will of necessity be put on hold. As a result, the aspirations of Melbourne, Perth, Brisbane and Adelaide for new airport operators will be frustrated by the economic irresponsibility of the federal coalition. In addition, work on the upgrading of Adelaide airport's main runway will also be delayed as funds for this project are predicated on the leasing of Sydney.

At the same time, the value of Sydney airport itself is depreciated by the coalition proposal to make its leasing conditional on an intersecting runway configuration, a configuration involving dependent cross-runway jet operations. According to Air Services Australia, this would cut Sydney's capacity by up to 35 per cent while guaranteeing that the airport is operated in a manner that does not maximise safety. Again, in the interests of protecting the taxpayer and flying public, the government cannot accept such a naked attempt to vandalise the process. Any government that did would be grossly negligent.

If the coalition persists with its attempt to stymie the leasing process, it will have to bear responsibility for the resulting impact in delaying the development of Sydney's second airport, which is at Badgerys Creek. Under the government's leasing timetable, the target date for completion of the first stage of Sydney West is the end of 1999. To meet this target, the government has approved planned expenditure of nearly $1 billion on the airport and associated transport links.

The first stage of development, built to a standard to accommodate major domestic and international jet traffic, will include a 2,900 metre runway, a 10,000 square metre passenger terminal, parking spaces for up to four B747s and four B737s, and international standard air traffic control, rescue and fire fighting facilities.

Under the government's leasing strategy, the FAC will retain contractual responsibility for the development of Sydney West airport until it is leased jointly with Sydney airport. The lessee will then be required, as a condition of the lease, to complete the first stage of Sydney West to the government's specifications and timetable.

The leasing process provides the revenue to construct Sydney West via a special levy at Kingsford Smith airport. Therefore, any delay in the leasing of Sydney sabotages what is a critical and tight timetable for the new airport. It would certainly guarantee that Sydney West is not available in time for the year 2000 Olympic Games. If the opposition persists with their threat to block the legislation, then responsibility for delays and traffic chaos at the time of the 2000 Olympics will rest squarely upon John Howard and his colleagues.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Government's Policy and Future Arrangements

PARA.TAB: I will now turn to the general principles underlying the leasing process, many of which are reflected in the objects clause of the bill. The key points to note are:

SPEECH.PARA: .the airports must be majority Australian owned;
.the government will seek diversity of ownership to the maximum extent possible;
.the government will encourage transparency and benchmark competition between the airports;
.as a minimum, there will be the separate ownership of Sydney, including Sydney West, from Melbourne and Brisbane airports;
.ownership of the airports by individual airlines and associated interests will be restricted to five per cent;
.the Commonwealth will retain responsibility for land use, planning and building controls at the major airports;
.the Commonwealth will retain reserve powers to deal with demand management issues that may arise during the 50-year leases.
By enforcing these principles, the government hopes to see Commonwealth ownership through the FAC replaced by strategic, well-resourced private sector organisations. They will be capable of:
.developing and operating the airports in accordance with best international practice;
.using local industry and local headquarters to promote Australia's interests in the region; and
.boosting the export of aviation services throughout the world.

In seeking to give effect to these objectives, the Commonwealth has undertaken extensive consultation with a range of interested parties, including the states and territories, local government, the airlines, the aviation industry, other airport users and potential investors. This consultation process included a market testing program in February this year and the circulation in August of a package that included drafts of the two airports bills. These processes worked well and the comments received have helped shape the final regulatory arrangements.

PARA.TAB: The Airports Bill and the Airports (Transitional) Bill provide the legislative framework for the granting of leases to airport specific companies initially owned by the Commonwealth. The companion bill, the Airports (Transitional) Bill 1995, being presented on behalf of my colleague the Hon. Kim Beazley, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance, provides the legislative basis to facilitate the leasing of the major federal airports. It provides for the granting of leases, the transfer of assets and FAC staff to the airport companies, and related sales matters.

The Airports Bill sets out the details of the post-leasing regulatory arrangements to apply to the airports. Responsibility for the regulation of on-airport matters, which currently resides with the FAC as a self-administering government authority, will remain with the Commonwealth at each `core regulated airport', as well as other airports specified in the regulations. Core regulated airports listed in the bill are: Sydney KSA, Melbourne, Brisbane, Perth, Adelaide, Darwin, Hobart, Launceston, Townsville, Coolangatta, Canberra, Alice Springs and Sydney West.

In accordance with the government preference for a general economic regulator, rather than an industry specific arrangement, responsibility for the administration of government policies in relation to airport pricing and related post-leasing matters will be administered by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, ACCC.
These new roles will not alter or interfere with the cornerstones of our aviation policy arrangements or the important roles currently performed by individual agencies including:

SPEECH.PARA: .the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, which will have primary responsibility for air safety in Australia;
.Airservices Australia, which will oversee the national airways system, air traffic services and aviation rescue and fire fighting services; and
.the Department of Transport, which will retain responsibility for aviation security arrangements as well as aircraft noise, engine emissions and curfew policy.

PARA.TAB: To ensure successful operation of the airports, it will be essential for airport operators to understand and respond to the needs of communities, passengers and airlines. Indeed, given their critical importance and potential impact on communities and regions, airport operators will have to be doubly sensitive to local issues, especially those involving noise.

The legislative provisions require airport operators to advise on all consultations undertaken with key stakeholders such as the states and territories, local government bodies, airlines and other interested parties, both during the process of developing draft master and major development plans and environment plans and prior to such plans being released for public comment. The public comment provisions then require airport operators to advise the minister on the public comments received and to have due regard for these comments. In addition, opportunities for comment and consultation now available under current price oversight arrangements will apply when this becomes the responsibility of ACCC post leasing.
A number of other provisions in the bill underline the government's commitment to retaining effective public interest regulatory control. Provisions include the requirement that:

SPEECH.PARA: .leases can be transferred only with ministerial approval;
.the airport-operator company will have statutory authority to use the airport site as an airport; and
.the airport leasing company will be restricted to carrying on activities related to or incidental to airport operations.

The last of these will ensure that airport operators are not distracted by non-airport activities and that airports are not put at risk by unrelated or non-core financial activities. The provisions will, however, allow airport operators to become involved in land transport access improvements.

PARA.TAB: The leasing provisions will ensure that current leases with the FAC become subleases, including the domestic terminal leases held by the airlines as well as leases held by other on-airport businesses. All such leases will be transferred with existing obligations and benefits intact. Similarly, airport operators will be required to make payments in lieu of rates as the FAC currently does.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Restrictions on ownership and control of airport-operator companies

SPEECH.PARA: .The bill requires airport-operator companies to be majority Australian owned, limiting the maximum level of foreign ownership to 49 per cent. It backs up the `Australian' status of airport-operator companies by requiring that a majority of directors be either Australian citizens and/or residents and that central management and control be exercised from within Australia.

.In addition to the five per cent limit on airline ownership, the airport-operator company will also be subject to a 15 per cent limit on cross-ownership for the major airports: Sydney and Sydney West together with Melbourne; and Sydney and Sydney West together with Brisbane.

This restriction will be further supplemented by a ministerial power to declare a person to have `practical control'; that is, control through some arrangement or agreement but which does not breach the 15 per cent cross-ownership limit.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Land Use, Planning and Building Controls

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth will retain control over land use, planning and building at the major airports. This will also ensure a nationally consistent approach to planning and building matters.

Under current arrangements the FAC is responsible for land use, planning and building approvals at its airports. The FAC consults with state, territory and local governments, the airlines and other airport users on proposed airport developments. This legislation builds on and strengthens these arrangements, particularly in relation to land use planning. This will help ensure compatible development in noise affected areas off-airport.
Under the bill, each airport-operator of a core regulated airport will be required to prepare:

SPEECH.PARA: .an airport master plan—essentially a long-term land use plan appropriate to meet the forecast demands over a 20-year planning period—and

.development plans for any major projects—for example, runway and terminal developments—at airports which will require environmental impact assessment (as is currently the case where significant environmental impacts would result).

These master plans and major development plans will be subject to ministerial approval. The bill also requires the airport-operator company to undertake a `public comment' process with master plans, major development plans and environment strategies.

PARA.TAB: The detailed arrangements will be set out in regulations to be developed in consultation with the industry and other interested parties. The Airports Bill allows the regulations to specify matters to be addressed by airport operators in developing their draft plans. This will ensure there is flexibility and scope to address emerging issues.

The Commonwealth recognises the legitimate interests of the states and territories in planning issues relating to airports and wishes to achieve appropriate outcomes in this important area. Through the provisions in the bill and the administration of the new regulatory arrangements, the Commonwealth will pursue the orderly planning and development of airports.

There is, in particular, substantial scope to protect areas surrounding the major airports from residential and other development incompatible with the long-term use of the airport. Whilst constitutionally this is a state responsibility, the Commonwealth is committed to working closely with the states and in turn expects the states' cooperation on land use planning in the vicinity of airports. This will be fundamental to avoiding any repetition of the problems created by inappropriate state and local government approaches to zoning and development around some of Australia's major airports.

The leasing process has provided the opportunity to review current processes and put in place arrangements to ensure improved environmental planning in the future. The leasing process is designed to guarantee responsible environmental behaviour by all new airport operators.

A vital new element will be the requirement to develop and implement approved environment management strategies. The development of these strategies by airport operators will be required to exhibit due regard for the range of public comments likely to be received—including from state, territory and local governments, local communities, and other interested parties—and will be subject to ministerial approval. In this respect, airport environment committees such as those already established at a number of major airports will help facilitate the process.

The airport regulatory arrangements to apply post-leasing will supplement the operation of existing legislation, as well as regulations relating to the curfew, runway operations, flight paths and noise acquisition-insulation programs.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Accounts and Reports of Airport Operator Company

PARA.TAB: Transparency of each individual airport's operations is an important regulatory requirement. The Corporations Law provides a ready source of guidelines and requirements for financial accounting and reporting by airport operators. However, the government will ensure that airport operators report on an airport-by-airport basis both to enable financial transparency and to promote benchmark comparisons between airports. This is an area where the Corporations Law alone will not achieve adequate outcomes because it allows consolidation of the accounts of subsidiary companies.

The Airports Bill therefore allows for regulations that force new operators to produce stand-alone financial accounts and reports for submission to the ACCC. At the same time, the reporting and accounting provisions of the bill encourage the use of common terminology. The government believes such transparency provisions will complement the general economic regulatory approach.

Consistent with the approach adopted by the government in other industry sectors, the ACCC will be responsible for prices oversight of the major airports. Prices surveillance by the ACCC will include monitoring of price caps set by the government at the four major airports—Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport, Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth. The price caps, which will apply to aeronautical charges and be developed as part of the leasing negotiations, will operate for five years.

The pricing arrangements will provide flexibility for caps to be adjusted to accommodate necessary infrastructure expenditure. As well, aeronautical related services will be subject to monitoring at these four airports by the ACCC. This decision follows concern about the potential for the exercise of market power in the provision of those services. At other regulated airports, aeronautical charges will be monitored by the ACCC to enable an assessment of pricing levels post-leasing. To ensure their continuing adequacy, these arrangements will be reviewed before the end of the first five-year pricing period.

The bill places a restraint on the Commonwealth not to close or vary airport leases without the consent of the lessee. An airport lessee company may, however, choose to surrender an airport lease to the Commonwealth on mutually agreed terms. Under the proposed airports regime, airport operators will be required to act in a manner consistent with international obligations. If necessary, specific regulations made to this effect can cover all major airports in Australia, not only those currently operated by the FAC.

Regulations can be made under the bill to control on-airport activities including liquor, commercial trading in goods and services, vehicle movements, gambling and smoking. In the absence of regulations being made by the Commonwealth, state legislation would apply. The Commonwealth is currently discussing with the states opportunities for their involvement in these areas.

An important safeguard for the current and future operation of airports is established in the bill through provisions covering the protection of airspace. The bill provides that a declaration of prescribed airspace can be made in the interests of safety, efficiency or regularity of air transport operations. Approvals will be required for activities which would result in objects intruding into prescribed airspace. The bill also allows regulations to be made which require a person to advise the airport operator of any proposed intrusion into prescribed airspace.

The government's preference, wherever possible, is for the industry to voluntarily and cooperatively deal with emerging pressures for access to airports. Post-leasing, airport operators will have the ability to set the terms and conditions of access to their airports, subject to ACCC price oversight arrangements and other legislation.

However, given the 50-year duration of the airport leases, difficulties may arise that cannot be addressed by industry alone. Therefore the Commonwealth will retain reserve powers over demand management at airports. The bill includes specific provisions on the ways in which such powers would be used. Those provisions and any potential impact on the financial viability of airport companies would be considered by the government in exercising these powers.

Within the bill there is certainly ample provision for the airport operator, users, Airservices Australia, the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and the public to express their views on airport capacity matters prior to the introduction of such a demand management scheme. In addition, under the bill, any proposed use of demand management powers is subject to review and disallowance by the parliament.

The bill includes further provisions which establish a series of checks and balances on the government and potential airport operators. These include the granting of injunctions by the Federal Court relating to contraventions of the legislation, prosecutions, false or misleading statements or records, review of decisions, delegation of powers and the making of regulations. In addition, most decision making powers in the bill are subject to parliamentary and administrative review.

The legislation allows for much of the fine detail of the regulatory arrangements to be set out in regulations. This is considered appropriate in view of the changing circumstances the Airports Bill needs to address. In developing the regulations required, the government will maintain the successful consultative approach used to develop the arrangements proposed in this bill. This process is appropriate given the wide range of interests including the travelling public, the airline industry, airport operators, potential investors, state, territory and local governments, and the community at large. Our aim is to complete the necessary regulations well before the first leases are finalised.

Most major airports, both here and overseas, have traditionally been publicly owned and operated. The decision to sell long-term airport leases is a major policy initiative which the government believes will further enhance the development of this vital part of Australia's transport infrastructure. The decision is founded on sound economic principles and a sales strategy designed to maximise taxpayer returns. By contrast, the opposition's proposed amendments would be operationally and economically disastrous. They are nothing short of economic voodooism and cannot be taken seriously.

Overseas experience has demonstrated that, despite the high level of public interest in airport operations, with appropriate regulatory oversight the government no longer needs to manage the commercial operation of airports. By ensuring continuing government control over key functions, as this bill has, no area of public interest can be compromised by commercial considerations.

Post-leasing, the Commonwealth's former role will certainly be transformed. The new focus will be on regulatory requirements, including pricing oversight and quality of service monitoring. This is consistent with the thrust of so many micro-economic reforms the government has undertaken. The regulatory arrangements which I have outlined will provide a full range of public interest protections. They will maintain all existing arrangements vital to protecting the public. They represent a significant step forward, breaking new ground in ensuring the orderly development of airports.

Overseas governments have and will continue to look closely at Australia's leasing and regulatory experience. Until recently, it has been an excellent process. Regrettably the opposition is now seeking to delay its implementation for cynical political considerations. In the process, they are greatly inconveniencing a number of large foreign and domestic investors, many of whom have spent millions preparing their bids. We would urge the opposition to desist and to abandon their economically nonsensical approach to this leasing debate. The government is joined by most objective commentators in the belief that this bill achieves an appropriate balance between the need to regulate airports and the desire to promote innovative, service orientated, world leading airport operators.

In commending the bill to the House, I sincerely thank the officers of the Department of Transport who have put a massive effort into this process over the course of the last 16 months. It has been a faultless performance by them and their diligence has been of an extremely high order. I am particularly grateful to Mike Waller and his team for their efforts.

SPEECH.PARA: AIRPORTS (TRANSITIONAL) BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: This bill gives effect to the government's decision to sell the long-term leases over the airports currently operated by the Federal Airports Corporation under a two-phase sales process. A separate company will be formed for the purpose of holding a lease over each airport and relevant FAC staff will be transferred to the new company. In the case of Sydney and Sydney West, the airport companies will have to be purchased by the same holding company.

The bill will provide a sound legislative basis for the leasing of the major federal airports. The bill provides for: the transfer of airport land and associated assets from the FAC to the Commonwealth; the granting of leases over the airports and transfer of associated assets to individual airport companies; and the orderly treatment of the FAC's debts during the leasing process. It also provides for airport staff currently employed by the FAC to be transferred to the airport companies.

The companion bill, the Airports Bill 1995, establishes the regulatory framework to apply to the airports following their leasing. The regulatory provisions contained in the Airports Bill are necessary to ensure that airport users and the general community receive the maximum benefit from the improvements in the delivery of airport services under the leasing process.

The provision of airport infrastructure requires a large amount of capital and, for this reason, airports have traditionally been considered to be the responsibility of government. However, Australian capital markets are now sufficiently sophisticated to support the development of infrastructure such as airports. Given that public interest considerations can be protected through the regulatory framework of the Airports Bill, the need for continued Commonwealth investment in airports is no longer compelling.

In addition, through the involvement of superannuation and investment managers, the airports' leasing will provide an excellent opportunity for the funds of Australian men and women to be productively employed in the provision of national infrastructure. This is to the benefit of all Australians.

The decision to lease the airports rather than sell them under freehold title was motivated by the government's desire to retain some control over the land on which the airports are located. The length of time for which these leases will be granted will ensure that sales proceeds are roughly equivalent to a sale under freehold title.

The lease of the airports is expected to produce a significant net offset to the outlays, with the majority of proceeds scheduled to be received in the 1996-97 financial year. The bill provides for a number of financial transactions necessary to facilitate and account for the leasing process and to allow for the orderly disposal of the FAC's assets. It is expected that these transactions will be budget neutral. As has previously been the practice, the government is not able to reveal details of the estimated proceeds from leasing the airports as this would in all likelihood influence the outcome of the process and would probably see a reduction in proceeds.

The bill now before the House contains a number of measures designed to facilitate the leasing of the federal airports. Under the bill, the land and the associated assets currently held by the FAC will be transferred to the Commonwealth. Once the airport land and associated assets have been reinvested in the Commonwealth, the bill provides for the Commonwealth to grant a lease over the land at a particular airport to a company referred to as an airport lessee company. (Extension of time granted)

Under the proposed airport regulatory regime, these companies must have the status of constitutional corporations incorporated under the Corporations Law. The bill enables the government to adopt a flexible leasing process involving either selling airport companies which already hold leases over the airports or granting airport leases to the airport companies following their sale. In either case, upon the granting of an airport lease, the FAC's contractual rights and obligations at each airport, as well as its liabilities, will be transferred to the relevant airport lessee company.

It is extremely important to the government that the jobs and entitlements of FAC staff are protected under the airport leasing process. The airports are therefore to be leased either with staff in place or with staff transferring to the relevant airport company immediately after leasing. Existing awards, enterprise agreements and contracts of employment will transfer to the airport lessee companies, which will ensure that airport staff retain key terms and conditions of employment as well as entitlements to accrued benefits post transfer. Following the transfer of staff, the terms and conditions of their employment, as contained in awards, enterprise agreements and contracts of employment, will be varied only according to the terms of these agreements.

The FAC head office will continue to oversee the management of the remaining federal airports prior to their leasing. Consideration will also be given to developing opportunities for head office involvement in airport activities, including the possible operation of airports to be leased in the second phase of the leasing process.

In accordance with the government's stance regarding payment of stamp duties in asset sales, the sale of shares in airport lessee companies or the sale of leases over the airports are to be subject to state and territory taxes and stamp duties. This will ensure that state and territory governments receive duties to which they are entitled on sale transactions that take place in their state or territory.

The bill does, however, contain some exemptions from state and territory taxes and stamp duties. These exemptions apply only to those transactions required to structure an airport company for sale with an airport lease and associated assets in place. In this instance, the full value of the airport company will still be subject to state and territory taxes and stamp duties through the sale of shares in the company by the Commonwealth.

From a tax perspective, the government is concerned to ensure that purchasers of airport leases and existing lessees under the FAC are not disadvantaged because of the government's choice of sales mechanism. Put another way, in terms of tax, the government is seeking, where appropriate, to treat the sale as if it were a sale by the FAC in the private marketplace. I refer honourable members to the explanatory memorandum for details.

The bill now before the House contains provisions to permit the FAC to discharge its Commonwealth debt and to allow for the corporation's non-Commonwealth debts to be dealt with in an orderly manner during the leasing process. The provisions contained within the bill, coupled with the existing provisions in the FAC's statute, give the government the flexibility to deal, in due course, with the corporation's debts in the most appropriate manner. The government can assure honourable members that the interests of holders of the FAC's bonds will be taken into account in dealing with the FAC's debts during the leasing process. The bill also facilitates the transactions necessary to ensure that the approach adopted for dealing with those debts is properly recorded in the Commonwealth's accounts.

The airports to be disposed of in the second phase of the leasing process present specific regional and administrative issues which will need to be addressed prior to their lease. For example, the airports of Canberra, Darwin and Townsville are jointly operated by the FAC and the Department of Defence. As such, new operating arrangements will need to be developed with Defence before the civilian facilities at these airports can be leased.

Although a number of the airports to be leased in the second phase have been unprofitable in the past, many of them are expected to become commercially viable under private ownership through cost reductions and improved revenues. For the remaining few that may prove to be commercially non-viable, the government will examine options for securing their future, taking into account the specific financial characteristics of each airport, as well as regional interests and sensitivities.

This bill seeks to provide a sound legislative basis for the leasing of the federal airports and, in conjunction with the companion Airports Bill, is a key element in assisting the government to achieve its leasing objectives. The leasing of these airports represents another step forward in the government's continuing micro-economic reform agenda. The leasing framework will promote improved efficiency in the provision of airport services through the introduction of private sector disciplines, as well as ensuring that the government receives a fair return from divesting itself of a function in which its involvement is no longer essential. I commend these bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Mrs B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I need to say that the government seems to pursue in its second reading speech on the Airports Bill and the Airports (Transitional) Bill its policy of confuse and abuse. The preliminary part of the speech by the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) dealt with the foreshadowed amendments of the opposition, which I will be moving when we consider the bills in detail, relating to the excising of Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport from privatisation until such time as the question of the noise burden over Sydney is dealt with in an equitable and fair manner and there is a resumption of full operation of the east-west runway at that airport. The minister has tried to paint a picture of this being an amendment which will prevent subsequent airports being sold. He also brought up the old furphy of the reopening of the east-west runway being something which is unsafe.

PARA.TAB: To begin with, we might just put a few quotes on the record concerning the safety question. Where else but to begin with Mr W. Pollard, the new CEO designate of Air Services Australia, who on 29 September said this about whether or not it was safe to have crossing runways:

SPEECH.PARA: Throughout the world and in my past experience, there are many airports that have intersecting runways and they are used quite safely. In fact, many airports do not have parallel runways but usually have one north-south and one east-west and many times they are intersecting and it is done safely.
Another quote that is available came from the Regional Airlines Association of Australia in a media release, which states:

The two largest independent regional airlines operating in New South Wales, Hazelton and Tamair, today called on the federal government to reopen the east-west runway and implement long overdue changes to air traffic management procedures. If the east-west runway was used to interleave aircraft arrivals and departures, it would be far safer than the major congestion caused when arrivals are occurring from the north, as aircraft from the south and west approaching Sydney airport currently intersect in the air with aircraft arriving from the north.

Currently, we have intersecting runways in Melbourne, Adelaide and Perth. As I have said to the minister before, how is it that we in Sydney are supposed to be so much less smart than the people who operate those intersecting runways in other cities, or is it that our safety in Sydney is supposed to be more important than that of people in other cities? It is clearly a nonsense argument.

PARA.TAB: Let us move to the bills themselves. Let me say again right from the outset that there are many problems with the bills. As to the nature of the drafting, I would point out that we originally saw an exposure draft. Then would-be bidders were put to a lot of effort in putting in submissions, which were basically ignored by the time we saw the bills, which came in only on the last sitting day of the last sitting.

It is also important to point out that today, as we came into the chamber to debate the bills, the governments themselves have issued some amendments to the transitional bill which also will be moved, I presume, when we consider the bills in detail. But this again just shows the lack of planning on the part of the government with regard to its undertaking of the whole privatisation program. Its desperate greed and grasp for money when it flogs off the assets of Australia and then just spends the proceeds is something that I think Australians have to be aware of. Yes, the coalition is certainly committed to the privatisation of airports and of the FAC, but we believe that a condition precedent with regard to Kingsford Smith airport is not something that can be swept under the carpet and must be dealt with.

The second amendment that I foreshadow I will be moving when we consider the bills in detail relates to the airport at Adelaide. The government has chosen to say that Sydney, Melbourne, Perth and Brisbane are the major airports; it has insulted Adelaide and, indeed, discriminated against it as the only other mainland state capital airport that should not be included in the first stage of sales. So I will also be moving an amendment to include Adelaide on the list of airports that are set out in the transitional legislation.

It is important to note that the transitional bill, in fact, is the mechanism which enables the government to lease all the federal airports as ongoing businesses, with most staff and management in place, under a two-stage sale process. Those airports which are listed in the bill itself are immediately subject to the legislation. All other airports are not subject to the legislation, until such time as regulations are passed to include them or make them subject to the legislation. Indeed, the whole framework of the two bills is merely skeletal.

The real essence of how the airports are to be regulated, the conditions and terms of the sales are all to be set out in regulations—and we have not seen those regulations. Not only have we not seen the regulations but we are not due, apparently, to see them until next February. I understand that undertakings have been given by the government to would-be bidders that they could expect to see them come in in February, and this would give until the end of June, which of course would be after the election, time for them to consider their position.

I believe that the one big complaint of almost all people who are associated with this whole privatisation process has been the fact that the enabling legislation is so sketchy. It is the unknown regulations that we are yet to see.

Let me give you an example of how important documentation can be to this whole process. Because of the standing orders in this place, when the bills came in on a first reading, we did not get a second reading speech, obviously. Here, if a bill is introduced with a second reading speech, the debate must proceed. I understand that that was brought in in order to make the explanatory memorandum explain all the intent of the bill. Well, of course, it does not.

One of the things that was missing from the bill was the very serious question which the minister did address in his second reading speech—and, interestingly enough, when courts are considering legislation and ancillary papers, it is the explanatory memorandum that has standing rather than his speech—when he said that the new airport operators would be required to make in lieu payments for taxes, as the Commonwealth does under a COAG agreement, but for which there is no other obligation to make.

The legislation is silent on that point. We had presumed that the matter would be dealt with by way of either regulation or in the lease itself. And, of course, we the public are unlikely to see the lease because it will be deemed commercial in confidence. So, again, it is important to raise the arguments concerning transparency and whether or not legislation is good or bad legislation when so much is still concealed or unknown at the time of debate of the primary legislation.

At this stage I would like to look at some of the specific problems raised with me and with others in the period of looking at the nature of these bills and what sort of attitude we would have to them. Many problems have been identified, the most important of which is that the bills themselves make only part of the total picture. As one potential bidder stated, the bills are only the tip of the iceberg. The regulations, the leases, the decisions that the government is yet to make regarding the debts of the FAC, the price control mechanism and the quality service monitoring to be undertaken by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission will present the full picture. The basic problem is that the government is proposing to legislate by way of legislation. The bill, as I said, is only part—the major details being left to be filled in by way of that regulation.

There is concern that third parties, such as airlines and concessionaires, may be affected by those other ancillary actions of regulations and leases, some of which will never be seen, yet they will never know the terms and conditions. So we already have a lack of certainty.

The drafting of the regulations, I understand, will begin in November 1995. There has been an assurance from the government to potential bidders that the regulations will be drafted in portions, each portion subject to consultation, as the bills were—although I hope more attention will be paid to the consultation—and that the whole will be in place in February 1995 before the sale process begins.

There needs to be a firm government assurance that the regulations are in place before the sale process begins. Also the government needs to give an undertaking that they will be in accordance with the Legislative Instruments Bill which was introduced into this place in November 1994 but which is still in the Senate. Basically, that bill requires that there will be a mandatory consultation process for all delegated legislation affecting businesses. This process would include the provision of a legislative instrument proposal which analysed the need for the instrument, its costs and benefits and alternative means of achieving those objects. This would ensure that any defects in the proposal are exposed and can be corrected before the instrument is made. Secondly, all registrable legislative instruments would be subject to parliamentary scrutiny. It is very important that subordinate legislation is subject to parliamentary scrutiny.

This act, which has still not been passed, will replace all existing provisions of the Acts Interpretation Act that refer to legislative instruments and enact its own provisions, which include the power of both houses to defer consideration of a motion of disallowance of a legislative instrument for up to six months. Currently, it is 15 sitting days. This will allow the rule maker to remake or amend the instrument to achieve an object specified by resolution of the House.

It is important then, Minister, that you give an undertaking that the regulations will be in accordance with those principles. This would give a degree of accountability. And this process, I might add, was adopted with regard to civil aviation regulations.

The Airports Bill provides for four methods of controlling the use of airports by aircraft once the leasing process is complete and gives the minister reserve powers in demand management at airports. These powers and these decisions are unappealable. The bill enables the minister to formulate a demand management scheme for an airport specifically in these four categories: the category exclusion schemes, slot allocation, movement limitation schemes, and anything else they like.

Before formulating a demand management scheme, the minister is required to declare that the airport is subject to a statutory demand management and declare the capacity of an airport after having received submissions from interested parties regarding the capacity of the airport and taken due regard of any submission received. Nice words. But the important point that needs to be made is that the ultimate declaration powers of the minister cannot be appealed.

There is considerable objection to this when the only reason being given is that airlines require certainty in bookings, which are taken up to six months in advance. These unappealable reserve powers will considerably diminish the appetite for bidders and for the purchase price—something the minister has already spoken about as one of his great concerns. Ideally, the legislation should have made provision for non-discriminatory access and for an appeal mechanism.

Some argue that the category exclusion scheme should only be at the request of the airport operator. Movement limitation schemes: as the airport operators' consent is not required, potential bidders again find this unacceptable, unless compensation is paid to the airport operator for loss incurred.

With regard to the slot allocation scheme, the airport operator, the air traffic controllers and the airlines must be involved in and/or manage any slot allocation scheme, but this is not provided for specifically. There is a feeling that the government should not be involved in this process as they do not have any expertise. However, it is relevant to note that in the final bill there is provision made for a person to be a slot coordinator. The airport operator is not precluded from fulfilling this role.

Another point is that there is no clear definition of the concept of capacity. This is important when considering that the minister retains the power to make capacity declarations in the final bill. Capacity, of course, goes right to the heart of the value of the airport. There is a fear that the airport capacity may be scaled down, thus reducing the potential income of any airport operator. In the event of this occurring, there has been some suggestion that compensation should be paid for potential loss of income.

The bill, again, does not provide for specific consultation with airlines, although clause 186 does allow for public submissions to be prepared by interested parties regarding the capacity of the airport in question. Neither does it require an expert opinion to guide the minister when he takes his decision.

A further important point in relation to part 5 is that the airport is required to have a final master plan, the contents of which shall be outlined in the regulations—once again, the unknown regulations, although the bill does outline the inclusion of some details such as the airport operators' development objectives and the way they see the future needs of civil aviation users of the airport and for services and facilities relating to the airport. These plans are to relate to a period of 20 years.

Points that are made by those who are involved is that the breadth required to be included in this master plan is very wide and may involve disclosing confidential information to the public. It was recommended by potential bidders to include only a major plan. This was not changed in the final bill, although the term for the master plan has been reduced from 25 years to 20 years.

In addition to that, there is a major development plan requirement. Provision is made, again in the unknown regulations, to outline what is to be included in the major development plan. There is a list of requirements to be included in the regulations, such as airport lessee companies' objectives for the development, a detailed outline of the development and their assessment of the extent to which the future need of civil aviation users of the airport are met by the development.

There is some feeling that the details required to be included in the major development plan may be unnecessary. Potential bidders have indicated that they feel major development plans should only include runways, new and major extensions, new passenger terminals, significant extensions to passenger terminals and major non-aeronautical developments.

Minor aeronautical activity, such as taxiways and internal roads, are a function of capacity and therefore are caught by the airport master plan process, so they should not have to be included in the major development plan. This was not remedied in the final bill and the definition was expanded to include the construction of any new buildings where the building is not wholly or principally for the use of a passenger terminal such as multilevel car parks. Many things are of concern to future bidders, who are really only seeing half the picture.

Another point that is raised and requires very serious consideration is price regulation and quality service monitoring. The Airports Bill 1995 provides for regulations to be established which may specify performance indicators to be used in monitoring and evaluating the quality of airport services and the facilities of the ACCC at regulated airports including the ACCC being able to publish reports on quality of service matters. It also gives the ACCC a power over prices regulation.

The Prices Surveillance Authority, which is to be subsumed by the ACCC—and it was supposed to occur in July but has still not yet been gazetted—had a discussion paper included in the legislative package. It is a discussion about price regulation, quality of service and the sorts of tests that may be used, particularly one of price capping. Currently, it is only that—a discussion paper. The government should have the issue of prices regulation established well and truly by the time the sales process begins.

The commercial return particularly is linked to the regulatory framework. Changes to the framework or the imposition of additional requirements and restrictions could cause financial detriment to the airport lessee company. This is a risk that has to be factored in by any potential bidder. It has been suggested by potential bidders that the bill be amended to ameliorate the risk of financial detriment by providing compensation to be paid in case of financial detriment caused by government regulatory change. This has occurred in GBE legislation in the form of financial detriment clauses and in section 70 of the agreement with Optus Communications. So there is precedent.

The bill itself contains detailed provisions for remedying a situation where a lessee company becomes bankrupt. However, it is silent as to how it will ensure that lessees are economically viable whilst retaining the lease. This detail could be found in the lease. However, this means that affected parties, such as airlines, have no access to these terms and, again, we can have uncertainty for tenants within the airport itself.

It is important that the lessee company remains viable and strong, enabling the company to be able to respond quickly when expansion is required or when technology requires updating. It has been suggested that this requirement may be added to the criteria found in the bill itself and that the minister may take into account when making the decision of the granting of the lease.

Then we come to the interesting question of debt. Part 10 of the Airports (Transitional) Bill outlines the treatment of the Federal Airports Corporation's debts. No final decision has been made by the Commonwealth regarding the debts of the FAC. Negotiations are still continuing. The bill outlines that the government keeps the following options open unto itself. What it is basically doing is saying that it may forgive large amounts of debt, as it did with Qantas Airways—$1.3 billion, if my memory serves me.

The provisions that the government reserves unto itself are these: the Treasurer may call up a loan made by the Commonwealth to the FAC; the Commonwealth may take over the FAC's obligations under a loan made to the FAC by a person other than the Commonwealth; the Commonwealth may give the FAC money to enable the FAC to discharge a loan made by the FAC by a person other than the Commonwealth. Essentially, the Commonwealth will step in with two standing appropriations to cover the FAC's debts to the Commonwealth and non-Commonwealth lenders. In the case of a non-Commonwealth lender to the FAC, the obligation is converted into a Commonwealth obligation.

There is another standing appropriation which is a capital advance to the Federal Airports Corporation. It will remain as an operational body through this whole process which, under the government's plan—I stress it is post-election—is meant to be continued until as late as 1998. There is provision for a capital advance to the FAC to carry on, pending competition of any sale by the Commonwealth of a Commonwealth owned company which is a lessee. There is very serious concern about the open-endedness of these three appropriations. The government should be able to make some sort of estimate regarding these figures and then place a statutory cap on the appropriations. Without this cap, the appropriations are almost open-ended, and it is taxpayers' money that it is spending.

There is no indication regarding the allocation of the FAC's debts to each airport, including a $400 million abnormal debt in the 1994 FAC annual report. The FAC as a corporation holds an overall level of debt to the value of $987 million, yet these liabilities have not been allocated to any individual airport. These are important issues as, depending on the level of debt of each airport, airports will be more attractive or less attractive to potential bidders. The government has indicated that, for the most part, borrowings can be linked to specific work projects and that there has been very little network wide borrowing by the FAC.

A further important point is foreign ownership. The schedules of the bill set out a 49 per cent foreign ownership limit, a five per cent airline ownership limit and a 15 per cent cross-ownership limit with regard to the three airports of Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne. The bill does have a definition of a `foreign entity'. But apparently the government has learnt little from its Qantas experience. There is no provision in the legislation which would prevent an airport falling into foreign hands—just as Qantas did. It was unknown for some three weeks whether or not the foreign component of Qantas had been oversubscribed. All remedies contained in this bill are after the event remedies not pre-event remedies, yet there are readily available remedies that could ensure that airports did not fall into foreign hands, as Qantas did when the foreign ownership level went as high as 53 per cent.

In relation to taxation levels, the bill sets out that state government duties are not to be paid on transactions between the Commonwealth and itself, but potential buyers of course will be obliged to pay duty on any transfers for their own transactions.

An important aspect of the bill is the environmental management section. Statutory liens, variations and closures of airport sites, rates payable—which, as I said, the minister has only deigned to address in his second reading speech—and cross-subsidisation of major airports are all issues which remain unsatisfactorily addressed by the legislation.

The Airports Bill provides that a draft environmental strategy will be prepared having due regard to public comment, but it will be for ministerial approval. For each regulated airport, there is to be a final environmental strategy—again, to be approved by the minister. Regulations may deal with pollution aspects of airports—but, again, the power resides with the minister.

In relation to statutory liens, potential bidders are concerned that the operator should have statutory protection to recover its airport charges from airline operators for non-payment of airport landing charges—which the government enjoys itself. The bill further provides for an airport lessee company to be consulted before an airport site is varied or closed, and airport lessee companies may surrender an airport lease to the Commonwealth unconditionally or on such terms as are agreed. Concern was raised over the fact that no provision was made for airlines to be consulted. If airports are to be closed or varied, their flight plans will be varied or terminated.

The question of cross-subsidisation of major airports is one that has been raised particularly by governments in South Australia and Western Australia, where there is concern with the fact that there are no cross-ownership limits between the major airports of Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne. There is concern in Tasmania as well that the airports in Launceston and Hobart could be operated by the same operators and competition could be lessened. The concern is that some of those smaller airports could be used to cross-subsidise the operations of the major ones, whose operations would perhaps be deemed to be more preferable. Again, the situation has not been clarified by the government and it would be good if they would clarify their position on those issues.

I return now to the important question of the amendments that we will be moving when we proceed to the consideration of the bills in detail. We will be moving five amendments to the Airports Bill and five amendments to the Airports (Transitional) Bill. The effect of those amendments will be to excise Kingsford Smith airport from the privatisation provisions so that the privatisation will be postponed, effectively, until such time as the aircraft noise burden over Sydney is more equitably and more fairly shared and the resumption of full operation of the east-west operation at Sydney is accomplished.

We realise that the bill provides, through regulation, that the government could restore Kingsford Smith airport according to the list set out in the transitional bill, but we have provided for that by moving that the regulations may not so restore Kingsford Smith until such time as those requirements as to fairness and equity and the reopening of the east-west runway have been achieved. Adelaide is, as I said, also important, and we can see no reason why South Australia should be discriminated against in this way. I noticed on page 2 of the minister's second reading speech that he deigned to include concern for Adelaide, but I do not see in his amendments to be moved any attempt to include Adelaide in that first stage of sales.

I conclude by saying that the opposition's position is very clear. We favour the privatisation of the Federal Airports Corporation and thereby the privatisation of the airports, but we do not believe that it can be done without addressing the important question of the noise over Sydney caused presently by shutting the east-west runway and by other managerial arrangements implemented by the current Minister for Transport. It is within the power of the minister to address—today, if he wishes—those concerns of the opposition. He can start to address those questions of noise and their equitable solutions and their equitable treatment straightaway. We are quite firm that, unless our amendments are agreed to, we will oppose the legislation.

We were told a fortnight or so ago, the last time we had a debate on this matter in this House, that people like Max Hazelton and the regional airlines of Australia did not want to reopen the full length of the east-west runway for normal operations. Indeed, it was interesting to note that that was a complete and deliberate deception. Max Hazelton and Tamair, which are the two biggest regional airline operators I think we have in New South Wales at present, both want and have stated on several occasions that they want—and restated on 28 September, a couple of weeks ago—the whole length of the east-west runway reopened.

We have sat here and listened to arguments put by the Minister for Transport and the Prime Minister that it would be unsafe to reopen the east-west runway. We have sat here and been told that people in the airline industry do not want to have the east-west runway reopened. That is simply untrue. We have been told that there are experts around the world who agree with the government that it is not safe. That is not true also.

There is a long list of experts who will tell you that you can quite safely operate an intersecting runway operation at an airport like Mascot and many other airports around the world. I just mentioned Max Hazelton. Dr Fred Bell, who was consultant to the airport coordinating task force in 1990, has said that you can do precisely that. Dr Fred Bell, who you would assume is an expert because the government employed him to advise them when they put the airport coordinating task force together in 1990, also says that it is quite safe to do it.

Dr Jean Cross, Professor of Safety Science at the University of New South Wales, will say the same thing. Captain Peter Skinner, President of the Australian International Pilots Association, has said publicly and privately—he will repeat it—that it is safe to operate intersecting runways at Sydney's Mascot airport and that the east-west runway should be reopened. The new head of Airservices Australia, which is a body in charge of air traffic control services in Australia, was interviewed from the United States upon the announcement of his appointment to the new job. He said on an ABC program that day:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . throughout the world and in my past experience, there are many airports that have intersecting runways and they're used quite safely. TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on this important legislation—the Airports Bill and the Airports (Transitional) Bill—I want to address a couple of the major issues which it raises. In the late 1980s the government corporatised airport ownership and operations, with the objective of removing taxpayer subsidies to and improving the efficiency of airport operations. A close look at the operations of the Federal Airports Corporation shows that these objectives were only partially achieved. The reality is that very substantial implicit subsidies continue to exist, particularly at Sydney airport.

PARA.TAB: One of these implicit subsidies was the absence of any recognition of the cost of noise on residents. I am glad to say that the noise tax arrangements introduced by the government have gone some way to redressing this issue. I note that there has been some criticism of the noise tax arrangements. I reject that criticism.

These arrangements mean that for the first time the very substantial impact of noise on residents is being reflected in the pricing arrangements facing the people who cause that noise—the airlines and their customers. It is an example of the `polluter pays' principle at work. There ought to be more of it. Of course, they also mean that funding is available for practical measures to help some of those most severely affected by noise.

The implicit subsidies I referred to a moment ago also arose from the absence of proper competitive pressures on the Federal Airports Corporation, allowing there to be a wide range of irrational cross-subsidies in airport operation and mis-valuation of airport assets in the FAC's books. I welcome the fact that the unbundling of airport operations represented by this legislation will partly redress this issue too. But the benefits of the legislation do not stop there.

For one thing—and I know this from my personal involvement as an ERC minister—there would not have been a decision to build Sydney's second airport at Badgerys Creek before the end of this decade if there had not also been a decision to lease the airports. This is because these bills create the possibility of a very innovative funding arrangement which completely protects the taxpayer from the risk of financing such a major piece of infrastructure.

Finally, these bills provide a substantial improvement in democratic control over airport development in this country. The fact is that the Federal Airports Corporation has been an out of control government quango. It has been exempt from the discipline of the marketplace and it has been exempt from proper democratic control.

Under this legislation, in contrast, the lessee must develop a master plan. Ministerial approval will be required for the master plan. Ministerial approval will be required for significant development projects. Ministerial approval will be required for environmental plans. And the minister will have the power to institute demand management arrangements. I believe that under this legislation the Commonwealth government will retain to itself the power to do everything that needs to be done to fix Sydney's airport problems. That is not the case under the current arrangements.

I now turn to what I believe those solutions to be. The government has decided that Badgerys Creek airport will be available for use before the end of the decade. As an ERC minister, I was well placed to press for that outcome. In doing so, we kept open the outcome that Badgerys Creek can be used to provide real and substantial relief from the noise of Kingsford Smith airport. There has been some criticism that this is not explicit in this legislation. This criticism is misplaced. The leasing documents will require the new lessee to develop Badgerys Creek airport to the standard required by the government. That is appropriate. It is absurd to suggest that a precise building plan should be enshrined in legislation.

Now that we have decided that the second airport will be available, we must ensure that the airport is used. This requires an ongoing, comprehensive program of development of Badgerys Creek airport and a program of transfer of certain aircraft operations to that airport. The government has started out on this path with its proposals to tighten the curfew. I welcome these decisions.

In the negotiations to occur over leasing the airport next year, following the completion of the due diligence process I understand to be under way at present, the government needs to make clear what its long-term plans for the airport are. I believe these plans should involve a transfer of aircraft operations to Badgerys Creek, starting with further extensions of the curfew at Kingsford Smith airport, direction of all freight only aircraft to Badgerys Creek, direction of all charter operations to Badgerys Creek and, over time, direction of an increasing proportion of international traffic to Badgerys Creek. Most international traffic, of course, is less sensitive to the greater distance to the central business district than is most domestic traffic.

In passing, I note the absolute hypocrisy of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) on this issue. He tried to mislead the people of his electorate and others in the inner city that he would send all international traffic to Badgerys Creek. Under pressure, his aviation spokesman, Senator Parer, revealed that he would do no such thing, resulting in a complete backdown on the issue. He has been rightly condemned by the people of the inner city for this ham-fisted attempt to mislead them. His deception does not stop there as I will elucidate in a moment.

My proposed program of transferring demand to Badgerys Creek would of course induce further domestic demand in order to service this traffic as well as to take advantage of the natural attractions of Badgerys Creek, which I will come to in a minute. Obviously, the facilities at Badgerys Creek would need to be sufficient to cope with the demands generated. In particular, a 4,000-metre runway will be required. These leasing bills and the associated price capping arrangements provide a ready method by which this development can be funded. I add that I believe the rail connection should be included in this arrangement, possibly as a loan to the New South Wales government.

I welcome the paper by the Prices Surveillance Authority on the broad principles that would apply in administering the price capping arrangements. There are some positive features in this paper, particularly the clear recognition that, as intended by the government, the new lessee can recover the costs of developing Badgerys Creek airport from charges at Kingsford Smith airport. However, I do have a couple of concerns with the PSA approach.

The PSA's prime objective is to minimise the costs to consumers, consistent with efficient economic outcomes. That is a laudable and appropriate objective for that organisation. However, in the case of airports it is clear to me that the full value of airport land is not reflected in the FAC's books. At Kingsford Smith, for example, the FAC valued its pre-third runway land at around $75 million. For some 700 hectares of prime inner city industrial land, this is absurd. The effect of this undervaluation is that an implicit taxpayer subsidy to the aviation industry remains through the fact that the taxpayer is not receiving a full rate of return on the asset employed. In my view, the PSA should investigate this issue. If I am correct, the PSA should allow airport charges to adjust upwards accordingly, with any excess profit available for Badgerys Creek and the associated infrastructure, including the rail link.

The second issue of concern about the PSA's approach is whether the PSA will recognise the complexities and subtleties the new lessee will face in relation to the complementary development of Badgerys Creek and Kingsford Smith airports. It is important that the new lessee not act the way the Federal Airports Corporation has in strongly favouring Kingsford Smith airport over the second airport at Badgerys Creek for reasons that have much more to do with the institutional interests of the corporation than with the efficient provision of airport services. In particular, it is important that the natural attractions of Badgerys Creek, such as its lower land value and lower noise impact, be reflected in its pricing.

I believe that my proposed program of transfer should be achieved using the powers the minister retains under this legislation. In particular, demand management arrangements should be used to ensure that such a program is implemented. The minister's power over development approval should be used to effectively cap the operation of Kingsford Smith airport.

There are some misconceptions about the nature of capacity at Kingsford Smith airport. The 1991 environmental impact statement on the third runway was predicated on 303,000 annual aircraft movements at the airport. Any increase in the usage beyond this level would therefore represent a misleading of those affected on the true nature of that proposal.

The EIS suggested that this level of activity would be achieved in the year 2010, but experience has shown, as I predicted at the time, that demand growth would be much more rapid than assumed and hence this level of demand would be achieved very much sooner than that. However, that same EIS quoted an ultimate capacity of 353,000 annual aircraft movements—a figure that is often mentioned in debate.

What is often ignored in the debate is that this figure assumes a particular peaking pattern and a particular mode of operation of the airport. The fact is that capacity at the airport can be expanded above this level by a spreading of the peaks and measures to further increase hourly capacity. Possible measures to increase hourly capacity have been listed in a recent report of the tourism task force and Sydney City Council.

Residents of the inner city already badly affected by aircraft noise have a great deal to fear from these proposals. They are to reopen the stub of the east-west runway for commuter aircraft and to allow take-offs to the north on the new runway for jets such as 737s. It disturbs me very much that the opposition's transport spokesman alluded to precisely these proposals in his speech on the curfew bill recently.

It is absolutely clear to me that the way the opposition leader would reconcile his commitment to reopen the east-west runway with the realities of airport operation is to adopt these proposals. In so doing, he would increase airport capacity by a further 10 per cent or so. This is the nature of the deception I believe him to be engaged in on this issue. The only alternative explanation for his statements is that he would be perfectly happy to accept a significant reduction in capacity at the airport, despite his longstanding support for the construction of the third runway. He will excuse my incredulity.

Together, peak spreading and greater hourly capacity could lift the ultimate capacity of Kingsford Smith airport beyond even this higher figure. Obviously the noise impact of any additional traffic would be even more unacceptable than the present situation. I understand that the Sydney airport management of the FAC has developed a fantasy development plan entitled `Terminal 21' to meet a higher level of demand. That is totally unacceptable to me and, I understand, to the government.

There is a positive side to my proposals. A persistent feature of this debate has been a failure to recognise the real attractions of Badgerys Creek to the aviation industry and its customers. The new airport will be of modern design with much lower operating times and hence operating costs than the poorly laid out, small, congested airport at Kingsford Smith. It will be congestion free. It will be curfew free. It will be able to handle the next generation of large jets. It is closer to a large and growing proportion of Sydney's industry and population. It will impose very much less noise on residents, and uses cheaper land than Kingsford Smith airport, both of which should be reflected in lower landing charges. It is in the region with the third highest unemployment rate in the country.

I understand the concerns of western suburbs colleagues that the problems of Kingsford Smith not be simply transferred to the west. I agree completely with that proposition. It is important therefore that the lessons of the Kingsford Smith experience be learnt and that proper analysis of potential noise and other environmental impacts and planning controls put in place to prevent residential development in affected areas.

I know that the airlines are reluctant to use Badgerys Creek. I believe that this partly reflects the fact that congestion at Kingsford Smith airport represents a backdoor two-airline policy and hence that there is an element of vested interest in the two airlines in adopting that position. I also believe, however, that their reluctance reflects a concern that a program of transfer could disadvantage one airline relative to another in the marketplace. I accept that the proposed program must be careful to avoid this outcome.

I welcome the initiative by the government represented by these bills. They create the possibility of decisions over the next two or three years to provide real and substantial relief for those affected by noise at Sydney airport. My concern from now on is to ensure that this possibility is achieved in actuality.

I believe that the opposition's position on the issue relating to the east-west runway and the confused and contradictory statements emanating from the opposition about the future development of Badgerys Creek simply exemplifies the total policy bankruptcy of the opposition on this issue. The reality is that the coalition has over the years shown an absolutely hypocritical double standard on this issue. If you go back to the earlier days of this debate in 1989, the now opposition leader was not only supporting the development of the third runway but in repeated statements was endorsing the switch to configuration of the traffic on the north-south axis as a virtue.

Will this opposition, if it secures government, set the pattern in relationships and arrangements in the bureaucracy that starts the groundwork for an introduction of a goods and services tax?
