—My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Can he advise the House of progress in implementing lower tax compliance costs? Is the Assistant Treasurer aware of any proposal to rapidly escalate the tax costs to small and medium sized businesses? Is the government intending to introduce such an impost on Australian businesses?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gear The Hon G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Dunkley for his question. The government is concerned to work with the taxpaying community to lower compliance costs. Recent initiatives that we have taken include completely rewriting the tax act and having the Taxation Office work with small businesses to lower costs for both state and federal taxes. We have also instituted the tax commissioner's liaison committee and also the financial products consultation. The recent passing of legislation in this parliament will reduce the compliance costs on the fringe benefits tax.

PARA.TAB: There is, however, a tax that has enormous costs for small and medium businesses. I refer to the GST, which is now squarely back on the coalition's agenda. In simple terms, this tax would devastate small business and a number of studies have been carried out which would support this. The first one I point to is a study carried out in New Zealand in late 1991 and early 1992. The New Zealand Institute of Policy Studies, which is non-political, carried out a major investigation into the compliance costs of business taxes in New Zealand. It was funded by the New Zealand tax office and had the support of the New Zealand Society of Accountants. The report found:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . very clearly the disproportionate weight of compliance costs of GST on small firms . . . on average, for every $1000 of goods and services sold, the compliance costs of the firms in the smallest category is $26.61; the corresponding figure for businesses in the largest category is 5.4 cents. The smallest firms have compliance costs which, proportionately, are almost 500 times—

If that is not bad enough, we should consider the impact that these costs would have on small businesses when they are competing with their larger competitors. A study of the British VAT in 1986-87 by Professor Cedric Sandford concluded:

. . . where small firms are competing in the same market with large firms . . . they are being put under a state-created comparative disadvantage. They cannot pass on their compliance costs to the same extent as the largest firms . . . compliance costs then become a factor helping to push small firms out of particular markets.
Even the Leader of the Opposition admitted the high costs when he was Treasurer. On 12 March 1981, when he introduced a ministerial statement on the taxation system, he said:
A multi-stage VAT was rejected fairly quickly because it would have imposed an enormous paper work burden on both taxpayers and collecting authorities.

That was his position back in 1991. What is it this year? On 2 May 1995 a headline in the Australian reads `Howard leaves the door open on GST'. In the concluding paragraph, when he was asked about the GST, he did not give it away. The article states:

`We were talking about the last election. I mean you can criticise the marketing. You can say with the benefit of hindsight there is nothing wrong with it, but it was very, very poorly marketed', he said.

He said nothing about disowning it. The door to the GST is completely left open, even though in 1981 he acknowledged what everybody else around here knows—that the compliance costs of this tax are considerable indeed.

PARA.TAB: But perhaps the impact on small business is best summed up in the January 1993 issue of Australian Small Business and Investing where New Zealand accountant John Morine gave Australia's small businesses a more explicit warning. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: If and when a consumption tax or GST is introduced in Australia, your personal stress level will rise sharply. Sunday at the beach with the family will be a thing of the past, as you spend your "leisure" time grappling with GST returns and trying to unscramble your accounting records from taxation complications you do not understand. You should consider how you will cope when you lose one day per week to GST, whether your business will survive and what you are going to do about it.

So here we have a situation where the GST is clearly back on the agenda. As usual, there has been nothing from the opposition's Treasury spokesman. He leaves it to his parliamentary secretary. But you cannot blame the parliamentary secretary because he is only agreeing with his own leader and he is saying publicly what they are all saying privately—that they still believe in a GST.

It is not only nurses, who are offside with the Court government, teachers, who are offside with the Court government, police, who are offside with the Court government, waterside workers, transport workers or any others you might call militants but the entire paid work force and the business community in Western Australia who are protesting about the industrial relations regime in Western Australian—not just this legislation, which is extremely bad, but the management as well.

If those opposite want to talk about the effects of it, let us have a bit of straight talking. I see the member for Chisholm has disappeared, as well he might. He, as a medical practitioner, which he is, asked me a question a little while ago about the effect of the blockade on radioactive isotopes. I am not an expert in this area, but I think it needs to be said that the member for Chisholm would have known when he asked me the question that he was deliberately trying to mislead this House, because those isotopes—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The minister will not make a charge like that unless she is prepared to substantiate it by motion. Minister, you will withdraw that.

—I withdraw that. I will simply say that the inference to be drawn from the information contained in his question was misleading because he said the isotopes would affect the treatment of people with cancer. I say this to the House: the isotopes are for diagnostic imaging, they come in kits, they are available for a week's duration and there is delivery once a week. They are predominantly used for imaging and not treatment. There is no harm to patients in any case, even if the hospitals had not taken any precautions. So the member for Chisholm, the opposition spokesman on health, a doctor, full well knowing this information, asked a question deliberately designed to create an impression at odds with the facts.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. Is the minister aware of reports of criticism that the government has eroded conditions of services for defence personnel? What is the government's response to these reports?

—I thank the member for Macquarie not only for her question but also for her great interest in the welfare of the defence community. This suggestion comes from the speech recently on defence by the Leader of the Opposition. It is interesting to note that basically it is just a rehash of that tired old line that was first put out in that very tired document The Things That Matter. So it is not even an original line.

PARA.TAB: Let's look at the evidence. Firstly, let's have a look at housing. When this government first came to office, defence force housing was an absolute disgrace. In fact in some places—and Holsworthy comes immediately to my mind—it resembled more like something from a Soweto ghetto than something befitting our armed forces. This was as a result of the total inaction of the coalition government.

In 1986 this government embarked on a 10-year $750 million program to fix defence housing. Today, over 90 per cent of defence houses have either been replaced or upgraded. If that is not telling enough, the most telling statistic in the area of defence force housing is simply this: in real dollars—in real 1995 dollars—this government spends six times more on defence housing than the coalition ever did.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much!

—Six times. To put it another way: from 1977 to 1982 in real 1995 dollars the average annual amount spent on housing for each defence family was $1,900. Under the Labor government that annual amount has increased to $11,900 per family.

PARA.TAB: Let's have a look at wages and conditions. This government has acknowledged that Defence Force service is different from every other form of employment—we said it in the white paper—and that is why we set up the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal some years ago. As a result of the combination of the tribunal and the enterprise bargaining system instituted by this government, ADF pay rates in the early 1990s largely outstripped the growth rates in the general community. Between 1992 and 1994 defence pay rates rose by 9.2 per cent, compared with three to four per cent in the general work force.

In 1994, of course, we also increased the service allowance by 16.7 per cent, effectively giving—and I ask members to take note of this—a total increase in military salary of 11.7 per cent. Further still, on 28 September this year the tribunal endorsed a further 5.6 per cent pay increase for our defence forces, payable over the next year. Add to that the field allowance increase by over 200 per cent and the seagoing allowance increase by over 135 per cent and it is hard to see where wages have been eroded.

Let's turn to child care—an issue which is more and more important to our Defence Force families as each day goes by. How far have the conditions in this area eroded? To put it another way: how much did the coalition spend on child care in their years in office? Not a cent. Under Labor, the Department of Defence has become a leader in the funding and establishment of employer sponsored child care. Four million dollars has been allocated since 1991. Twelve centres are currently operating; two more are in the planning. That is a total of over 530 places.

If you add to that over half a million dollars in support funding for occasional child-care centres and $278,000 in grants for play groups since 1989, you can see that child care was actually an invention for the defence forces that occurred under this government. Let me go on record here and now and say this: there is more to come. There is more to come in terms of child care, spouse employment and assistance for ADF members to buy their own homes, just to name some.

In short, there has been no erosion of conditions for defence force personnel. I say this to the House: long gone are the days when coalition spokespersons could put down bald statements on defence and expect them to be taken on face value. That is because successive Labor governments have delivered not only on strategic thinking and not only on equipment but also on personnel conditions for the defence forces.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Deputy Prime Minister. —On the point of order raised by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Speaker: it may be that technically the Deputy Prime Minister has satisfied the standing orders, but I put it to you that it was such a flagrant abuse of the forms of this House that it is not outside your power and discretion to actually suggest and invite the Deputy Prime Minister to do the right thing. It is a very unreasonable but calculated remark for him to make. Under those circumstances, Mr Speaker, I put it to you that, in respect for the forms of this House, it would not be unreasonable for you to exercise just some discretion just once to require some reasonable standards from these people.

—Order! Resume your seat. I have ruled on this. Under the provisions of the House, unparliamentary language is unacceptable. I required the Deputy Prime Minister to withdraw. He has done so. I just say in passing, however, to the honourable member for Flinders that the comments he just made might be taken on board by members of this place.

—The fact of the matter is that, under the policies that this government has put in place over the last decade, the industrial relations performance in Western Australia until very recently has been the same as for the rest of the country. We have had a substantial reduction in industrial unrest, to a factor of about 10 per cent of what it was at the point of time when we came into office, and Western Australia has been the beneficiary of that.

PARA.TAB: What has been happening in Western Australia over the last few years is that Western Australians have been bolting from the system that Graham Kierath and Richard Court have introduced in Western Australia into the federal jurisdiction. Part of the purpose of the industrial relations legislation, which Graham Kierath is attempting to put in place now is to prevent precisely that.

Incorporated in this set of propositions by Graham Kierath is a proposition that if a group of workers, a group of unionised workers, decide that they want to go to the federal jurisdiction, it is open to the Western Australian state government, effectively, to remove their coverage of that group of workers and institute another union to cover them. That is what this legislation does, among many other heinous things—irrespective of what they think, irrespective of what their views are. So that capacity that they have had in Western Australia to bolt from the Western Australian system, to get into the federal system, is a capacity which is being removed effectively from them. That is the first point I would make in answer to the honourable member.

On the question of what has been going on in the public sector in relation to industrial matters in Western Australia this year: you have had rolling strikes and industrial dispute virtually all year from the teachers in the government schools system; you have had that virtually rolling through the nurses in the hospitals; you have had the police in exactly the same position. A wholesale attack has been mounted on public sector workers in Western Australia.

Intimidation works in some cases; it worked for a period of time in Western Australia. Then after a period of time, because Australians basically are decent, egalitarian, democratic people, they will in the end stand up for their rights. They will in the end do that. That is precisely what they are doing in Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel in his capacity as representing the Minister for Defence, and it concerns Australia's defence relationship with the United States. I ask the minister: can he advise the House of the details of Australia's defence relationship with the United States and can he advise the House whether the government has neglected that relationship?
—I think I will make a few more speeches.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Punch The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope you do. We all hope you will. Just put some details in them as well.

PARA.TAB: I thank the member for Oxley for his question and acknowledge his long interest in defence matters, particularly with Amberley being in his electorate. The Leader of the Opposition claims that the government has allowed the ANZUS alliance to drift and that we have downplayed the alliance with the United States in the 1994 defence white paper.

Firstly, let me quote from chapter 9 of the white paper on alliances. It should interest the Leader of the Opposition to know that, in this chapter, five of the eight pages are devoted to the alliance with the United States. It says quite simply:

ANSWER.PARA: Australia's defence alliance with the United States continues to be a key element of our defence policy and will remain so over the period covered by this white paper.

In essence, what the opposition has done on Australia's defence relationship in respect of the United States is simply to plagiarise from our 1994 defence white paper our ideas and parts of our strategic analysis, and then overlay them with all its prejudices from the 1950s. Let me quote from page 99 of the government's 1994 defence white paper:

US strategic engagement and military presence will continue to be important to the security of Asia and the Pacific over the next 15 years. We will facilitate, when we can, US activities and deployments in the region.
Now let me quote from the recent address of the Leader of the Opposition:
We will strongly encourage the continuation of the United States presence in the Asia Pacific and do more to promote closer ties.
I would like to thank the honourable member for his endorsement of our policy and really say what a pity it is that intellectual property rights do not extend to defence policy.

PARA.TAB: As to downgrading the relationship, it must have been of great interest to the Leader of the Opposition to read in the weekend papers what General Colin Powell, the retired chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, had to say on the Australian relationship. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: "We had to find reasons just to get together,"
"I mean, the relationship has been so strong, World War I, World War II, Korea, Vietnam, Desert Storm . . . you name it . . . "

I don't cite General Powell in a partisan political way, but his comments certainly illustrate the point that the Leader of the Opposition is a long way from the mark. I ask those people who make their decisions at the ballot box about defence issues to compare this with his comment that this alliance is somehow drifting due to government neglect.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at some hard facts on some exercises because this, too, is embarrassing to the Leader of the Opposition. In 1994-95 there were 28 exercises with the Americans, of which 20 were conducted in Australia. There were over 2,100 US service personnel here in Australia and over 130 aircraft and 25 US navy ships visiting in one form or another. Next year it will increase even further to 33 exercises. Four thousand US personnel may be involved and 150 aircraft may be here. Of course, we should all remember the significant contribution and presence of the United States in the recently completed K95 exercise.

How does this stack up against the coalition's record? In 1982, the last year of a coalition government, there were only 21 exercises held with United States forces, and only 10 of them were in Australia—half the amount we had last year. We see all this when the Leader of the Opposition has forgotten to mention that his coalition partners, the Nationals, have said from time to time, and no doubt will again in the future, that we should use the joint facilities as bargaining chips over wheat exports. The defence relationship under this government with the United States has never been stronger. The facts speak for themselves.

—My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. It concerns competition reforms. What progress has been made in implementing the agreements on competition policy signed by the Prime Minister, premiers and chief ministers in April this year? Are those agreements well understood by participants in the reform process?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gear The Hon G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Paterson for his question. It would not surprise you to know that the degree of progress and understanding varies considerably between the states. In New South Wales, the Carr government has moved fairly quickly to implement reforms. This is particularly in the case of access for potential competition for the state rail system. New South Wales is also the only state that has passed enabling legislation.

PARA.TAB: By contrast, Western Australia seems confused about what the reforms it signed up to actually mean. I have a few instances here. The ink was not even dry on the agreements when the state minister with responsibility for the Water Authority announced a privatisation of maintenance work carried out by Water Authority workers. In human terms, this meant that 1,500 low paid mainly blue collar workers lost their jobs. Some of them had been there for 30 years. He said that this was necessary because of the signing of the competition policy agreement.

He was wrong. I have pointed out already to the House on a previous occasion that the natural competitor was sitting there all the time in the Water Authority. It might surprise the House to know that the Homeswest tender for water service supplies was put out for tender on instructions from the minister. The Water Authority actually won that tender. The minister did not believe that a public authority could beat private sector firms and he asked for the Water Authority to check its figures, which it did. It came in with the lowest bid but it was stopped from doing the work. So much for competition policy in the Water Authority.

Then some time later we had the fiasco down at the waterfront. That was when the state government allowed a house builder who has strong anti-union views to be a stevedore on the port. The aim was to save $400,000. It cost the state economy $19 million and we lost the state shipping service. If you had seen this on Monty Python you would not believe it, but this is what is happening in Western Australia.
The simple fact is that, once again, we were told that this was because of competition policy. I have the report from the West Australian of 24 May. It said:
Mr Charlton . . . said their decision to give—

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Buckeridge's company, BAAC Pty Ltd, a contract was all about competition and was in line with the Federal Government's Hilmer report on microeconomic reform.

Nothing of the sort. All it was was a union bashing exercise, but here we have the state minister saying that the Hilmer report made him do it. The state government in Western Australia is not all that bright, but you would expect a little more of somebody who sits in this place. But no, the Leader of the Opposition, who talks about micro-economic reform but does not understand it, put out a press release on 23 May entitled `Hilmer demands Keating back WA over waterfront dispute'. In the body of his press release, the Leader of the Opposition said:

Yesterday's wasteful and widespread industrial action strikes at the heart of Hilmer. Paul Keating must show national—not sectional—leadership by calling on the MUA to accept the tender fair and square.

It was not a fair and square tender. That has been established since. Let us go back to the first part of that. What the Leader of the Opposition is saying in his press release is that this dispute on the Western Australian waterfront was at the `heart of Hilmer'. I am using his own words.

PARA.TAB: The opposition talks about micro-economic reform but it does not understand it. The Hilmer report and the competition policy reforms which flowed from it were about competition, not about being stupid. The sole aim of the waterfront confrontation was to try to bust a union. That failed. It should not come as any surprise to people around Australia that today we have more industrial disputation in Western Australia.

I will go on. A report on the Court government's radical plans for reforming the rest of the public sector was published in the Australian newspaper a couple of weeks ago, under the headline `Public sector revamp plan sparks mass strike threat'. That sounds familiar in Western Australia nowadays. The first paragraph of that report said:
A continuing program of radical public sector reform is proposed by the Western Australian Government and seems set to escalate industrial activity by public servants.
The framework depends heavily on traditional public service activities being sold to the private sector.

ANSWER.PARA: This has got nothing to do with competition policy. Speaking in support of the reforms was the head of the Western Australian government's public sector management office, Dr Paul Schapper. The report said:

PARA.TAB: Dr Schapper told the meeting last Thursday that the public service reforms were essential in the aftermath of State and federal governments' acceptance of the Hilmer Report's recommendations on competition policy.

ANSWER.PARA: Wrong again! These changes in the Public Service or down on the waterfront are driven by ideology, not by competition policy. We have already seen that the established work force, if it is a public sector work force, is not allowed to compete in Western Australia, even if it is competitive and can win a tender fair and square.

PARA.TAB: There is a pattern evolving here—the Western Australian government is so proud of its reforms that it has to blame them on the federal government's national competition policy. This is what it is all about. Now we have the opposition today doing the same thing. The embarrassment felt by those on that side of the House with what is happening in Western Australia must be acute.

What they are trying to say now is that, because we have a strike in Western Australia today, it is somehow the federal government's fault—in exactly the same way as the state ministers and the Leader of the Opposition, who knows nothing about micro-economic reform, are trying to say that the shemozzle—and that is all you can say about what is happening in Western Australia—about these so-called reforms has anything to do with competition policy. It does not. There has only ever been one party in this country that has believed in competition policy for the benefits it can bring to the Australian community and that is the Australian Labor Party.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Costello Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is again directed to the Attorney-General. I refer again to the allegation by Mr Graham Richardson, who said:

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Human Services and Health. Is the minister aware of reports concerning the Commonwealth's commitment to mental health? What strategies is the government adopting to improve mental health services nationally?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lawrence The Hon C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that most members know that this is mental health week. Apparently the Leader of the Opposition—to answer the member's question—in the latest of his vacuous wasteland speeches, last week claimed that the Commonwealth's response to concerns expressed by Brian Burdekin about the neglect of people with mental illness could best be described as half-hearted. That is pretty rich coming from the opposition. The claim is also utterly without foundation.

PARA.TAB: Under the Medicare agreements, mental health has been the responsibility of the states fair and square. We fund, of course, visits to psychiatrists through private health legislation and Medicare rebates, but the provision of public sector mental health is a responsibility of state governments. Nonetheless, we have worked with state governments since 1992 to reform this much neglected area through the national mental health strategy. At the time when Mr Burdekin's inquiry was proceeding—in fact, before the report came down—we allocated some $135 million directly to the states to assist them with necessary reform to their mental health services and to promote the interests of people with mental illness.

Members will know that in 1993 Brian Burdekin handed down his landmark report, and in response we effectively doubled the Commonwealth's contribution to $269 million in line with Mr Burdekin's key recommendations. So there is nothing half-hearted about our commitment at all. In fact, Mr Burdekin at the time welcomed the Commonwealth response and suggested that the states and territories should follow our lead. I would like to quote him:

ANSWER.PARA: also constitutes a clear indication that the Federal Government is now clearly committed to a leadership role in protecting the rights of the mentally ill.

That is another blunder by the Leader of the Opposition—claiming Mr Burdekin's apparent disappointment or our failing to keep pace with Burdekin reforms when that is far from the truth. I wonder sometimes at the contribution of the member for Chisholm. Either he is ignored or the information he gives the Leader of the Opposition is just wrong.

PARA.TAB: What the opposition should do, if they claim to support Medicare, is have a good, hard look at the role the states are playing in the area of mental illness and the treatment of mental illness. If you want to see how the Liberals manage health—mental health problems in particular—look at Victoria. We saw some savage exposition of its health system generally on Four Corners last night. Equally, we could also look at South Australia, Tasmania and my own state of Western Australia, because what we will see is radical funding cuts, ideologically driven privatisations and industrial tyranny, which is having its effect particularly on people with mental illness.

Only yesterday I was forced, after considerable correspondence, to write again to the Victorian Liberal health minister, chastising her for taking funds out of the mental health services more quickly than the Commonwealth has been topping them up. She has actually been removing funds while we have been putting them in under the national mental health agreement—that, in mental health week. That is what is actually going on in the state-run mental health services.

In Victoria funding for mental health services appears to have been cut by 5.8 per cent, yet they claim it is an area where they have been improving their operations. I have asked Mrs Tehan to show cause why the Commonwealth should continue to put funds in when her Liberal government siphons them off and puts them into their own pet projects which have no benefit at all to people with mental illness.

The spotlight has also been on South Australia's mental health system this week, following recent tragic shootings by someone who appeared to have had a history of mental illness. Again, what we see in South Australia is the Liberal-National modus operandi in health generally, and that is a savings driven deinstitutionalisation without any community service. It is unmatched by proper planning of accommodation services, community support and emergency teams. If the Leader of the Opposition was at all clear about what was happening to mental health in Australia, he would be talking to those state governments and others and making sure that they put the money and the services back.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I have received a letter from the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The failure of the Prime Minister to exercise national leadership and condemn the political blockade of Western Australia.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —No-one could be in any doubt after today's question time that the federal Labor government is behind the blockade of Western Australia. They are today publicly supporting a deliberate plan, a policy, to inflict economic pain on the people of Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: It is the first time in Australia's history, to my knowledge, that a government has actually set out to score a base political point by condoning and encouraging union action to punish, by a blockade, the proposed actions of a duly elected government—a government which, in policies announced before the election, stated its commitment to introducing legislation for secret ballots to protect workers in relation to industrial action, for the consent of union members before political donations could be made, and for the prevention of jurisdiction hopping. That is a complete response to the lie the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) told on the Sattler program this morning—a clear distortion of the facts.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The honourable member will withdraw.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw. Today I want to demonstrate the complicity of the government and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), in particular, in this strike. I want to highlight the fact that, rather than acting to prevent this strike action and the economic damage being brought on Western Australia, the Prime Minister has encouraged it, condoned it, and simply cannot help but to seek partisan advantage out of the situation at the expense of the people of Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: As was so clearly demonstrated on radio this morning, this is just an opportunity for him. As we all know, we are heading for a federal election and it truly is the case that this man will literally do anything or say anything for his own political advantage. Amongst the remarks which struck me this morning, which say so much about his attitude, was this: `I would never turn such industrial strife to suit my political purposes.'

He followed up with these words, literally—I wrote them down—`Howard runs a conflict model of industrial relations; the ALP runs a consensus model.' In other words, he took the conflict in Western Australia, which he has been encouraging, then moved on immediately—virtually in the same breath, and without a blush—to make the political point which so demonstrates my thesis. He is the arsonist who lights the fire, then runs back and complains that he did not know about it.

Looking through the development of this dispute, it is incredible for the Prime Minister to say that he did not know anything about it. On 6 September Tony Cooke of the Trades and Labour Council went on 6PR radio in Perth and called for the blockade. He said that he had written to the ACTU—the assistant secretary, Jim Pallas—seeking ACTU support. On 11 September Tony Cooke announced in the West Australian that the ACTU had agreed to support the blockade.

Where was the Prime Minister? Where was he when it was on radio in Western Australia that these guys were going to be running a strike? Perhaps he was at Lindsay Fox's for the day and missed the news. When it was in the West Australian, where was he? Was he out the back somewhere with Warren Anderson? On 25 September Tony Cooke of the TLC in Western Australia said they were going to have the blockade. On PM he said:

SPEECH.PARA: What we've got to do is to inflict harm on the economy of the state.

Where was the Prime Minister that day? Was he down in Queen Street, Woollahra, with his mates in the antique shop, so distracted that he missed the news? I challenge the Minister for Industrial Relations, who is at the desk, to tell us when he stands up whether he retracts his statements of support because on 5 October he is quoted as saying:
Before we—
that is, the federal government: I presume he includes the Prime Minister—
were apprised of what the union had in mind for a blockade at the national level, I had some reservations. But I can say I have none today.

You actually said that, Minister. Where was the Prime Minister that day? Was he down with his new petrol head mate, John Laws, looking at his collection? On 11 October he was in Western Australia and was quoted as having `backed next week's planned statewide strike and blockade of WA business'. The Prime Minister says he did not know anything about it until he got to WA. How come on 12 October, when the Prime Minister was in WA, Jim McGinty was pretty clear about the Prime Minister's attitude—don't forget: McGinty is the head of the Labor Party in Western Australia and is as thick as thieves with Keating—because he said:
Keating is entitled to his point of view but I disagree with it and . . . I don't agree that inflicting economic pain on WA is the way to go. . .

Yet the Prime Minister said he did not know anything about it and, furthermore, he has never publicly supported it. Yet the Labor leader in Western Australia is actually on the record as saying that he did. It is unbelievable.

PARA.TAB: Let me remind you, Minister, that Bruce Chapman, who works for the Prime Minister, was in Western Australia at the beginning of September. What was Bruce sent to Western Australia for? One specific task, and that was to go to Western Australia and find all the ammunition he could in Western Australia's proposed legislation to attack the federal coalition. That is a fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not hard.

—You don't deny it. I thank you for that confirmation. We have it from the minister that you actually had the Prime Minister's bloke in Western Australia looking for the ammunition. This guy who would sell coal to Newcastle fronted up in here yesterday and said the blockade was announced before he even went there: he knew nothing about it. No-one in their right mind would believe what the Prime Minister has to say. The fact is that he has been up to his neck in this dispute.

PARA.TAB: It is not just the Prime Minister who has been involved. The minister, as I have just read to you, has publicly supported it and the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence)—she is not running the Keating line of `we neither support nor condemn' or `we neither confirm nor deny'—has a prerecorded message in her office in Western Australia. If you want the minister for health you ring up her office and are told, `We are all on strike today because we are getting stuck into Richard Court's legislation, and that is the basis on which you as a constituent are denied the basic service of having your local MP available to you.'

There is no question about this whatsoever. The smile on the minister's face confirms the fact that these people have conspired to run this as a campaign. It has nothing to do basically with Western Australia. Western Australia is just your instrument: it is a tool. You have used the people of Western Australia for your own benefit at the political level. I will come to the very headline that you have got in a moment.

I suppose one thing which I find particularly galling in all of this is the extent of the hypocrisy and the lies that these people tell. The minister told a distortion on radio this morning which I have already outlined. The picture those opposite want people to believe is that, since the Liberals have been in power in coalition in Western Australia, there has been industrial mayhem—that it is chaos.

That is why it was so revealing when the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Beazley) got up and said that the level of disputes in Western Australia is the same as the rest of the country. That was something of a boo-boo but, when you look at the figures, you find that the number of days lost per 1,000 employees in WA for the latest year we have got is actually 42. That has dropped since the Labor Party was in office. Go back to 1989: it was 187 days. If you look at the figures, you see that they are not just going backwards: the fact of the matter is that they are lower now than they were under Labor, they are lower now than the national average, and they are lower than for Queensland. That is very revealing, because Queensland has exactly the same state industrial laws as we have federally. When it comes to the so-called industrial mayhem, the fact of the matter is that WA is a land of peace and calm compared with other states in the Commonwealth.

The second message that the government is trying to give to people is that in WA, as a result of these reforms, shock, horror, you could have the same federally if the coalition gets in. What they do not tell you is that people in Western Australia have actually been getting higher wages. In the latest figures, if you take the 12 months to May 1995, and you take all states and territories, guess who had the highest increase for average weekly earnings? The highest increase was Western Australia at 6.1 per cent.

Rather than people having their wages cut, which is the lie you want the rest of the country to believe—this whole dispute is not so much about Western Australia; it is about a message you want to send to marginal seats in the rest of the country—people have got bigger wage increases in that 12-month period than in any other state. The state that has got the lowest figure is Queensland, with minus 2.2. It is the one state that replicates—duplicates—your industrial relations model, Minister.

The third incredible hypocrisy is your claim that the first wave and the second wave are the same. That is basically your line: it is just a nasty, horrid coalition government getting stuck into the workers. That is your line. I want to quote something Tony Cooke said this morning. Tony Cooke is running this strike. He said in respect of the first set of reforms in Western Australia that this was Pol Pot arriving in Western Australia and that people would be dying in the streets, et cetera. There was an article in the Australian this morning by Nigel Wilson, a person who used to work for Carmen, so he is no supporter of ours. He said this about the first set of reforms in Western Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: The change—
that is, the first set of reforms—

was achieved in relative harmony and both sides of the industrial equation accepted that industrial relations had changed irrevocably. West Australian Trades and Labor Council secretary Tony Cooke acknowledged as much earlier this year when he said:

"The legislative agenda and the approach of the State Government has been effective. There is no point in having an ideological blinker on which says, `they must be wrong—they have always been wrong' because they are actually being effective."

The guy running the dispute today as your instrument, Minister, has said that the first set of reforms was effective. You have got the quote here. We will have the distortions by the bucket—the Laurie load—in a moment from you. The Leader of the Opposition said that the model which Tony Cooke has endorsed—and which I have just shown you, Minister, has given the highest wages in the Commonwealth—is a model that we want. It is hypocrisy. You attack us for wanting to cut wages. The fact is that it is our policy to increase people's wages. That cuts at your heart, Minister. That cuts you to the quick. The truth is that after 13 years of the Labor Party the average person has had a cut in real wages. It is the great irony of Australian politics.

PARA.TAB: The Western Australian situation is happening under the government. All these people under federal awards are all out on strike today; actually, I am not sure how many are out because only 400 turned up to the rally. Leaving that aside, the incredible cheek of you people is that this is happening under you, yet you say that this is what had happened under us. You must be a contortionist to understand this. People are losing the value of their real wages today under you people, and you say that is what is going to happen under us. The contortions in logic are incredible.

The Minister for Human Services and Health is saying that we were attacking the unions. She was the minister who actually set out to deregister the teachers union in Western Australia back in 1989. The member for Canning (Mr Gear) is supporting this industrial action, but when his own employees in his own office complain about their situation and take industrial action, he attacks them for doing so. The government will attack people where it suits their political interests, regardless of the facts and regardless of the merits.

The Prime Minister ought to take note of one thing said by one person—that is, Jim McGinty. He is the head of the Labor Party in Western Australia. He demonstrated what leadership was about. He obviously has to work closely with the WA Trades Hall Council; it is important for his political interests that he do so. When it came to inflicting damage on his own people, McGinty knew what was in the public interest. He was prepared to stand up against some of these types and declare himself in favour of the people of Western Australia, not just for the partisan political interests of his federal colleagues. McGinty said:

SPEECH.PARA: Keating is entitled to his point of view, but I disagree with it. While I support the right of people to protest, I don't agree that inflicting economic pain on WA is the way to go.
That is all that we demand of the Prime Minister—to stand in favour of the national interests just for once. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Mr BRERETON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Transport)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is nothing guaranteed to get members of the opposition frothing and bubbling more than working people exercising their right to take industrial action. Nothing gets them more upset and nothing can be more relied upon to rile them and have them in the state they have been in all day today than this issue. It started with their leader on radio this morning. He was absolutely venomous about the prospect of Western Australian workers having the temerity to express their opposition to the most draconian anti-union legislation anywhere in this country since World War II. That is what we have—the most draconian anti-union legislation you can imagine. Working people are up in arms about it and the opposition is absolutely venomous. `How dare they?', they say.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has been trying to tell anyone who will listen for the last few months that he has softened his line about industrial relations. It is the new look John Howard. It is not just the eyebrows that have been trimmed up; this is the new soft, friendly, cuddly, absolute joy to behold to all the workers John Howard. The moment that workers exercise their rights against a vicious conservative government, we see the same John Howard showing his true anti-worker colours. He just cannot help himself as soon as he sees people going about their business, expressing their democratic rights.

This morning the ABC journalist asking the questions on the AM program must have felt like a snake charmer because after each one the opposition leader rose more and more like an agitated cobra. None of that is surprising to us. Right through his political career he has pursued a line that has been characterised by unprecedented industrial confrontation. We only have to look at the results of his years in office. They are well shown on the bar chart that I have here. All these dark lines up the top show that on average almost 600 working days were lost per 1,000 employees between 1976 and 1982. The bottom of the graph shows the Labor years. The average number of working days lost during all of that time was down to 200. It dropped from almost 600 to almost 200—a reduction of one-third. It has still been trending down for the last three years, down to the present number of 70 days. The Leader of the Opposition left it as 790 and now it is down to 70. But, as the Prime Minister so often says, today the Leader of the Opposition would say to Australia, `Let's go back to the good old ways. Let's go back to confrontation. Forget about consensus. Let's go and hop into the workers.'

The fact is the Leader of the Opposition is all about the conflict based model. He has always been about it, and that is in total contrast to the results achieved through 12 years of Labor government. Now he wants to see us go back there. He has his state colleagues, particularly those in Western Australia, starting the work for him and is encouraging them to go all the way. We saw him endorse the Jeff Kennett reforms. Remember Jeff Kennett—the Jeff Kennett who said, `No worker will be worse off. Trust me. Elect me. No worker will be worse off'? One hundred thousand people in the streets of Victoria and 300,000 escaping the federal awards—that is what we have seen down there in a program endorsed by the Leader of the Opposition.

The most recent step is the Leader of the Opposition giving his blessing to the reforms in the Western Australian legislation. He went to Western Australia two months and two days after the second wave was made public and said that it was his template, that it was his model. Of course, he has been backing away from that ever since, but the reality is that he endorsed it. He said that it is his model. It is that model—the one he endorsed—which is provoking the national blockade we are seeing across Australia today as far as the Western Australian state is concerned.

What does it tell us about the prospects for Australian-wide industrial relations? There would be conflict in the workplace Australia-wide were the Leader of the Opposition ever to get himself into power. It tells us that, as far as he is concerned, Australia ain't seen nothing yet. What we are seeing in Western Australia we would see writ large the length and breadth of Australia. The opposition leader endorsed, as he did again this morning, a system that has ministerial discretion to determine minimum wages. Imagine that: forget the tribunals, forget the umpire—ministerial discretion to determine minimum wages. He has used it to determine a minimum wage of less than $16,500.

This is a system with an absolutely impractical and rorted system of secret ballots. People will not be able to have a stop-work meeting for an occupational health and safety issue without a secret ballot and six weeks notice—and the ballot will be conducted not by their union, not by the members on the job, but by the Australian Electoral Commission or by the AIRC. What sort of democracy is that?

This is a system that completely proscribes a union's right of entry and a union's ability to ensure award enforcement. This is a system without any award underpinning whatsoever. There will be no no-disadvantage test in Western Australia. This is a system where donations to the ALP are effectively outlawed—if they come from unions, that is. There is no similar restriction on donations from companies to the coffers of the Liberal Party—not on your nelly.

There will be over there a system where state registration of any union—any union that legitimately seeks federal coverage—can be cancelled. Cancelled by whom? Cancelled by the minister. The coverage of that union's members can be awarded to any union that the minister in Western Australia sees fit to award it to. So here is Graham Kierath with the notorious, infamous second wave.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's wrong; you know that's wrong.

—And you love it, don't you? You love it. That is the system, and that is in the legislation. That is in the legislation pure and simple. So not only do Western Australian workers have their minimum wages determined by the minister—the minister who took $8 a week off the award that was granted by the Western Australian Industrial Relations Commission; that is what he did: when the WA IRC made its award, he cut it down by $8—this is the same dictatorial minister who determines which unions workers will belong to. What sort of state is this? How can anyone with any fairness and any decency anywhere in Australia embrace this. And here is Johnny Howard saying, `Western Australia is our model.'

PARA.TAB: Have a look at Graham Kierath's form through the years. The last thing that happened to him before he became Western Australian Minister for Labour Relations was that he was investigated for award breaches—a terrific reputation and a terrific amount of experience to bring to the job.

This morning on AM a lot of these provisions were run past the Leader of the Opposition. It is fair to say that on that program he publicly endorsed them. But what is worse is that he told a deliberate untruth when he said that the things relating to what happened if a union went into the federal jurisdiction had been taken out. That is what he said, and that is a deliberate and complete untruth.

The Western Australian government has done no such thing. There has been no such modification to the second wave. There is still a provision in the legislation allowing for the deregistration of unions seeking federal coverage and still a power for the minister to award coverage, and this morning John Howard endorsed that. That is what you are all about. That is the conflict model that you think is so terrific.

We only have to turn to Graham Kierath to see the proof of this. He said in the West Australian of 17 August that Mr Howard supported his plans for the second wave and supported them wholeheartedly. That is what he is reported as saying. That is for all to see in the West Australian published on Thursday, 17 August.

Later on he was quoted again, in the Sunday Times of 20 August, as denying that the federal coalition was pressuring him to drop his legislation. He had this to say: `I have had no warning at all. The only discussion I have had with John Howard is with John Howard, and he seemed very supportive of the principles.' We can thank the newspapers for reporting the situation so adequately. Graham Kierath, with his own words—words expressed in the last two months—condemns John Howard and the deliberate untruths that John Howard would put to the Australian people today.

John Howard is supportive of Graham Kierath's principles. Of course, that was an expression that was made immediately before they buckled under the employer pressure, and they dropped the outrageous proposal to deduct union officials' pay during a dispute—that is one thing that they have dropped—and the provisions outlawing donations to federally registered unions and peak councils because they were political donations. They are the only two things you have dropped—nothing else. All the rest of this draconian legislation is still there fair and square. Added up, it is the nastiest piece of legislation and the most anti-labour legislation that we have seen in our time.

The Prime Minister pointed out yesterday the absurdity of the coalition's position. Richard Court and Graham Kierath have introduced completely contemptible, vindictive, anti-worker legislation, and they have provoked an industrial blockade by the targets and the victims of their own legislation. They are responsible for this, and no amount of obfuscation can cover that. No amount of trying to apportion the blame onto this government for legitimate industrial action can hide the facts that this is all the work of vindictive, anti-labour legislation brought in by Graham Kierath and a model that is endorsed by the Leader of the Opposition.

The reaction of the victims is entirely understandable, and everyone in Australia will understand it. But, according to the opposition, the whole blockade is the Prime Minister's fault, this government's fault. What absolute nonsense. For them, it is all a conspiracy, it is all orchestrated from Canberra—all orchestrated for the federal elections, mind you. You cannot treat the intelligence of the Australian electorate with such utter and complete contempt and expect to get away with it. Not only does that pour scorn on the genuine grievances of ordinary Australians being industrially assaulted by the Court government—the same Australian battlers, I might say, whom the opposition leader said on the Howard Sattler program this morning should be sued for damages—it ignores the real culpability in all this.

From our government's point of view, we are opposed to the Court government's legislation and we know that all fair-minded Australians are. But we have no influence with that government. There is no way in the world we could persuade them to drop this legislation—the legislation that is jeopardising industrial peace in this country.

The Leader of the Opposition could. He could use his influence. He has already used his influence in Western Australia—successfully, I might say, in the setting up of the farcical Marks royal commission. He has plenty of influence when he wants to use it, but he has not sought to here.

Instead, the Leader of the Opposition has been urging the WA government to go about this business. He is saying that quietly, but really he has been giving them a big rap in their pursuit of it. He has said that it is his model. He has supported the principles even when people like Judith Sloan—Judith Sloan of all people—have been calling for the second wave to be abandoned. Having Judith Sloan dump on you is like a conservative IR minister being dumped on by their own mother, but that is what has happened with this Kierath legislation. Instead of standing up and saying that the WA government should back away, the Leader of the Opposition has given them backbone and given them succour. Of course, he is doing so because Graham Kierath is doing his work—he is implementing his model.

How does that sit with the assurances given to ACOSS and the battlers? Of course, it does not. The Leader of the Opposition says to any audience who will listen to him that he does not want to threaten them in any way, shape or form. But the reality is that the plans have not changed; the plans are just hidden until after the next election. In the IR plan it is Jobsback, it is wage slashing, it is abolishing awards and it is encouraging industrial confrontation—pure and simple. In Western Australia we see his bona fides out in the open. He is for the second wave and he is for all the industrial conflict that is promoted. No amount of obfuscation and no amount of apportioning blame to us can hide those who are responsible for this blockade—that is, Richard Court egged on by John Howard.

Without that legislation there would be none of this conflict; yet it is the same Richard Court who had the temerity to say before the election that he was no Jeff Kennett. Perhaps not. I reckon he is probably worse. Now the opposition leader is trying to say that he is no Jeff Kennett and he is no Richard Court, but of course his actions say another thing. All his statements over two decades say just one thing: he is anti-worker. The opposition leader can say that he is no Jeff Kennett or no Richard Court, but he cannot say that he is no John Howard, because he is John Howard—the John Howard who supported the second wave, who supports industrial conflict and who supports Graham Kierath. By doing so, it is the opposition, not our government, which has a lot to answer for as far as this blockade is concerned.

Mr Deputy Speaker, if the opposition got into power, you can be sure that blockades would not be restricted to Western Australia; they would be national. Just as Western Australian legislation is the foretaste to their approach on IR, the blockade is the foretaste of the consequences of their IR policy. For Australia's sake, let us hope that, nationally, they never get the chance to implement that terrible policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moylan Mrs J.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia has a declining share of world trade, it has a foreign debt of $180 billion and it has nearly 800,000 Australians still out of work, 30 per cent of whom are the youth and the cream of this country. Today's union blockade is an absolute disgrace and the support of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and his senior ministers is a disgraceful performance that will go down as one of the black days in Australia's history. All Western Australians, in fact all Australians, ought to be deeply concerned about what has taken place today.

PARA.TAB: The issues driving this blockade deserve very close scrutiny by workers because their interests are not being served by the union elite who purport to protect their interests. The Prime Minister's interference is not warranted and not wanted in Western Australia. He would do much better and serve his party's interest if he stayed out of this. That is clearly the case when you consider that the Western Australian Liberal-National party coalition put out a clear policy direction as they went to the last election. It was available for everyone to see and the Western Australian public gave them a mandate to implement that legislation on industrial relations.

The union elite, serving their own interests and those of a self-serving Prime Minister and senior ministers, are intent on winning the next federal election, regardless of the cost and the pain inflicted on this nation's citizens. Their highest priority today is to maximise the disruption. There is a legitimate role for employee representation in this country. But, with an alarming decline in union membership, despite being protected by legislation in some areas, union officials need reminding of their obligations to union members.

They received this reminder today. I received news that 400 people—400 people—were reported by the ABC as having attended this morning's rally for a major blockade of the whole state. The state has 1 1/2 million people. That was the ABC's estimate. The police estimated there were 200 people at this morning's rally. This afternoon at 2 o'clock there was a second rally, and they could not even muster 100 people. Those 100 people were probably made up of Carmen Lawrence's staff, along with the staff members of other Labor Party offices in Western Australia. So the workers in Western Australia have voted clearly with their feet and stayed away in droves.

The attendance of the titular head of the ACTU and its and the Labor Party's media personality, Jennie George, was not even a lure to get the public along to the two Perth rallies. And make no mistake about it: the boys still drive the bus. Jennie has been put there at the head, and we were all hopeful that we might see a change in industrial relations legislation and direction in this country. But, no, Kelty is still there and he is driving the bus. She was hurried over there and they were not able to get any kind of attendance up at all.

The Australian public is not as gullible as the Prime Minister and some of the union elite would like to think. There have been statements on record from union officials signalling their intent to undermine the coalition as part of a blatant political exercise as we move towards the next election. Tony Cooke, the secretary of the WA union, said, `What we've got to do is to inflict harm on the economy of the state.' That was a clear agenda of the secretary. In a very fiery speech on the final day of the ACTU Congress in Melbourne, Mr Kelty, who is still driving the bus, declared that the unions were `drawing a line in the sand' in the battle against the coalition in the lead-up to the next federal election.

Workers understand that this blockade today has nothing to do with the rights of workers; it has everything to do with the panic-stricken Prime Minister and his ministers putting their privileged positions ahead of the interests of Australian people. This is best summarised by comments in the Australian by economics editor Alan Wood in relation to the reasons why the bill is upsetting the unions. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: But what an inspection of their list of objections does show is they have a lot to do with union power and privilege and precious little to do with workers' pay and conditions. This is what the blockade is really all about, and so is much of Labor's industrial relations policy.

It is not about looking after the pay and the conditions of workers; it is about protecting the union elite. These are the people who have taken over. The extent to which the Prime Minister is seeking to deflect attention away from any analysis of his disastrous handling of the Australian economy is encapsulated in his support for today's blockade. On 11 October it was reported in the West Australian that he `backed next week's planned statewide strike and blockade of WA business'.

PARA.TAB: While the Prime Minister could not wait to have his say and attempt to whip people into a frenzy in WA with his tacit, if not blatant, support for this action, he is now denying any involvement. But I can tell you that the WA Labor Party leader, Jim McGinty, had no difficulty in fully understanding what the Prime Minister was saying. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Keating is entitled to his point of view, but I disagree with it and . . . I don't agree that inflicting economic pain on WA is the way to go.
There was no equivocating by the Prime Minister's senior ministers. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton), who was just standing here a minute ago and has now deserted the House, said:
Before we were apprised of what the union had in mind for a blockade at the national level, I had some reservations. But I can say I have none today.

He supports it totally: it is all right to hold the state to ransom. The Deputy Prime Minister and Western Australian member for Swan, Mr Beazley, was quoted as saying that he was `backing WA unionists' and `that the blockade had national support'. So he, too—Western Australia's own minister—was happy to go along with this. It appears that the Deputy Prime Minister, Kim Beazley, does not share the state Labor leader's view about inflicting economic pain on Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: Let us take a look at what WA's union blockade will do to WA today. It will affect 75,000 small business people. Despite the government's rhetoric, these are just hardworking men and women who are prepared to take risks and prepared to employ other Australians. The blockade will result in a loss of export income of approximately $50 million to $60 million at a time when Australia can least afford it. It will result in 1.5 million Western Australians suffering hardship and inconvenience. It will also result in small retailers bearing the brunt of union leaders and the Prime Minister's selfish actions.

Tony Cooke, the Western Australian Trades and Labour Council secretary, said, `What we've got to do is inflict harm on the economy of that state.' That is their agenda. It is not to look after the workers; it is not to give them better pay and conditions. This is a blatant political exercise to disrupt my state and inflict maximum economic harm on it. The Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia has also condemned the Prime Minister's support for the blockade against an elected government and has stated that the stance taken by Keating and Beazley was outrageous. I would support that statement.

The government has quite correctly sought to introduce accountability and transparency into many areas of this economy, but it has not had the spine to insist on the same rules of accountability and transparency in the union movement. That is what this bill is largely about. It is about giving people choices; it is about democracy; it is about transparency; and it is about accountability. What is so bad about it is the fact that the union elite do not want to be accountable. They do not want things to be transparent within the movement. It does not suit their purposes.

As I have said, employee representatives do have a legitimate role in the future of Australia, but there is no room for divisive and confrontationist activities that impact on the viability and the profitability of business and those responsible for providing the livelihood to millions of Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to see that the subject matter of today's matter of public importance is Western Australia and industrial relations. I am very pleased that those opposite have raised this matter. The previous speaker, the member for Pearce (Mrs Moylan), and the gaggle of Western Australian opposition members behind her have just handcuffed themselves to what we know the opposition is all about: reducing wages, taking away safety nets, taking away conditions and reducing the living standards of workers in Western Australia and generally.

PARA.TAB: I was very pleased when a couple of weeks ago the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton), who spoke earlier, visited Gonninan's, a factory in my electorate which has received a major contract from the National Rail Corporation for the construction of locos. The minister was asked in Western Australia about today's industrial action, and I was very pleased to be standing beside him when he answered the question. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Working men and women are entitled to any legitimate avenue of protest, provided it is lawful. And I would urge those who are to be involved in this to ensure that all of their actions are lawful. But as far as a . . . a right to protest is concerned, I've always supported it. And people have that right under the Industrial Relations Reform Act . . .
That is, the Commonwealth act. He continued:
It's the sort of right that Graham Kierath, of course, in the West Australian second wave, would rip away from workers.

I absolutely endorse those remarks. Why is there this day of action in Western Australia today? It is a direct result of the legislation and policies of the Court state Liberal government to which the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has handcuffed himself, as have all those opposition members from Western Australia who are present. Why is the Leader of the Opposition so sensitive and so interested in this issue? Because he has handcuffed himself to those policies of the Court Liberal government.

PARA.TAB: When you talk about industrial relations and people's living standards, there is no doubt that Court industrial relations equals Howard industrial relations. We know that is absolutely the case. The West Australian, in an article headed `Howard: WA is our model', reported on the Leader of the Opposition's address to the state Liberal Party conference on 29 July which, as the minister pointed out, is some couple of months after the second wave legislation proposals were released by Minister Kierath. The article in the West Australian of that date reads:

SPEECH.PARA: A federal coalition government would mirror the industrial relations policies implemented by the Court Government in Western Australia, Federal Opposition Leader John Howard said yesterday.

PARA.TAB: "I would like to see throughout Australia an industrial relations system that is largely similar to what the coalition Government has implemented in Western Australia," he said.

SPEECH.PARA: In the same article, Premier Richard Court is quoted as saying:

PARA.TAB: We are pleased that the Federal (coalition's) industrial relations policy will be modelled on what we have successfully implemented here.

SPEECH.PARA: I noticed that subsequently the Leader of the Opposition tried to remove himself from this particular handcuff, but Mr Kierath sprung him. After the Leader of the Opposition understood the full ramifications of what he was saying—that is, when it became clear that industrial relations was to John Howard what the GST was to Dr Hewson—he tried to remove himself and create a bit of space for himself. But Mr Kierath sprung him. An article in the West Australian dated 25 August, headed `Kierath denies rift with Federal body', reads:
Labour Relations Minister Graham Kierath denied yesterday the Federal coalition was distancing itself from his controversial second wave of industrial reforms.

PARA.TAB: Mr Kierath told The West Australian 10 days ago that Mr Howard supported the major elements of his proposed second wave after he explained them to him when he was in Perth last month.
"He (Howard) said what constitutes the second wave . . . are things the coalition feel very strongly about and agree with wholeheartedly," Mr Kierath said then.
He also said Mr Howard was happy with his reasons for going ahead with the two proposals criticised by the WA Chamber of Commerce and Industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Kierath has sprung him and clinched the handcuff back on. So what is today all about? Today is about John Howard saying to the Australian community, `What is happening in Western Australia through Court and Kierath's legislation is what I would do in Australia writ large.' In other words, he would take away the safety nets, crush allowances, crush award conditions and reduce living standards. These are all the things which John Howard stands for. The fact that Kierath has clinched the handcuff back on is repeated in an article in the Sunday Times of 20 August, in which Mr Kierath is reported as saying:
The only discussion I've had is with John Howard . . . and he seemed very supportive of the principles.

So what are these principles, policies and legislation to which John Howard is so attached. What is the first wave and the second wave all about? In general terms, they are about safety nets going, minimum standards going or being pushed down, penalty rates going, overtime allowances going and meal breaks going. This is the same old industrial relations and living standards legislation, philosophy and principle that we have seen from the Liberals all our lives. It is the same approach that we saw from Sir Charles Court in 1974 when there was a day of action in Western Australia in opposition to his emergency services legislation. It has been carried on, like father like son, and it has been carried on by John Howard. What you see with Richard Court and Graham Kierath today is what you saw over 20 years ago with Sir Charles Court, and it is what you will see with John Howard if we ever have the misfortune of him being elected as Prime Minister of this country.

PARA.TAB: The Howard model is quite simple. It is all about lower wages; it is about worse conditions; it is about a massive rise in industrial disputation; it is about the abolition of safety nets; and it is about pushing down or abolishing minimum standards. As a worker, you may have lots of doubts about the things that you might lose, but you can be absolutely sure of one thing: John Howard will reduce your living standards. At the same time, as if pushing down wages, allowances and conditions was not enough, the cat has been let out of the bag. An article in the Australian Financial Review today is headed `Coalition springs GST surprise'. They might say they are not going to introduce it, but you know that in their heart of hearts they really want to. You might have doubts about whether they will or they will not, but you know that in their heart of hearts that is what they want to do. So they will whack you with that too!

The Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), the man responsible for the development of taxation policy, has let the cat out of the bag. On the one hand, we have Howard handcuffing himself to Graham Kierath and Court. On the other hand, we have the development of taxation policy going back to the old Fightback proposal, a GST. These are the things that we know they in their heart of hearts are absolutely committed to and would do.

Let us get an indication as to what some people in Western Australia have had to say about the industrial relations legislation of Mr Kierath and Mr Court. An article in the West Australian of 21 June, under the heading `Kierath plans flawed', says:

SPEECH.PARA: Major aspects of the Court Government's proposed second wave of industrial relations are provocative and unworkable, according to the WA Chamber of Commerce and Industry.

PARA.TAB: Labour Relations Minister Graham Kierath's plans would bring the community pain in exchange for marginal benefits, chamber labour relations director Brendan McCarthy said yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: A quote from Mr McCarthy reads:

PARA.TAB: Why legislate knowing something is not going to work? Because it is unworkable and because it is impractical, it would be bad legislation and we are opposed to that.

SPEECH.PARA: An editorial in the West Australian on the following day, on 22 June, says:
It should be a clear signal to him—
that is, Kierath—
to think again for the sake of industrial stability when both the WA Chamber of Commerce and Industry and the Trades and Labour Council denounce his legislative proposals as unworkable.

PARA.TAB: But Kierath has shown a hidebound resistance to calls for change to controversial parts of his so-called second wave of industrial legislation, despite the blunt rejection of them by the most effective parties.

SPEECH.PARA: The editorial goes on to say:
The community will not support laws that are unfairly one-sided in their application—or appear to be based on vindictiveness rather than need—regardless of whether unions strike over them.

How prescient that comment from the West Australian on 22 June was. Some six weeks before, John Howard stood up at the Liberal Party conference in late July and said, `What you're doing here, what you're proposing here, I wholeheartedly agree with and I would do nationally.' I repeat:
The community will not support laws that are unfairly one-sided in their application—or appear to be based on vindictiveness rather than need—regardless of whether unions strike over them.

How prescient was that editorial from the west. We find further examples from Western Australia in August in the West Australian under the heading `Bosses question industry reforms'. This is the Chamber of Commerce questioning Kierath's reforms. But we find the quote of all quotes coming from Kierath himself on ABC TV Lateline on 23 August 1995. Talking about the system he has implemented and is proposing, he states:
It's really empowered the people at the workplace to make arrangements on wages and conditions that suit them . . .
He goes on to say:

And we did that quite deliberately, we thought that there would be some areas of the labour market that were over-priced and needed to be re-adjusted, what we would call low-skilled, low paid starter jobs.

So there is Kierath, bold as brass on ABC TV, stating a deliberate strategy to reduce the wages of low skilled, low paid jobs. That is what John Howard has handcuffed himself to. That is what he would do if he ever became Prime Minister. (Time expired)
