TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Crimes Amendment (Forensic Procedures) Bill 1995 be omitted and that the second reading be postponed until the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee has reported to the Senate on the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I move this way because, notwithstanding the efforts of the shadow Attorney, Senator Vanstone, to have this matter by agreement deferred, the government has declined to follow that course. On 12 October, which is last week, the shadow Attorney wrote to the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) indicating that she was concerned about the timing for the second reading debate on the Crimes Amendment (Forensic Procedures) Bill and noting that the bill was to be debated in the House of Representatives this week. She went on to say:

You will be aware that the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee has been conducting an inquiry in relation to the bill. It is due to report to the Senate on 18 October. I understand from conversations between my office and yours that your intention is to seek the passage of the bill in its current form, with some limited amendments foreshadowed in committee hearings, but will consider any committee recommendations in the context of the bill's passage through the Senate.
She went on to say:

I must say I have considerable concerns with this course, given the importance of the bill both in the federal context and its role as a model for state and territory legislation. It deserves, as does any piece of legislation, proper consideration by both houses.
She further went on to say:

Numerous and detailed concerns that have been raised in relation to the bill warrant proper consideration by both houses. By increasingly treating the lower house as nothing more than a rubber stamp for initial drafts of legislation, you acknowledge as impotent the House of which you are a member and fundamentally undermine the importance of our bicameral system. Given that the committee's inquiry has occurred prior to debate in the House of Representatives, I believe you should respond to any committee recommendations prior to the passage of the bill through either house. I believe the debate should be deferred. However, should you intend to proceed with the bill, I request your assurance that you will not debate it until at least the day following the tabling of the Senate committee's report.
I have a copy of the minister's reply and will read the relevant section. He said:
It is my intention to proceed in the House of Representatives with the bill in its current form, including the foreshadowed amendments, but debate will be after the Senate committee reports.
He went on to say:

I can assure you I have no intention of treating the House as a rubber stamp in the passage of the legislation. As a minister in the House, I naturally reject any proposition that would make the process of the House subject to those of the Senate. If there are any recommendations in the Senate committee's report which are acceptable to the government, then this can be dealt with in the Senate. The bill will of course need to come back to the House of Representatives. I believe this is fully consistent with the importance of our bicameral system of government.

As I understand it, the Senate committee will not be reporting until 26 October. Clearly, the date for discussion of this matter will be for the tabling of the report and will be after the debate has concluded in the committee, if we follow the course recommended here.

PARA.TAB: The Senate committee has not reported. It will not report until 26 October. The date has been extended for the tabling of that report—and 26 October is the date. If the matter is to be debated on Thursday, as the government proposes, it will be debated before the parliament has had the benefit of the knowledge of the Senate's concerns in relation to a number of matters. They are important matters. Let me just give some indication of some of those matters.

As I understand it, the committee has had raised with it questions relating to the carrying out of forensic procedures before a person has been arrested. This gives the police powers, contrary to the Australian Law Reform Commission, the Gibbs committee and the Coldrey committee recommendations. While the government seeks to justify that provision, the fact is that it is contrary to the recommendation of each of those bodies. The bill authorises a constable to order non-intimate forensic procedures if a suspect does not consent—and, again, this extension of police powers is contrary to the Law Reform Commission, the Gibbs committee and the Coldrey committee recommendations.

There have been other suggestions made that the operation of the bill should be subjected to a regular system of audit. It has been argued that the bill should include offences for exercising or threatening to exercise powers contained in the bill without following proper procedures.

It is also of concern that the bill allows for the taking of swabs, or photographs of breasts. It has been argued that it is difficult to imagine an offence for which forensic evidence obtained by such means would be necessary. It has been suggested that the bill is likely to disadvantage those in the outback areas.

These are all matters that have been raised before the Senate committee and upon which it has been asked to deliberate and report, yet we are being asked to consider this legislation when we know that it will not be tabled in the Senate for another week. In those circumstances, the only proper course to follow is to carry this motion I have moved today; that is, to omit this bill from the reference to the Main Committee and, in relation to this matter, to generally determine that the second reading be postponed until the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee has reported to the Senate on the bill.

I do not believe that is an unreasonable course. If the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mrs Crosio) has instructions to follow any other course in relation to this matter, that indicates that the Minister for Justice's assurance that he has no intention of treating the House as a rubber stamp or of making the processes of this House subject to those of the Senate was clearly a nonsense, that he did not mean what he said and that he has no regard for this chamber.

This is an occasion on which I am debating particularly this reference, but it is the case in relation to numbers of bills involving the Minister for Justice that opportunities for this House of parliament to be involved in considering the detailed provisions of legislation have been, under his stewardship, specifically avoided. He has always taken the view that any reference to our committee on legal and constitutional affairs ought not to be entertained when the Senate committees are deliberating on these matters. He seems to take the view that the Senate committee is appropriate and that there ought to be only one inquiry by one committee, but he now seems to take the view as well that this chamber should have no knowledge of and no ability to consider the detailed recommendations of Senate committees in relation to bills we are considering. It makes a nonsense of the legislative process and this course being followed certainly devalues this chamber.

I notice that the parliamentary secretary has been fulminating about this matter. I am quite astonished that there would be any sensitivity about it. In fact, I would have hoped that the parliamentary secretary would have been endeavouring to reach the minister, who is not here to see his reference of the bill to the Main Committee. She seems to take the view that we ought to accept this as a fait accompli. I think it degrades the parliament. It degrades this chamber. It makes it a chamber of second order significance in the consideration of important legislation.

I have moved this motion and we will divide on this matter. We consider it to be of great significance, a matter which reflects the way this government sees important legislation of this sort. It sees it as being legislation that ought to be considered without details, without comments and without the opportunity to hear what others have had to say in relation to the provisions and without the benefit of that expert advice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams Mr D.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second and support the motion of the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock). I will approach the issue before the chair in two ways. In the first instance, I will take a benevolent view of what has occurred. The letter from the shadow Attorney-General, which was effectively read by the honourable member for Berowra, raises the question not so much of the consideration of the bill before the tabling of the Senate committee report as of whether this House should be debating the bill without knowing what amendments the government will seek in response to the Senate committee report itself.

PARA.TAB: At the time that letter was written, it was anticipated that the Senate committee would report tomorrow, 18 October. It was only known at that point that it was to be debated next week. In his reply, the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) said that it is his intention to proceed without any amendments that might arise out of the committee report, other than those foreshadowed during the committee hearing by government representatives. He did say that debate would be after the Senate committee report.

In that respect, what has happened up to this afternoon is consistent with the minister's undertaking. But this afternoon in the Senate the time for tabling of the report was extended by a week and a day—from Wednesday of this week to Thursday of next week. That means that if the minister is genuine in his intention that the debate be after the Senate committee reports, the debate in this House will not take place before 27 October. That is consistent with his expressed intention in the letter. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: It is my intention to proceed in the House of Representatives with the bill in its current form, including the foreshadowed amendments, but debate will be after the Senate committee reports.
On that basis, there is absolutely no reason for the minister to not, consistent with his undertaking expressed in writing, now extend the time for debate of the bill in this House.

PARA.TAB: If one takes a less benevolent view—there are some reasons one might take such a view—the actions of the minister in refusing to allow the bill to be debated until after the Senate committee reports are in effect making this House a mere rubber stamp. It is not enabling this House to debate the government proposals.

The history is that this bill is a highly contentious bill. It has been prepared as a model for state and territory governments to adopt. As a model, it will introduce dramatic new powers for police and authorities exercising police powers which are of an intensely personal and intimate nature. Those powers may be exercised not only against people who have been convicted, not only against people who have been charged, not only against people who are believed to have committed offences but also against persons who are merely suspected of having committed an offence.

These are very draconian powers. They may be appropriate if correctly examined, but we do not know what the Senate committee will determine in its examination. It has conducted an examination which the House of Representatives Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee offered to undertake. The minister declined to allow that to occur.

The benevolent view—that the minister was really concerned to allow debate in this House to take place after the Senate committee report has seen the light of day—is open to some suspicion. The suggestion really ought to be that the minister wants to have this bill rushed through this House and dealt with in the Senate at a time which would enable the Senate amendments to be dealt with without any consideration in this House.

He is taking the debate in this House for granted. The fact that it has been referred to the main committee which was set up originally largely to deal with non-contentious bills also raises a query because it must have been known to the minister right from when this bill saw the light of day as an exposure draft that it would be contentious when it came to be debated. It must have been known to him at all times that it would be the subject of intense scrutiny and would be likely to be the subject of extensive debate.

I think the minister is in breach of his undertaking if he does not allow the debate in this House to be postponed until the Senate committee report is available. In failing to postpone the debate, the minister is really revealing that his intention never was to allow the Senate committee report to be properly considered in this House. Without that report, the debate will have to proceed on the strength of what is known as a result of the public inquiry, but it will not have the benefit of a careful consideration by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee of the important provisions of the bill.

The minister is treating the House as a rubber stamp—something he denies in his letter. Although he asserts that he naturally rejects any proposition that would make the processes of the House subject to those of the Senate, by his very actions he is making that happen. He has already made the actions of the House committee subject to the actions of the Senate committee—something for which, as the member for Berowra has said, the minister should stand condemned.

This bill is not party political. It has not raised any issue that is going to determine who is going to win the next election. None of those likely to contribute to the debate, previously, were likely to raise any issue relevant to the politics between the major parties in this House. But an issue is now raised that demonstrates the arrogance and contempt with which the government treats the House. It treats it as a mere numbers exercise to bring legislation into this House. It does not wish to see any legislation properly considered in this House. The government does not wish to see any legislation brought before a committee of this House for proper consideration.

It is treating the House as a rubber stamp. I believe this House will rue the day when it ceases to exercise the proper function of considering and debating legislation. I support the amendment which would see this bill not referred to the main committee until the Senate committee has reported.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs CROSIO
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —We oppose the amendments that have just been moved by the member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock). We oppose them for a number of reasons. From a procedural point of view, it should go down in Hansard exactly what has been moved and the hypocrisy of the particular motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who did you check it with? You saw me speaking to the opposition leader of business here in the House before I spoke.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Rocher)—Order! The honourable member for Berowra will cease interjecting.

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Berowra got up here stating the reasons why and reading out in full the letter from the shadow Attorney-General. I again question the motives of the member for Tangney. Do the member for Berowra and the member for Tangney have a certain agenda that the opposition has not got; and if they have do opposition members not all agree to it; or do they have a certain agenda they wish to carry without really coming forward with the true reasons?

After the consultation that has taken place, I can only assume that not only are we, the government, always being confounded at no policy coming from the opposition but also what we seem to have here today is conflict in the opposition—conflict about procedures of debate in the House. Obviously there must be.

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely nonsense.

—The member for Berowra may say it is nonsense. I repeat: agreements were reached. Procedures were put together and the daily program was printed. Consultation took place and this was agreed to. Again, as I said, even after the member for Berowra had finished speaking and the member for Tangney was on his feet, I requested that information—go back to check with the whips office as to whether this procedure was what they required. They said no, it was not what they required.

PARA.TAB: Both the opposition whip and the government whip, as I have now been informed, and I repeat, at 5.18 p.m.—this was after the member for Berowra had finished stating the reasons why he wanted this deferred and the member for Tangney was on his feet—repeated that the procedures which I had just implemented on behalf of the Leader of the House were what they wanted to proceed with. TALK.START.PARA: —Not checked.

Both members, in speaking on this motion today as to the reasons why they wanted to have this particular bill omitted from the program, fully understand the procedures that go on in the main committee. PARA.TAB: The reasons for this action will gradually come to light, I feel sure, particularly when the whips consult again. The government certainly opposes the motion. It opposes the way it has been introduced. Certainly, in this House the government would never have a precedent set into place where we have to be dictated to by the Senate as to whether or not we have a second reading speech on a bill that has been already placed before this House. TALKER.NAME: Mr LINDSAY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Excise Tariff Proposal No. 4 (1995); and
Customs Tariff Proposal No. 8 (1995).

SPEECH.PARA: The tariff proposals which I have just tabled contain alterations to the Excise Tariff Act 1921 and the Customs Tariff Act 1987. Excise tariff proposal No. 4 (1995) and customs tariff proposal No. 8 (1995) formally place before the parliament, as required by law, tariff alterations made by notice published in Special Commonwealth Gazette s386 of 10 October 1995 during the recent recess of parliament. The changes are operative from 11 October 1995.

PARA.TAB: Excise tariff proposal No. 4 is consequent on measures in excise tariff proposal No. 3, which I introduced into the House on 29 June 1995. As foreshadowed by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) in the budget on 9 May 1995, excise proposal No. 3 amended the definition of fuel oil in order to exclude so-called light fuel oils from that definition. Fuel oils not meeting the definition are now dutiable at the rate of excise applying to diesel fuel.

Topped crude petroleum oils for use otherwise than as refinery feedstock can be used as substitutes for fuel oils, but some topped crudes can also be used, and are being used, as substitutes for diesel. Excise tariff proposal No. 4 provides that the fuel oil rate of excise duty only applies to non-refinery topped crudes, meeting the requirements of the definition of fuel oil detailed in subsection 3(4) of the Excise Tariff Act 1921. Other non-refinery feedstock topped crudes will now be dutiable at the diesel fuel rate.

Customs tariff proposal No. 8 introduces similar alterations to the Customs Tariff Act 1987. Excise tariff proposal No. 4 also provides exempt status for all condensate which is produced separately or marketed separately from stabilised crude petroleum oil, other than condensate intended for use as a fuel. Condensate which is produced and marketed as part of a crude oil stream will continue to be regarded as crude oil and remain subject to the crude oil excise arrangements. This amendment removes an unintended consequence of the present legislation which could, in certain circumstances, require the payment of excise duty on condensate production that is intended to be excise exempt. A summary of the alterations contained in these proposals has been prepared and is being circulated for the information of honourable members. I commend the proposals to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Airports Bill and the Airports (Transitional) Bill revolve around the government's program of privatisation and assets sales. They are fundamental bills to that program, a program that the government has not been too successful with in recent times in the number of Commonwealth assets—taxpayer owned assets—that have been factored into budgets over the last couple of years and the subsequent sales prices that have been achieved. Let us hope for the sake of the people of Australia that the government ultimately achieves the budgeted prices for the sale of the Federal Airports Corporation and the airports that it is going to sell.

PARA.TAB: The government proposes initially to sell a number of airports, namely, Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth. The coalition has proposed an amendment which includes Adelaide in that sale, and there is also a rider attached to the sale of Sydney airport which includes KSA and Sydney West.

I have been involved in a number of inquiries in this place over the last two years which have revolved around the commercialisation of government business enterprises with a particular focus on the now defunct Civil Aviation Authority and the soon to be defunct, as a result of these bills, Federal Airports Corporation. In our report we came up with the recommendation that the Civil Aviation Authority of Australia as a commercialised entity should be split, that air safety control should be brought back under the department and that the air traffic section should remain a commercial entity. Ultimately, the government, after much prompting from a number of different areas, including the opposition, took that course of action and established Airservices Australia.

During the inquiry we also had the opportunity to discuss at length with the Federal Airports Corporation the ultimate proposition of the government which is embodied in these bills—that is, the privatisation of the Federal Airports Corporation or the privatisation of the government owned or taxpayer owned airports in Australia. It was indicated at that stage that, of the 22 airports owned by the taxpayers of Australia, only six or seven were actually profitable. The alarm bells should be ringing a little bit here: it is obvious that the first tranche of this sale is going to encompass the profitable airports.

The question should be asked: what is going to happen when we get to the stage when the first tranche has been sold and we are down to selling the rest of the airports, a lot of which are not profitable and are subsidised from the more profitable airports? The indication that was given by the Federal Airports Corporation at the time was that the whole outfit should be sold lock, stock and barrel so that it could remain providing the services as they stand today to the travelling public across Australia and at reasonably acceptable market prices because of that cross-subsidisation from one airport to another.

We know that that element of the operation of the FAC has been attacked from a number of different areas. The Prices Surveillance Authority conducted an inquiry back in I think 1993 which recommended that the Federal Airports Corporation should not cross-subsidise the aeronautical side of its operations with the profits being made by its commercial activities in leasing out space in terminals to commercial operators. This created a fair amount of concern in regional Australia. It meant that the cost to the travelling public who fly from regional Australia into some of the major airports would have increased to such an extent that it may have made those regional airlines unviable. That has been highlighted in a government discussion paper entitled `Pricing arrangements in the pre-lease period' where those options are certainly discussed—not just cross-subsidisation within airports like KSA but also cross-subsidisation from the more profitable airports to the non-profitable airports.

In the whole privatisation debate in the public policy area, we should be drawing as much as we possibly can from the experiences of the United Kingdom where the current government and the previous government, the Thatcher government, went hell for leather privatising a number of government owned monopolies without any due concern or diligence being shown towards the establishment of suitable regulation over those authorities. That is what we believe is missing from these bills. In the haste—and I emphasise `haste'—of the assets sales program, we do not believe there has been enough regard to regulation. It is too late after it has been sold. It is too late when the citizens of Australia are not receiving the services that they are used to at a reasonable price. It is too late when the government has sold off a profitable monopoly to the private sector without reasonable regulations in place over and above those assets.

It is with a great deal of caution that the coalition is participating in this debate. The government should realise that they will only get one lick of the lolly out of this. If you own an asset that is producing a profit year in and year out, you can budget for that each year. But you can only sell it once. Once the money you have received from the sale has been spent, there is no more income. There is no year-in, year-out income as there is at the moment. The government would be well advised to move very cautiously with this project.

As I have said, the purpose of these two bills is to get into a position with the Federal Airports Corporation for the sale of the airports we have mentioned. The coalition is proposing to move amendments that seek to include the Adelaide airport in the first tranche of the sale process, along with Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth airports. The coalition is also proposing to move an amendment to defer the privatisation of Kingsford Smith airport by excising it from the relevant parts of the legislation until satisfactory arrangements are in place to more equitably share the aircraft noise burden over Sydney, particularly through the resumption of full operation of the east-west runway.

So there are two elements to the amendment proposed by the opposition. It should not come as a surprise to the government. This is an issue that has been flagged over the last month with the very intense and emotional debate in Sydney over the burden of aircraft noise above a number of its suburbs. Blind Freddy can see that aircraft approaching KSA are now being funnelled down the north-south access, making a very distinct political point.

It is a very cynical exercise being undertaken by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton). I do not know what it takes to get a message across to someone but the Minister for Transport still has not got it. He has to drive around Sydney in a car with darkened windows so people cannot see him and have bodyguards with him, such is the emotion and anger of so many residents in many suburbs—not just the suburbs north of the harbour that the government likes to allude to when we participate in these debates, but also many inner city suburbs, suburbs represented by members of the government. The Minister for Transport is not taking any notice of the concerns being expressed by those people.

As was proposed by the private member's bill recently, the aircraft noise issue must be resolved before the Commonwealth signs on the sale of these airports—before these two bills pass through this House and the Senate to become law. That issue must be addressed now because it cannot be addressed afterwards. Once the government sells these assets, if there is no proper regulation in place beforehand, they forfeit the right to do anything about the very serious problem in Sydney.

It is this government's responsibility. They closed down the east-west runway. This government made the decision to spend somewhere in the vicinity of $250 million on what is now the second runway but is loosely called the third runway—the parallel runway in Sydney—then closed down the east-west runway. We still have not seen the new control tower operating. We still have not seen the new radar system in operation. The net result of all that, after how many years, is fewer aircraft movements per hour. The major international airport in this nation—the gateway into this country—is less efficient than it was before any of that action was taken by the government. It is just outrageous.

We have government members coming in, defending the position taken by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport. We have poured hundreds of millions of taxpayers' dollars into this exercise. But every time we travel in and out of KSA, there it is unmanned. I heard that, on Australia Day this year, the Minister for Transport told Bill Swingler, a then executive officer of the FAC, and Buck Brooksbank, the acting CEO of the CAA, that they were not to do anything about opening that control tower until he, the minister, told them to act. That is the situation we are in with this government and they should stand condemned for it.

We are flagging to the people of Australia that there is an alternative course of action to the one the government has taken with respect to our No. 1 international airport—the No. 1 entry point into this nation for overseas travellers. There are also the disturbances to domestic travellers and disturbances to the people who live in the suburbs under the flight paths around KSA.

As I have already said, the opposition proposes to move amendments to these bills. We should flag at this point that the coalition is not opposed to the privatisation of the FAC and these airports as long as that is done in a proper and orderly manner and the government has regulations in place before they head down that path. I note from the explanation that goes along with these bills that there is a section that talks about regulation under the Airports Bill. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Airports Bill 1995 sets up a system for regulating airports currently owned and operated by the FAC on behalf of the Commonwealth and Sydney West Airport following their leasing. These regulations include:
.operations covering pricing and service levels—
That is very important but do they go far enough? We do not believe so. It goes on:
.limits on ownership and controls—

That is fine. That was flagged by the shadow minister, the member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop), in her address earlier today. We can put a 49 per cent foreign ownership cap on this but are the mechanisms there to ensure that does not zoom past 49 per cent with the initial float, requiring later redress, as we saw with the Qantas float?

PARA.TAB: It goes on to talk about `slot allocation'. Those are dirty words to commuters, particularly with regional airlines, travelling in and out of Kingsford Smith airport in Sydney. If you are going to Sydney to do business, you buy your ticket and budget your day, thinking you will arrive at such and such a time, giving you enough time to transfer onto another flight. But that never happens because of slot allocation, particularly with regional airlines. My greatest concern in this whole exercise is that the regional airlines that service not only New South Wales but other parts of Australia will be squeezed out of the equation.

When the proposition came forward from the Prices Surveillance Authority that the FAC should not be cross-subsidising its aeronautical operations through its commercial activities, the FAC said, `We will have to increase our leading charges in shoulder periods per landing.' That was going to add somewhere in the vicinity of $1 million in costs for outfits like Hazelton airlines, which services a lot of regional ports in New South Wales. It would almost put them out of business because it comes out of the profit they make.

The travelling public cannot afford to bear that sort of burden. That is the sort of effect that I am afraid of with this whole process if the government is not very diligent with respect to the regulations they need to put in on the operation of these airports before they embark on the leasing exercise. Once done, they are gone, and the government needs to have the regulation in place first.

Mr Deputy Speaker Fitzgibbon, I might be labouring long and hard the point about the impact on regional travellers and regional airlines, particularly in New South Wales, but that is the part of New South Wales that I represent, just as you do. You should also be concerned about what may happen to the regional airlines that operate out of ports in my electorate as well as in yours.
Earlier I mentioned a government discussion paper that was released on pricing arrangements in the pre-lease period. There are a couple of sections in the paper which I am concerned about. I quote:

The move towards more economically efficient pricing principles will lead to changes to the structure of prices at some airports. While it is not possible to be definitive about the level of likely price changes in the absence of detailed and disaggregated cost projections, there is likely to be price adjustments required at the smaller regional and general aviation airports, with resulting regional and local impacts. Changes may also result at some of the larger airports.

SPEECH.PARA: The paper went on to say:
Price changes would also be expected at the major airports over time as large infrastructure projects currently under construction are completed and incorporated into the airports' cost bases.
Under the heading `Options for implementing "efficient" prices', the paper stated:

PARA.TAB: In view of the likely need for price changes and the resulting regional and industry impacts, a full move to `efficient' pricing levels in the pre-lease period at all airports is not proposed. Instead, it is expected that there will be a graduated move towards efficient pricing levels in the pre-lease period, with the aim of moving aeronautical cost recovery to a pre-determined level prior to leasing.

SPEECH.PARA: It went on to say:

PARA.TAB: . . . while recognising that the likely price adjustments required impose additional costs on industry and regional communities which should be phased in over time. The approach is also consistent with ICAO guidelines and principles for the setting of aeronautical charges . . .

SPEECH.PARA: I say in response to that that everybody in this place knows full well that Australia is different from the majority of other nations. We are an enormous island continent with a small population in comparison with the size of the place. We have vast distances to travel. We talk about the tyranny of distance in Australia and we have to be prepared as a Commonwealth to implement strategies that can provide equitably priced services to the majority of people in Australia.

PARA.TAB: If that means a bit of cross-substitution between airports, if it means a bit of cross-substitution between activities at individual airports, then so be it. If we do not pursue policies like that in all sorts of public policy areas, we are all going to end up living on the eastern seaboard in Sydney, Newcastle, Wollongong and Brisbane because we will not be able to afford the services outside of those cities. That is something that I know a lot of government and opposition members are cognisant of.

In concluding my remarks on the bill, I urge the government to seriously consider the implication on regional people and on regional airlines and the costs. I urge the government to seriously consider the proposition that has been put forward and supported by a number of independent experts to reopen the east-west runway at Sydney's international airport—it has been supported by about six different independent experts—and run it safely. I urge the government to equitably distribute the noise pollution in Sydney. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile) has again addressed us with comments that show those opposite have one view in the morning and a different view in the afternoon. The reality is that the National Party and the Liberal Party have long advocated the selling off of our nation's airports—right back from the late 1970s and the early 1980s. If one looks back at what airport services were available then and what the situation facing regional airports was then, had that policy been implemented then, regional Australia would be in a much worse position today in respect of air services than it is as a result of the Federal Airports Corporation and as a result of government investment in those other airports through the Australian local ownership plan. You cannot have it both ways. You can't be a little bit pregnant: either you are or you aren't. If you want regional Australia to have access to better air services, I suggest that you look at revising your policy.

PARA.TAB: To come to the latest stump over Sydney airport: to be trying to tag on to that airport operations linked to the passage of this legislation is the height of irresponsibility. We have to remember that as far back as the 1970s the opposition were pushing for a third runway, particularly people from country Australia. There was a great campaign around New South Wales. All the mayors and shire presidents were running a campaign calling for a third runway. They all wanted the benefit of a third runway at somebody else's disturbance. It was the nimby syndrome—not in my backyard. They wanted the people of Sydney to put up with the noise so they could utilise the service when they felt like ducking down to Sydney. There is merit in both arguments. But taking one view only is not the way to resolve the problem.

Let me make it very clear: in my view, there is far too much glamour, far too much exaggeration and far too much importance attached to air travel as a form of transport. It is simply regular public transport. If it was regarded more often as being simply a form of public transport, we could sweep away some of the gold plating and concentrate more on ensuring that air travel as a major form of public transport was available to as many Australians as possible.

I hold the very firm view that all Australians ought to have access to that network and ought to have access to the opportunity to travel between Sydney and Melbourne or Brisbane, or whatever the major ports are, in an hour or an hour and a quarter, as do those who happen to live in those areas. Regional airports and regional travellers have to have access into the hubs—but if we just concentrated on ensuring the service was available as a form of public transport and not looking upon it as a milch cow.

Regrettably over the years what has happened is that here in this citadel of wisdom in Canberra many bureaucrats in Finance, Treasury and Prime Minister and Cabinet have seen airports and airline services and `cost recovery' in that area as milch cows rather than simply looking at it as a form of public transport. I sometimes feel sympathy for the people in the Department of Transport who have to be at the coalface and cop the flack, but there is no way in the world that those three bureaucratic departments would put forward the same proposals for the same level of cost recovery and revenue generation from surface passenger transport. The answer is very simple. They will not do so because the political backlash would be far too great; they could not withstand that. The old silvertail syndrome in Canberra has always applied to air travellers: `You wouldn't be flying unless you could afford to, so why shouldn't you pay it?' It ought to be seen as a form of public transport providing a reasonable return.

Far too little recognition is given to the importance of an airport. Airports—there is some disturbance factor and one has to manage that in the best interests of all concerned, particularly the residents in the area where the airport happens to be—are major economic generators. Taking the example of Sydney airport, and looking at the 1988-89 figures, Dr Paul Hooper from the Institute of Transport Studies at the University of Sydney is reported as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Sydney airport traffic generates 59,000 jobs in Sydney and the economic impact of the facility should be taken into account when airport policy is being debated. . .

He said that five per cent of jobs in New South Wales could be attributed to international visitors. In 1988-89, $5.4 billion in net income in that state came from visitors. Yet the airport is seen as a disability, as a weakness, rather than a strength. New South Wales as an economy, as a state, is extremely fortunate to have a traffic and an economic generator as it has in Mascot and being the prime port of entry for overseas visitors. Tourism is constantly referred to as the key. Airports are the key. The careers, the jobs, the revenues to governments—state, federal and local—and the revenue that goes to people who work in those operations and related activities depend on having access to an airport that is available and an airport that is recognised for its own importance.

PARA.TAB: I heard the honourable member say something about aeronautical versus non-aeronautical charges. I will say only a couple of words about that at the moment as I will come back to it in a few minutes. Those revenues—aeronautical revenue and non-aeronautical revenue—are inseparably linked. You can have aeronautical revenue with little non-aeronautical activity but you cannot have non-aeronautical activity or revenues of any substance without aeronautical services. The aeronautical services beget the non-aeronautical services. I will deal with that in a bit more detail as I go through it.

I want to refer to another matter. It would help governments of whatever colour at whatever level—and certainly the industry—a great deal if politicians and governments dealing with airport related activities and air transport related activities put realistic expectations upon what can happen and what ought to be happening.

Next time you go up to your electorate of Hunter, Mr Deputy Speaker, on a fine, clear day in the Hunter Valley, if you look up straight above you, way up into that dark, deep blue sky, you will see a big fleet of big aeroplanes circling round and round and looking for some bright, new airport at which to land. Everybody hopes that it will be their new airport, and when they build that airport and the aeroplanes come down then prosperity will change forever. That cargo cult exists in much of Australia and in the minds of politicians at all levels of government. If we want to get the right decisions, and the best for people who want to use air services, we must leave that big fleet of white planes circling in the sky up there, concentrate on the reality and have realistic expectations.

I was the person who put together the concept of the Federal Airports Corporation as the father of the Federal Airports Corporation. I was looking at other arrangements across the world in the late 1970s and I formed the concept of the Federal Airports Corporation in my mind. Originally it was going to be a national airports authority.
I think the Deputy Clerk is looking for that fleet of aeroplanes. You can see it through the skylight up there. She is looking; it is at about a 70-degree angle.

When I was putting the concept of the Federal Airports Corporation together, it was in recognition that at that time the governments of the day did not know what airport and aviation related services cost and it was impossible, from the information available, to directly relate expenditure to the earning of revenue.

The opposition wanted to sell the airports at that time. The value of departmental assets—they were all administered by the Department of Aviation at that time—was $661 million at the end of June 1982. Today the value of the 22 airports administered by the Federal Airports Corporation is just over $2 billion. Let us go back to those figures. The reason I put the proposal together was that we had no efficient way of knowing what the value of the assets was or of relating expenditure to revenue earnings. Despite the processes of the bureaucracy, it was extremely difficult to get government to spend money at the airports where it was needed. The main reason Canberra airport was not upgraded at the time was that Canberra was seen to be a public service town. It did not matter that it was one of the airports of growing importance. It was simply that Canberra was a public service town, and it was Canberra, and that was the last place you would spend any money.

There were massive sums of public funds involved. There was no proper measure of financial performance or efficiency of government airport operations. Because air navigation charges were levied on a route annual charge, revenue could not be related to specific airports. The airports themselves were not on a proper commercial accounting basis.

When we set up the FAC back in 1986, the first meeting of the board of the airports corporation was in the training room in the Department of Aviation in Sydney. The very first instruction concerned the fact that airports are like shopping centres. Airports are facilities through which people pass on the way to their destination. People do not visit the airport. People may see people off at the airport and meet people at the airport, but they do not visit the airport. They pass through the airport to get to where they want to get to. Airports are like shopping centres, and airports are places where people gather on a regular basis.

That first instruction I gave to the FAC was that we should look at every possible service that could be provided to those people visiting airports and passing through airports, and so add to revenue. It was recognised, with the 12 airports that we started, that some would have losses: we were a young country, we were a market that had to grow, and some airports would have difficulty in reaching the standard of others for quite some years to come. There was a clear strategy and a clear plan. We had to give the airports access to the capital they needed to upgrade. Sydney is a fine example. Then we had to see that the whole network operated together. The FAC network now has 22 airports and is one of the largest airport networks in the world.

I am proud of the FAC—its board, management and employees. I think they have served Australia well. They have given this country over the period from 1986 to 1995 a much better level and adequacy of airport services than would have been available by any other means. A lot of effort was put into that by those officers, and I want to put on the record here in this place my appreciation of that and my congratulations to them.

Now when we move on and look at the needs and the performance of airports, we see that overall in 1993-94 some 50 million passengers passed through the 22 airports under the FAC's control. Of those 50 million passengers, 38 1/2 million had a domestic origin and destination, 10.4 million were international passengers arriving and departing and 1.04 million were international passengers on on-carriage. How does that relate to the number of aircraft movements at airports and all the other activities? In 1993-94 there were 660,000 regular public transport movements—that is, by aircraft that are operated by airlines like Qantas, Ansett, Hazelton and the other major airlines. General aviation had 2.44 million aircraft movements. That is a total of 3.1 million aircraft movements overall. We will see when we look more closely at the figures later that the vast majority of passengers carried were RPT—regular public transport—activity. It is the minority of aircraft movements that carry the vast majority of aircraft passengers.
The total non-aeronautical revenue for that year was $279 million. The total aeronautical revenue was $178 million, with rounding, which gives a revenue total of $457 million for the FAC in 1993-94.

I referred earlier to non-aeronautical activity. You cannot have non-aeronautical services in an airport without an airport. It is ludicrous to suggest, as the Prices Surveillance Authority does in what I see as pure theoretical reasoning, that somehow non-aeronautical activity should be separate and not regarded as part of revenue earning by the airport and earnings from the industry. You just cannot do it. They are inseparably linked. You can put the shops and all of the other services out in the paddock and leave them there but unless there are aircraft landing at the airport no passengers are going to come, no visitors or meeters and greeters are going to visit, so the revenue is not going to be there.

It was the very clear intention at the time the FAC was set up that non-aeronautical revenue was a field that had not been exploited. There was a major source of revenue to be developed, and it has been developed. The FAC has been excellent at doing it. That revenue should go to supplement the other revenue earned from the actual air travel, as distinct from the land travel of the total journey.

Looking at all of the forecasts that are put to us about air transport and airline movements and the development of airports, I want to turn to the national planning transport task force report on adequacy of transport infrastructure at airports. That report was brought down at the end of last year. It said that aviation infrastructure investment of at least $2.8 billion is likely to be required between 1995-96 and 2014-15. More than two-thirds—67 per cent—of that total expenditure need will be on terminal expansion. Of the total terminal investment, 41 per cent will be required at Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport.

When one turns over to see what will happen to airports and their importance in the handling of passengers, we see that by 2014-15 Sydney will be the No. 1 airport, as forecast, Melbourne No. 2, Brisbane No. 3 and Cairns No. 4. If I turn back and look at the actual passenger movement, we see that in the Sydney basin, which by that time will be taking in Sydney West and Sydney, the number of passengers is expected to accelerate from 17.9 million in 1995-96 to 36.8 million in 2014-15—a 105 per cent increase. Cairns will go up by 209.6 per cent and Coolangatta by 155 per cent. Overall, the number of passengers handled—domestic, international and on-carriage—in Australia by 2014 will grow from 54,800,000 this year to 113 million by 2014-15. That is a 106 per cent increase. Similarly, when we look at air cargo—that is the other issue that is coming up increasingly—and its availability and the growth in it, we see that the figure of 789,000 tonnes for this year, 1995-96, is expected to grow by 73.3 per cent in 2014-15 to 1,368,500 tonnes.

When one looks at those figures, they put a little bit of soberness on some of the numbers we hear lauded about the place. In all of these things—I was saying this a few minutes ago—we need to have our feet firmly on the ground and deal with realistic estimates and realistic expectations and leave that great fleet of planes that the Deputy Clerk was watching circling way above us. It is probably about 150,000 feet up.

I have not gone into the provisions of the bill; they have been outlined by the minister. I have chosen instead to deal with issues arising from the bill and look at the current and future performance of the industry. The bill and the explanatory memorandum sets out the details of the changes and now the move from the Federal Airports Corporation of Australia to the individual divestment of airports with the conditions attaching to them that have been mentioned in the explanatory memorandum by the minister himself earlier today and by other speakers. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —One would be a lot more confident if the aviation transport policy of this country was still in the hands of the member for Shorthand (Mr Peter Morris). He has a capacity to draw the great themes and ideas of transport and put them into practical terms. Instead we are now dealing with legislation proposed by the current Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton). He as an individual and his manner of operating really does not create a sense of confidence either in the Australian electorate or in members of parliament.

PARA.TAB: The legislation that the House is dealing with sets out the proposal that the government lease the major airports around Australia. They will not be selling them, they will be leasing them, but retaining for the Commonwealth some major areas of control. It is a half good, half bad sort of result if you come to analyse it. The people of Australia will need to keep a close eye on the behaviour of the minister and the way in which this process goes into operation because the truth is, as in many areas where the government is uncertain of itself, that it puts a framework of legislation in place and at later stages fleshes out that framework with a multiplicity of regulations.

That delegated legislation process will enable us to finally have simple and clear legislation. This legislation is far from simple and far from clear and will worry a great number of people as its significance unfolds upon them. Already in this simple legislation we have three amendments to the Airports (Transitional) Bill 1995 to be moved on behalf of the opposition and five amendments to be moved by the government—and it is simple legislation. One hates to think—one shudders—when one considers the regulations and the multiplicity of activity that those regulations will control when brought into place. I confess that I can see real complexity and disaster ahead for the aviation industry in Australia. I see no clarity of thought. I see a mishmash of political ideology—a process that the minister has inherited from his term in office in New South Wales to fiddle in a political sense with what should be really clear and important economic decisions.

I intend to briefly run through some of the main flaws that I see in the legislation and then deal with the opposition's proposal that none of this go ahead until the government reopens the east-west runway. That is a significant thing and something that the opposition stands by. The government has provided in the minister's second reading speech an outline of the future operational responsibilities for airports and the consideration of Sydney West as it is linked with Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport.

I notice in the government's policy that the airports will be majority Australian owned. Australia will own 51 per cent. Unless one of the owners happens to be a friend of the government, such as Mr Murdoch or Mr Packer, those rules will be changed. I accuse the government of misleading the parliament in this area because they have no intention of sticking to the 49 per cent foreign ownership rule. They will change it at the drop of a hat if a powerful friend makes them a better offer or where they can see a better deal or where they can see that the process is failing and they need an extra injection of funds. They have done it time and again: they have done it within media ownership and control, they have done it with pay and cable television and they have done it with the Commonwealth Bank. First of all, they were not going to sell the Commonwealth Bank and, ultimately, they are selling the whole of the Commonwealth Bank. They did it with Qantas.

This is just another instance where in order to balance their failing budgets the government has sold more and more of Australia to overseas interests. It will be the same with the airports. The government should have the decency and the honesty to set out their real intention, because the Australian people are sick and tired of this sophistry of making a claim and then finding that they cannot match their claim or promise and they ultimately sell more and more of Australia to anybody who comes along, particularly if they are a rich and powerful friend like a media baron. The legislation is changed specifically for those people. In fact, the media ownership legislation was changed to accommodate a non-Australian citizen in an area that was reserved for Australian citizens.

The government will also seek diversity of ownership to the maximum extent possible. That is similar to what happened with the television licenses. The government will also encourage transparency and benchmark competition between the airports. They are high sounding words, but we know the complexity of the way in which the competition commission will work, the formulas that they will develop and the rules that they will devise, which will be incomprehensible to most Australians. Whilst talking about transparency on the one hand, on the other the government provides a screen behind which the operations of airports can hide from the gaze of the public. As a minimum there will be separate ownership, except in Sydney where Sydney and Sydney West will be linked. If you own Sydney and Sydney West, I understand that you cannot link Brisbane and Melbourne with that airport, but you may be able to link others.

All of these rules, including the rule that the ownership of airports by individual airlines and associated interests will be restricted to five per cent, are just like the ownership rules of media. It does not matter whether it is newspapers, television, pay television or cable television—these are all subject to change on the whim of the minister.

I need to point out to the House that this legislation has maximum ministerial interest, oversight and control because there is hardly a process in the whole legislation that does not finish up with the minister having to give each item his tick. Whether it is land planning provisions, the standards observed within airports or the processes of master plans, development of plans of any projects, including runways, terminals and other developments, and environmental impact assessments all have to get the ministerial tick.

The bill also requires that the operators, as I have said, have certain limitations placed on them. This is all under the ministerial control of the Minister for Transport. The minister's second reading speech states:

SPEECH.PARA: There is, in particular, substantial scope to protect areas surrounding the major airports from residential and other development incompatible with the long-term use of the airport.

It is to be under ministerial control, but the minister expects the cooperation of states in this process. He expects the cooperation of states because he recognises the constitutional limitation on what he can do.

PARA.TAB: But one only has to look at Sydney to understand how the minister has failed to gain the cooperation of states and the cooperation of the community. One only has to look at the press reports relating to the Hon. Jeannette McHugh. There has been protest after protest in the area of Sydenham, where, according to a representative of the Marrickville No Aircraft Noise Party, a suburb in a Labor electorate is being demolished. So here we have houses which have been lived in by Labor supporters being bulldozed in Labor electorates, and we have the minister saying in his second reading speech that he will get the cooperation of the states in all of this process.

I do not think the minister will get the support he wants. We have seen how he behaves when he does get support. He bulldozes houses to clear people out of properties they have lived in for years. It is a shameful day for the Australian Labor Party with what they have done around the Sydney airport. They are going to do more. The western Sydney airport promises to be just as difficult because across Sydney, I inform the House, group after group is jumping up to protest. These groups now suddenly understand what will happen when Sydney West opens and aircraft are flying over their properties and destroying their peace and their lifestyle.

These groups are growing in numbers because the government has failed to communicate and they distrust the minister. They have seen what the minister has done in relation to Sydney (Kingsford Smith), and they do not trust him to tell them the truth or to communicate effectively. The result of the minister's failure to communicate or to effectively explain what he has in mind about Sydney (Kingsford Smith) has resulted in the bulldozing of houses of Labor supporters. So why would people trust the current minister?

The minister leaves everything out of the agenda. He tries to cover up the issues. Curfews, runway operations, flight paths, noise, and acquisition and insulation programs are the minister's responsibility, as outlined in his speech. They are the responsibility of the minister, and the minister is bulldozing houses. I think that is deplorable.

I now refer the House to the decision by the opposition to oppose this sale or leasing of airports until the east-west runway is opened. The current situation is—I will hold up this map so that the House can see it—that aircraft fly through what I call `Laurie's loop'. They come up from the south and head straight for Sydney (Kingsford Smith) until they are about 10 miles away from the airport. When they are above densely populated areas they do a left-hand turn and fly out to the west of Sydney, out to the area around Pennant Hills, Baulkham Hills and North Rocks, which is in the electorate of Mitchell. They then fly over Parramatta and turn in a southerly direction to come in and land in a southerly direction on the north-south runway.

If Laurie, in his maddest dreams, had tried to find a flight path that inconvenienced more people, he could not have found it. The fact of the matter is that this Laurie's loop, as I have called it, covers almost the totality of Sydney. If you are going to do anything dangerous or stupid, you would fly aircraft over houses. That is what this map shows—that aircraft are covering the maximum extent of Sydney that they can. The only way that you could cover a greater number of houses with this process would be to fly aircraft zigzag across Sydney and try to cover every single house. There is no logic in this process. Every resident of the city of Sydney is disadvantaged by the current processes and landing patterns.

When we examine what has happened, we see 40 per cent of aircraft used to come in from the southerly route and come straight in and land on that east-west runway. That 40 per cent have been diverted all over the countryside—out through Hurstville, over Parramatta, around through Pennant Hills and west Pymble and right back through the electorates of Lowe and Bennelong—to land from the south at Sydney (Kingsford Smith). It is no wonder Labor Party members are being abused and no wonder Liberal Party members are being abused, because Laurie has developed this loop to cause the maximum inconvenience to everybody.

The aircraft are flying at 3,000 feet at 80 per cent power. To me, that seems a crazy process too. Why has this been devised? Is this a plot by the minister to make it hard for everybody in Sydney? That appears to be the case. Laurie's loop means that every individual—particularly if we take in the likely flight paths of commercial aircraft inbound from the north, where they can go over the peninsula and come in across the top to join the loop or they can fly around and cover the Cronulla area—is being inconvenienced and every house is being placed at some risk.

I would have thought the simplest and the most safety conscious process would be to fly aircraft in by the shortest route across houses and land. That is not being done in Sydney. I do not know what inspires the minister to say that this is the safest and the best process. I guess that he wants to lose seats. I can assure him that the people of Sydney understand what is going on.

The minister says, and has said, that the use of the east-west runway in Sydney is a dangerous process. He denies that we have used that successfully from practically the commencement of Sydney (Kingsford Smith). The American consulting company Flight Transportation Associates provided a report for the department and the minister saying that they can up the throughput of Sydney (Kingsford Smith) to 94 planes per hour by using cross-runways. The minister does not seem to know about that report. He has not mentioned it in any of his comments, although it was raised with him by Kerry O'Brien when he did an interview with the minister on Lateline on 23 November 1994, about a year ago.

We have experts saying that Sydney (Kingsford Smith) can be successfully used if there is an east-west runway operating. Max Hazelton, one of the doyens of Australian fliers, a great aviator and a man with huge success with all sorts of aircraft, agrees. Dr Fred Bell, consultant to the airport coordinating task force in 1990; Dr Jean Cross, Professor of Safety Science at the University of New South Wales; Captain Peter Skinner, President of the Australian International Pilots Association; Bill Pollard, the new chief executive of Airservices Australia; and Laurie Gruzman QC, a legal expert in aviation, all say that we can use the east-west runway and use it successfully. It is only the minister's decision that means we are not using it. I think it is wrong and the opposition is opposing this legislation, unless the government decides that it will release the east-west runway into proper use.

Finally, I need to say something about the development of Sydney West, because that is a shemozzle. I have heard from the Minister for Transport that there is no rail link plan. I have here from the FAC a proposal for Sydney West airport for a 2,900-metre runway development indicative timetable. There is nothing at all there for a rail link. The planning and negotiation finishes at the end of the second quarter in 1996. There are a whole lot of things on this indicative plan that ought to have happened but have not happened. The EIS has only just commenced. It should have been running for three months. It should have started at the beginning of July.

The whole program is running behind; yet we get press statements and releases that the bulldozers are ready to run in March. What is happening here? Has the government decided that, despite the results of the EIS, the bulldozers are going to move? That is what we are reading in the press: the bulldozers are ready to roll in March, whether or not the EIS is satisfactory. I want to hear some answers from the minister on these things. Is he going to be impeccable in his behaviour on this issue, or is he going to treat it like he does everything else—as a toy and a political plaything where truth does not count and veracity and safety of the Australian people are irrelevant?

One has to only look at the budget papers to find out the sophistry of this minister. The opening part relating to Sydney West airport mentions the government's commitment to the airport's development and its associated transport infrastructure. It then goes on to talk about the allocation of funds, including for rail.

Where is the allocation for rail? There is none. The minister has had to admit that there is no intention to proceed to provide rail links by the time of the Olympic Games; yet he is putting out press releases saying everything is going to be fine by the time the Olympic Games come. They are lies. We know they are. If he could come clean, at least we could manage the thing. But he is not prepared to come clean with the Australian people and tell them what is going on. He makes a budget statement claiming one thing and now he is saying another thing. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs CROSIO
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the last few months, in the parliament and throughout Sydney especially, airports and their effects have been a hot topic of conversation—noise, pollution, flight paths, supplementary airports, runways to the north, the south, the east and the west. Obviously airports, their development and their operation are very important to Australians, and are subsequently very important to us.

PARA.TAB: I think one of the most important spin-offs from all of the discussions concerning airports and their ramifications is that they have given Australians a clear indication on how the major parties in this country seek to address government to the needs of the people. While the leasing of airports is perhaps a less immediate issue to people concerned about noise or pollution from aircraft, I think it is this matter alone that really marks the difference between the government's and the opposition's desire to produce genuine solutions to the vexing questions of airports in this country.

In short, I believe the whole question of airport leasing has established the government's credentials without a doubt. From this issue alone I think it is stunningly obvious that we are the only people in this chamber willing and able to accept the mantle of responsible government for all Australians. The opposition, on the other hand, due to their inadequately structured policies and their willingness to change tack on any issue when it suits them, have shown themselves to be a terrible excuse for a bunch of alternative leaders. They bark and they bark; but, when it comes down to it, they are toothless—nothing but gums flapping in the breeze over there.

The Airports Bill 1995 demonstrates two things above all. The first point is that we, as a government, are committed to a program of responsible and well planned micro-economic reform. The leasing of Australia's airports will deliver $2 billion into the nation's coffers—$2 billion that is an essential part of the government's future financial strategy. The second point is that we are determined to guarantee the safe and clean operation of airports by any company that holds an airport lease. Any company that enters the Australian airport market will have to be prepared to follow a rigorous set of guidelines for that airport's operation.

In my time today I want to go through what I see are the chief issues concerning airport privatisation and, in doing so, highlight the government's ongoing commitment to pursuing a responsible airport policy. At the same time, I hope to make it perfectly clear to the members of this House and to all Australians just what kind of reckless and capricious opposition this country has.

Seeing that an airport's effect on the environment is one of the chief concerns in the community today, let me briefly explain the bill and how it delivers in this particular area. I believe truly that there is a misconception among certain sectors of the community that, once the government begins leasing airports, the airports will suddenly cease to be under the government's control and private companies will be able to run roughshod over the public's environmental concerns and to operate in any way they see fit. If anyone reads the bills, they will understand and appreciate that nothing could be further from the truth.

Just as landlords place rules and regulations on their tenants, so will the federal government on prospective airport lessees. A lessee company must submit to the government an initial draft and then, upon approval from the minister, a final draft environmental strategy which must specify the objectives of the environmental management of the airport; the source of environmental impacts; the proposed studies, reviews and monitoring of environmental impacts from the operation of the airport; the measures to be carried out to prevent, control or to reduce environmental impacts; and details of the consultations involved in the preparation of the strategy.

When considering approval of an environmental strategy, the minister must take into account what effect the implementation of the strategy would have on air, water and soil quality; the effect on noise levels; and details of the consultations entered into in developing that particular strategy. The minister can then refuse to grant an approval, asking the company to submit another strategy for inspection. The minister, through this legislation, has the power to refuse or approve an airport lessee's environmental strategy, just as the minister can refuse or approve an airport lessee's management plan for an airport and plans for any major building development at that airport.

Once a draft environmental strategy has been approved, the airport lessee must make the plans available to the public for inspection and must advertise to the public that it is doing so. Failure to follow such guidelines would lead to the government imposing a fine of up to $25,000 on the company. This is just a fragment of the tight guidelines that the government will be making all airport lessees follow. There will be no plans approved under the table.

Companies that eventually gain control of airport operations will not be able to turn around and build a couple of new runways as they so desire. The government, as landlords of the airports, will make certain that they are operated with the interest of all Australians in mind. Certainly I, for one, will be more comfortable as a resident of Sydney's south-west when Badgerys Creek is developed knowing that the company operating the airport must adhere to the regulations laid out by the government and is ultimately answerable to them.

Airports and their operations have become very important to me over the years. Since Badgerys Creek was announced in 1985 as the intended site for the development of Sydney West airport, I have watched with interest and sometimes—I must admit—with bated breath as this government's aviation policy has progressed. The future of my constituents has been at stake since the announcement in 1985 and I see it as a very grave responsibility to have my views heard on any matter that will affect the operation of Badgerys Creek.

The government's plan for airport privatisation aims to usher in a new era of sound management and development of civil aviation in Australia. We must provide airports, for Australians and visitors from around the world, of the highest international standards without sacrificing stringent standards covering airport operations and spin-off effects such as noise and pollution.

Let me give you an example. An independent consultancy group, Axis Environmental Consultants, was appointed by the FAC in September and is now conducting air and water studies and an aircraft noise assessment for the future Sydney West airport. This study is in addition to the exhaustive environmental impact statement originally carried out in 1985 for Sydney West. Axis will also develop environmental management plans for both the construction and the operation of the new airport and will prepare a notice of intention. Once its studies are completed, it will then have to report back to the FAC and to the government. The findings will be widely discussed and broadcasted in our local communities.

While the opposition sits back and takes pot shots from the sidelines, this government is purposefully making its way forward. The opposition, as demonstrated by its obstinate intention to block this bill, is pursuing a course whereby it is saying, `Let's just run the train off the tracks.' Providing better airports means providing more efficient airports, which inevitably means cheaper running costs with the savings being passed down to the consumer. We believe the best way to do this is to offer their management to private enterprise. The privatisation of the airports which are presently managed by the Federal Airports Corporation is essential if this government is to meet its budgetary responsibilities. Yet on the other side of the House we have the self-proclaimed economic rationalists—the team whose political bread and butter is attempting to prove to Australians that they are the ones that should be running the economy.

It must leave a bitter taste in the mouths of those opposite to have to follow the lead of a man so desperate to hold on to his own seat that he would even go against his party's natural grain. He will run against every fibre in their collective beings. He will make them oppose a bill that makes economic sense for the whole country. The opposition benches are creaking with the weight of them all squirming in their seats. They are mouthing off about the quality of life of people under the flight paths while at the same time they are opposing a bill that delivers on quality of life, and categorically so. This government has proven itself as being prepared to deliver a far-reaching reform of Australia's airports with the future—20, 30 and 50 years from now—in mind.

The opposition owes it to the Australian people to support this bill wholeheartedly. They have done themselves a great disservice in stating that they will oppose its passage. The opposition have let themselves down not only in displaying to the electorate their small-mindedness and their incapacity to provide strong leadership but also in giving us a peek into the big black hole that is their policy bag. From the opposition's continually shifting stance on airports, it is quite obvious that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) just sticks his hand into the lucky dip and pulls out whatever his little fingers can grab a hold on.

Only a few weeks ago it suddenly became the opposition's policy that, once Badgerys Creek was built, it would become Sydney's international airport while Kingsford Smith would be scaled down for domestic traffic. Where did that come from? It came from his lucky dip bag of tricks. The chief executive of the tourism task force, Mr Chris Brown, said, `It's quite bizarre. It's totally unbelievable and utterly unfeasible.' What kind of confidence can Australians have in a man that formulates policy like that? What kind of confidence can Australian business people have? With the opposition's intention to stand against the government on this bill, a move obviously made again at the drop of a hat, business people all around the country and around the world are questioning their motives. They are asking themselves, `What kind of a man is this?'

You now have international companies such as Lockheed Corporation and BAA thrown into total confusion. Where is the opposition's famous business acumen that they would like to think they have? If the opposition continue with this line of action, they will cause serious economic damage to this country. Our reputation will also suffer accordingly in business circles abroad.

I know that some people in our community have listened to the speeches made in this House over the last few months concerning airports and airport policy. They have thought, `Oh well, what is it? A load of old rhetoric.' I can appreciate their weariness and their wariness. When the government announced that Badgerys Creek airport was the intended site for the new Sydney West airport, I was one of the few people—I might have been the only one—to get on their soapbox and register disappointment and concern over the then proposals. This was five years before I entered federal parliament. It was 10 years before our current friends in the opposition attempted to gain some political mileage from objecting to airport development.
