Where were all the protesters then? Where were the action committees, the supposed concerned citizen groups and the Liberal Party apologists?

I know that sometimes people get so worked up about an issue that they can develop selective memories. Despite my past reservations, I am convinced to my very bootstraps that this government is the only team capable of providing Australians with an aviation policy worthy of our tourism needs, our capacity for economic growth and our community's demands for clean air and peace and quiet.

From simply looking at the opposition's actions in regard to this particular bill, do people really think that if ever that lot gained power in this country they would have a government capable of formulating a cohesive, fair and safe aviation policy? I think not. They said, `We want the third runway.' Then they dithered: `No, we want the east-west runway.' They then said, `We want Kingsford Smith operating at full capacity for Australia's tourism future.' But they are now saying, `We want Kingsford Smith as a domestic airport and Sydney West as the international operation.' What will they be saying in a few months from now?

TALK.START.PARA: —Whatever comes into their head.

—Exactly. Who knows? Certainly not the Leader of the Opposition. I believe he will sniff the air, lick his finger to see which way the wind is blowing and then provide us with a few abstract ideas, a few fuzzy notions, that he might have rolling about in his head for a few hours as he sees fit. There is no leadership, there is no firm decision making and there are certainly no guts on the part of the opposition.

PARA.TAB: If the Leader of the Opposition had read the Sydney Morning Herald on Monday, 15 October, he would have noticed that his heroine, Baroness Margaret Thatcher, cited what she believed was the secret to her government's success. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: We had principles, we had purpose, we had action and we had perseverance.

These are qualities that are missing from the opposition. They are certainly qualities that are missing from their excuse for an aviation policy. The opposition's shallowness over aviation has been an insult to the Australian people. Their objection to this bill is so self-serving.

PARA.TAB: The crime of it is that the opposition actually want Australia's airports privatised. It makes plain and simple sense to support this bill, but they will not. In fact, they cannot support it because of their leader's navel gazing. Never mind that if the coalition block the bill they will be condemning the largest micro-economic reform in civil aviation over the last 25 years to the backburner. Never mind that they will be knocking $2 billion out of next year's budget. Never mind that the logic behind their planned prevention of the bill is illogical and that rather than sharing the noise around, as the Leader of the Opposition so naively explains, opening the east-west runways would, apart from providing a safety risk, actually affect as many as 142,000 more people with aircraft noise. Never mind that, even if you open up the east-west runway's stub, it will increase the north-south runway's capacity for another 10 jumbos an hour. That means another 10 jumbos over the member for Bennelong's own electorate. He really should keep his eyes open just a bit more when he delves into that lucky dip policy bag of his, should he not?

I began my speech by making the point that the main result of the Leader of the Opposition's intentions to block this bill has not been that Sydneysiders and Australians have become enamoured of him through his supposedly noble actions. Rather they have seen it as just another example of a politician acting out of self-interest and being blown where the wind takes him. Australians, despite enjoying fame for being a fairly easygoing bunch, demand integrity from their politicians. They also demand leadership, decision making and the provision of a vision for the country. They are all qualities that Australians admire and respect.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) recently made the comment, in relation to airports, that governments that do things the nation needs are generally rewarded—and he is right. The Australian people—not Sydneysiders, not even those who are trapped in the electorate of the Leader of the Opposition, the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard)—will reward the Leader of the Opposition for his stunning narrow-mindedness in blocking the passage of this bill. There is no leadership behind his actions, there is no grander plan. It is definitely small town stuff.

The Airports Bill 1995 is part of the government's plan for Australia's future. It will benefit us all. The opposition leader's concept of the future extends to the next election. His sole intention is to benefit himself—and I believe this has been proven by the debate which has been had in the House today since the introduction of this bill.

We need to have opposition that is true opposition. We need to have input into legislation that is to be carried through the community at large. This is not what is happening today. Many people out there will call it political blackmail.

But we have had it said with one breath that privatisation will take place, and will take place if ever the opposition gets into government, and then we have had it said with the next breath, `We will not allow this bill to go through because you are not going to open the third runway.' I believe people will see through that come polling day. But, most importantly, the people who would benefit from stringent guidelines and stringent legislation, as are contained in this bill which is before the House, are the ones who could ultimately suffer.

I believe that, if the opposition are truly on about protecting the environment, are true in their concerns about pollution and noise and where we are going with the development of aviation policies within this country, then they will read this bill and read within it the intent with which it has been expressed—and that is to put a policy into place that will protect people not only in the next five to 10 years but also in the next 20 to 50 years. As I have repeatedly said: as landlords, we will never give up the responsibility of what we own, just as no landlord should be expected to do. Only in that and with this legislation can we truly have a bill and have into policy what can be accepted through Australia at large. At least then we will have put in place in the aviation policy sound thinking, sound guidelines and, most particularly, expert legislation.

I commend the bills. I do not congratulate the opposition on the stance they have taken. Rather, I condemn them for it, and I condemn their actions and their speakers in the way they have taken this policy. I support the bills before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —My association with the Kingsford Smith airport in Sydney goes back to the days when I was a child. My father knew the late Reg Follett, who was one of the pioneers of the development of Mascot airport. In those days it was I guess a sand flat, it was really a grass strip, and of course there was very little traffic. It was underdeveloped. In those days it certainly had problems when there was a lot of heavy rain. Drainage still remains a major challenge for the use of those facilities.

PARA.TAB: But it is a facility which has from then, in those prewar days to now, had several advantages. Probably the most notable is that it has, because of its lie adjacent to Botany Bay, a facility to ensure that aircraft movements can be significantly over water. It probably is one of the most conveniently located international and domestic airport anywhere in the world. It is close to the CBD.

Of course, while the population centre of Sydney has moved west, and there are certainly a large number of aircraft movements in and out of Bankstown airport, the character and nature of passenger traffic increasingly is either to the central business district—and that is where a large percentage of the intrastate traffic moves—or to the hotels which, again, are largely located around that central heart of Sydney. It is to that heartland that, of course, so many international visitors first go.

With the Olympics 2000, the Olympic Games and all the tourist potential there, that will be out to the Homebush region of Sydney. In that instance I have no doubt that many tourists will want to go and live down by the waterfront. They will want to enjoy the magnificent beaches that are along that eastern strip of coastline adjacent to Sydney.

What concerns me about this whole proposal in the legislation before us is that it shows a government not knowing what it is going to do to provide better access to Sydney. This government has not looked at all the alternatives and tried to provide the maximum traffic flow through this airport as it is now and as it may be developed in the future. This government is really trying to ensure that, to the maximum, it contains what it sees as the political threat to its own seats in the Sydney metropolitan area.

I rise to speak on this debate for several reasons. One is that I am concerned for those who live in rural New South Wales. I think it is important that people do not just look at Mascot as an international airport but understand that, unlike most other states, there has been enormous growth in intrastate traffic to Mascot. Indeed, East West Airlines, which unfortunately is now a part of Ansett, developed a major intrastate service in the postwar years. The late Don Shand and his colleagues in setting up, with very small and humble beginnings, such a service really ensured that country centres—like that which you represent, Mr Deputy Speaker Vaile, and Tamworth and the south and the west of New South Wales—were among the first centres in Australia to really enjoy a better than average air service and, consequently, an accelerated access to the centre of Sydney.

It is no use saying to those people on those services, `We're going to put you out to some new airport way out at Badgerys Creek.' They are not interested in that. What they want to do is to see how, to the maximum, they can maintain access to the central business district, so that they can come down to Sydney in the morning and do their business and return home at night. If it is for tourists, they too, in my view, do not want to go to Badgerys Creek.

I know other countries are developing international airports, some of which are a long way from the heart of their city. I know that, in the days to come, Sydney certainly needs a second airport. But I remain to be convinced that Badgerys Creek is the site. Having had a look at Badgerys Creek and knowing the undulating terrain, seeing the infrastructure and the lack of reasonable access there, all the plans that we hear from the government seem to me to be all predicated on a political agenda rather than a rational assessment of what the long-term future will be of an airport built out there at Badgerys Creek.

I have made the point on other occasions in this place that for the life of me I cannot understand how an airport in the most rapidly developing urban area of outer Sydney, where all take-offs and landings have to be over land, is not—in the course of the next 20 years, if not a little longer—going to become far more a source of noise contamination and pollution than that at Mascot. At Mascot, certainly with the north-south take-offs and landings, 50 per cent of landings and take-offs are over sea and 50 per cent over land. The significance of Mascot is that it has other advantages that Badgerys Creek demonstrably lacks.

I started by saying that I am concerned about the maintenance of maximum possible access to Mascot in the future. And I continue by saying that I do not know whether the Badgerys Creek site is the best one for future development for international and domestic air services into Sydney.

It is not easy developing a site for a second airfield. I have been very taken by the ideas that I have read in recent times about an inquiry into a major new freight centre somewhere out of Sydney. I know centres around New South Wales, including Canberra, have been putting in their bids for consideration to be a new international airfreight hub.

If we are going to develop such an airfreight hub, I question whether it might not be better to think of allowing those airfreight aircraft to carry passengers to supplement the loadings and to make sure the economics of that international air hub would be better than would otherwise be the case. It might allow a significant development which would allow, therefore, other means of transporting people from wherever that international hub is outside Sydney in a way which will overcome the need for that second Sydney airport.

If you are going to look at going to Badgerys Creek and at the time taken to travel from Badgerys Creek to the CBD in Sydney, I am not convinced that it would not be possible to find some such hub out of Sydney with either a very fast train or some other communication which might ensure that you do not have to develop that second Sydney airport.

This legislation is about selling the airport. It is legislation which is designed to get the government out of its financial quandary. It is not legislation designed to provide better air services. It is not legislation designed in any way to overcome aircraft noise. It is not legislation in any way related to trying to meet the tourist needs of Sydney in the future. It is all about trying to privatise the airports around Australia and about the government getting more money to operate. I am in favour of privatisation, but I am not in favour of trying to develop legislation only to get money for the government without looking at all those wider problems.

I am particularly concerned that, as far as Mascot is concerned, there are a number of significant matters that, to my mind, have not been satisfactorily answered. I do not follow why using two parallel runways exclusively in any way can be seen to be an efficient management of aircraft movements to and from Sydney. If we look at the direction in which aircraft approach Sydney, we see that there are a minimal number at this time that can fly straight into Sydney.

I find it impossible to understand why, in the control of aircraft movements, nearly every aircraft movement into Sydney is subject to some sort of a delay. Those of us who, as members of parliament, use Sydney quite extensively and access Mascot airport frequently by air know that you come in from Canberra and you finish up coming in from the south. You run over Warragamba Dam, you probably approach Sydney on the south western precincts and you run up over the west. You are just as likely to come in from the north and the aircraft will probably be down at 5,000 feet for a large part of that approach into Sydney. The noise contamination is just inexcusable. The delays into Mascot cost time and money and add to air pollution, fuel consumption and passenger costs.

I know that as far as this bill is concerned privatisation really relates only to the ownership of the airport precincts, but Mascot has to be operated efficiently because it is to be licensed as an airport, as will all the other airports to be sold. It has to take into account how you are going to reasonably be able to operate efficiently and accurately into these airports with maximum safety but also with minimal time delays and, hopefully, minimal aircraft noise contamination.

Until there is a reasonable and rational use of Mascot airport, I do not believe anyone can say that the time has arrived for this bill to be put into effect. It is for that reason, and because I absolutely despair of the management of the whole air transport industry as well as other aspects of the portfolio of the present minister, that I suspect this legislation must be deferred until the change of government, after the next federal election.

I have several other worries about the whole of the present use of Mascot. When you turn back to the Financial Review report of 23 March 1989, which detailed the marathon cabinet process which led to the approval for the third runway, you realise that some of the problems that exist now in the structure of the airport are unlikely to be solved if the airport is presently privatised and if the present government is put in charge of the whole process. I will comment a little more on the content of the Financial Review article in a moment.

That approval ensured that, instead of the third runway bringing aircraft somewhere close to the hangars and to the terminal, it has been pushed right out into the bay. As a result, aircraft come down on the approach from the northern precincts far lower over the buildings and the occupied area than is necessary. Then they have to taxi for an extraordinarily long distance before they get back to the main hangars.

We would be much better off with the plans of the third runway that the coalition approved in 1982, put up by the Hon. Wal Fife, the then minister for aviation. I am satisfied that if that runway had been built we would be so much better off. Instead of that, with the parallel runways we have now we have houses being pulled down in Labor areas. We have all sorts of supposed measures being taken to contain noise contamination. Why? It is because the aircraft are not being managed in the right way in their approach and take-off to Mascot. It is that mess that this bill seeks to transform in some way by privatising the airport. To my mind, unless you approach those other areas adequately, you are just not going to resolve the problem.

I return to the article of the Financial Review. It says that it is not the Minister for Transport presently in the Keating ministry who is responsible but that it is the Prime Minister himself. It said:

Before the cabinet meeting on Tuesday morning, Mr Keating, Mr Hawke and the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Willis, met to discuss the issue. Mr Keating's concern was that the third runway—north to south with aircraft landing and taking off only to the south over Botany Bay—would have only a marginal impact on the airport's capacity, would require the Badgerys Creek airport to be developed relatively quickly [by the mid-1990s] and would not relieve noise problems associated with the east-west runway. After looking at various configurations, Mr Keating proposed that the new north-south runway be fully operational from both directions and the old east-west runway be virtually made redundant.

That article is an accurate reflection of the reason many of the problems presently being suffered at Mascot need to be sheeted home to the Prime Minister. In other words, the original proposal of the third runway was that aircraft should take off only to the south and land from the south so that they flew over water rather than houses. What did the Prime Minister do? He changed that. He sent them roaring over suburbia. So all the problems in Sydney are not specifically the responsibility of Minister Brereton. They are the responsibility of the Prime Minister and his intervention in the cabinet process.

To my mind, to proceed with the sale of Mascot airport in circumstances where those aircraft movements are only permitted in that narrow configuration on the two parallel runways, with a significant number of take-offs and landings over land and without use of the cross-runway, is madness. If you think, `That is in some way going to prejudice airport safety,' you have to remember the evidence Dr Fred Bell, of F&J Bell and Associates Environmental Consulting, gave in a letter to the Sydney Morning Herald on 1 October this year. He was a consultant to the Airport Coordinating Taskforce in 1990 and he had to look at the third runway impact and the extent to which the third runway was going to increase or otherwise the prospects of some sort of an aircraft accident on the tarmac. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)the risks of fatal aircraft collisions on the tarmac are much lower than the risks of fatal crashes of airborne planes in the flightpaths . . . and

(b)the risks to flightpath residents of crashes from airborne planes are greater with the concentrated flight patterns of the parallel runways than with the dispersed flight patterns of crossed runway operations.

In terms of safety, you have an environmental assessor who says that, with the closeness of the parallel runways, the risks to flight path residents of crashes are greater than with the dispersed flight patterns of crossed runway operations.

PARA.TAB: I mentioned before the problem we are all conscious of as we fly into and out of Mascot; that is, so many aircraft traverse the city in order to land on those two parallel runways. I have done flown into Sydney twice in the last three weeks. I have been in the air with aircraft not very far away from the aircraft I am in. Many of them are at a distance not that far from where we are travelling.

It concerns me that without using the cross-runway you still have a very high risk—I am not too sure of the measure of that risk—of aircraft flying on a collision course through the very fact that they are forced to cross the city in order to use the parallel runways. That is not on the ground; it is in the air. That is an extension of what, to my mind, Dr Bell was commenting on in that letter of his.

It seems to me that there are four things that need to be considered before this airport is sold. As far as the safety of Mascot is concerned, I believe it is absolutely essential that you get aircraft directed into Sydney by the most efficient and shortest route. That means when you allocate slot times you should allow not for the aircraft to traverse Sydney before it comes into land but to the maximum have aircraft landing and taking off over water, to the maximum ensure that in their flight path you direct them, as near as possible, towards a direct approach into Mascot from as far out as you can. It is possible. It used to be done when the cross-runway was used. That will save time, ensure aircraft are not approaching Mascot in a way to accelerate the noise contamination, and will ensure more economic use of the airport and more economic travel by the aircraft themselves.

Another thing which is absolutely essential is another survey. I know we have had many of them, but I am not happy about Badgerys Creek. I remain to be convinced that the present plans for Badgerys Creek in any way are going to save the traffic flow out of Mascot. I believe the long-term potential of development in the Badgerys Creek area is likely to exacerbate noise contamination in the western part of Sydney in a way which is going to be far worse than presently occurs at Mascot. It is no use the government today saying, `We are going out to Badgerys Creek to save your problem in Mascot.' All you are going to do is create a problem in 20, 30 or 40 years time. I do not see that as the answer to Sydney's problems.

The last thing is that, as far as the sale of this airport is concerned, I believe it would be improper to proceed, not only on the basis of the amendment moved by the opposition—that is, until the cross-runway is open—but until there has been more efficient and less politically motivated direction of aircraft traffic movements around Mascot than is presently the case. I think there is a real problem not peculiarly in Mascot but around Australia because of the problems of Mascot.

This bill is not really designed to meet the needs of the travelling aircraft public of Australia but to meet the financial needs of this government. For that reason, the bill should be deferred. I support totally the amendment moved by the opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Airports Bill represents what must be the nadir of the government's 13 years in office. It confirms that the government not only has been a coalition government in drag but has consistently served the special interests rather than the public interests. It is probably the final betrayal of its constituency.

PARA.TAB: The Hawke-Keating government since 1983 has done most of the fundamental things that the Fraser-Howard government of 1975-83 promised to do but did not do—deregulation, asset selling, privatisation, the rich getting richer and the neutering of the union movement, to mention but a few things. At least a coalition government would have been more honest and the Labor constituency could have fully vented its opposition.

This is a bill to privatise Australia's airports. Let no-one be deluded by the term `lease'. Leasing for 99 years, under the terms set out in this bill, is effectively forever. All the options for the future of Australia's air services to be operated in the national interest or even the local public interest at specific airports will be closed off.

The inevitable problems that will emerge in the future both on a national and local basis will be resolved in the private interest. It is almost unbelievable that the government could propose such a course given the disastrous situation at Sydney airport—a disaster which is largely the result of the government's mismanagement since 1983; a stewardship which at every twist and turn has been for the benefit of the airlines and in contempt of the people of Sydney and the Australian taxpayer.

This bill entrenches not only all the current problems at Sydney and other airports but locks up the future for over a century. What has happened at Sydney over its 50 years of development will be repeated at many other sites—Melbourne, Brisbane, Cairns, and even places like Broome. The writing is already on the wall for the relatively short-term future at these airports, let alone 99 years.

Airport traffic will eventually grow, more space will be required, urban areas will inevitably expand, and patterns of air traffic in Australia will change as will management and technology. Yet all this will be resolved in the interests of a series of private companies and the public will be left virtually powerless to the mercies of private profit—a complete abandonment of the role of government.

Make no mistake; all the paraphernalia of regulation in the bills with respect to controls on foreign ownership, diversity of ownership, existing airlines and the limitations of land use is so much window-dressing. All that can and will change on demand just as have similar so-called controls on foreign ownership generally or media regulations.

Airports of the future will be vast complexes of wide ranging commercial activities such as supermarkets, offices and entertainment facilities, all totally excluded from any local or state controls—one law for the public and another for the government's favourite sons.

Future problems will be dealt with by the minister of the day with `That's commercial-in-confidence' and `We can't afford the massive compensation that that would involve.' The Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) shows no concern for or recognition of these problems or even of the current problems of Sydney residents. His main concern seems to be, using his words, `inconveniencing foreign interests'.

Indeed, most of the minister's speech reminds me of the manufacturers of the Auschwitz gas chambers extolling the quality, manufacturing techniques and delivery times as recorded in the book The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich. He seems oblivious to the long-term future of residents of Sydney and other cities around Australia.

I know that here in Canberra, among the government, the bureaucracy, the press gallery and even among many members, Sydney airport is considered a minor local issue affecting two or three seats out of 147 at the next election. The government apparently sees only the noise problem and even that in only political terms. Its approach of concentrating the noise on as few voters as possible is cynical and brutal.

This bill ensures that Badgerys Creek will never be more than a minor overflow airport. It maximises aircraft movements at Kingsford Smith, cuts off options for the future, ensures that the massive public subsidies to the airlines continue, ensures the control of the airport by Ansett and Qantas, cutting off competition, ensures the airport remains a third-rate airport, ensures the urban blight of Sydney will continue and ensures that thousands will continue to be exposed to massive health hazards from noise, carcinogens and the ever present threat of airline accidents. It represents an environmental and economic disaster unrivalled in Australia's history.

Sydney is Australia's largest city. It contains almost a quarter of Australia's population. Forty years ago only a few thousand were affected by noise, which was only a fraction of the intensity that perhaps over 100,000 endure today. Some 28 suburbs are now affected by aircraft noise far in excess of acceptable health standards. Doctors are now seeing increasing numbers of people suffering from sleep deprivation, headaches, stress, and respiratory and hearing problems. These problems can only increase and will lead to endless future litigation. Yet the noise is only one problem.

Abundant evidence has been given by some doctors concerning the nightmarish effect of the carcinogenic hydrocarbons emitted from engine exhausts. As the Sun-Herald of 7 May 1995 reported, `In Sydney the exhausts from thousands of planes will kill people. Nobody in the government or the aviation industry will yet recognise this.' Yet this bill entrenches and expands these problems for the long-term future.

The bill ensures that Qantas and Ansett will continue to expand at Kingsford Smith, safe from effective competition—safe with their 30-year leases secretly negotiated in an obscene deal at Kirribilli in the late 1980s. The bill attempts to ensure not only by the leasing of Kingsford Smith but also by leasing Sydney West to the same owners that Sydney West will only remain a minor overflow airport. There is no incentive to develop it and in fact every incentive to expand Kingsford Smith for international and interstate aircraft, with general aviation and regional airlines gradually forced out to Sydney West. The bill thus provides for a maximising of large jet movements and passengers at Kingsford Smith.
The government seems intent on piling horror on horror for Sydney residents. In December 1990, in opposing the expansion of Kingsford Smith by the construction of the third runway, I said:

What is the fate of residents of postcode 2044 in Tempe, Sydenham and St Peters—8,106 people within two kilometres of the runway, directly under the flight path; 47 per cent non-Australian born; 33 per cent below the poverty line; 46 per cent left school before 15? For them it is not just a matter of annoyance noise, it is vibration that cracks walls, and noise and kerosene from jets that seriously damages health. It is slow extermination of postcode 2044 as a residential area.

TALK.START.PARA: —The famous poem The Man from Snowy River was first published this day 100 years ago. The publication of this magnificent poem is being celebrated in Corryong in the upper Murray in my electorate. Many people from around the world and Australia are going to be there over the next few days to join in those celebrations.

PARA.TAB: I thought I would take this opportunity to pay tribute to Banjo Paterson and his poem and mention briefly my view of what the poem means to Australians 100 years since it was first published. I think most Australians would take this poem as their favourite as it represents many aspects of the nation. Many Australians respond when they hear the words:

SPEECH.PARA: There was movement at the station, for the word had passed around
That the colt from old Regret had got away. . .

They are very familiar words and they bring back many memories to Australians overseas when they hear them. The poem is about the men, the people and the wild bush horses from the rugged mountains, rivers and streams in the alpine, Kosciusko and upper Murray area. The words state that the horse—`he was worth a thousand pound'—had gone off with the wild horses and everyone had gathered to go and find it and bring it back.

PARA.TAB: The Man from Snowy River is an entertaining, evergreen poem. As a national poem, it has endured for 100 years and it will continue to do so. It tells us a lot about our nation and it reflects on the mystic relationship between horse and man. For a poem to live as long as this, it has to mean a lot to Australians. Being set in the magnificent and beautiful country which I am so proud of and which many Australians love to visit is very appropriate.

There is also some controversy with the poem because it celebrates the anonymous battler, the person who was to ride and find this famous horse and bring it back. There is much controversy and legend as well as some stories that are hard to believe about who that famous battler was. But the people of Corryong know who he was. He was Jack Riley, who is buried in the Corryong cemetery. He died in 1914, and on his gravestone in Corryong are the words `The Man from Snowy River'.

To doubting Thomases who say that this person was someone else or that it was just the imagination of the poet, I say that no-one else has a grave with those words on it, and that sort of evidence is irrefutable. So the legend lives on. I congratulate the committee and the people of the upper Murray for their wonderful festival and for the traditions which they preserve, respect and use to help Australians celebrate and remember their history.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to talk about an announcement made last week by the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) at the ACOSS annual conference regarding a pilot proposal for homeless young Australians. I think the proposal put forward by the member for Bennelong is unacceptable, as it should be to all members of this House.

PARA.TAB: As Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs, I had the privilege of tabling a report on youth homelessness in June following an extensive nationwide inquiry. That report dealt in great detail with the issues, characteristics and problems relating to youth homelessness.

The proposal put forward by the member for Bennelong indicates the introduction of a six-week transitional payment to be managed by a voluntary agency, which must take all appropriate steps to mediate a reconciliation with the young person's family or guardian. The intent of that part of the proposal is to introduce compulsory mediation as a requirement for financial support. Effectively, it means that abused young people who seek assistance from the government would have to agree to participate in meetings with their abusers before they gained financial support.

During the inquiry there was very strong evidence that mediation can be a very effective and beneficial vehicle for reconciling families, but only when it is voluntary. The idea of compulsory mediation was rejected almost totally by the witnesses and by comments in the vast bulk of evidence that was submitted to us.

The proposal that the member for Bennelong raised and that the Liberal Party would introduce in government effectively imposes compulsory mediation. This reflects the committee's minority report, which was initiated by the shadow minister for social security, who was a member of the committee, and signed by all opposition members of the committee.

These opposition members put forward the proposal that mediation and adjudication should be available when serious allegations of physical or sexual abuse are made. They also incorporated in their report the suggestion that a form of appeal should be available—that is, the payment should be subject to appeal by the parents. In effect, the abusers could appeal against the person abused being supported.

The fact is that most young Australians and their families do not have major problems. Most grow up, become independent and become parents themselves without a hiccup or a concern. But it is also a fact that tens of thousands of young Australians are abused every year. In 1992-93, there were more than 22,000 substantiated cases of abuse or neglect against young Australians, and that number is increasing annually.

We might like to ignore that or pretend that it is not happening, but the fact is that it is happening. The opposition is now putting forward a proposal which blames the victims for the problems, implies that the veracity of the young people making the allegations should be questioned and says that they need to agree to be mediated. This is outrageous.

Those people whom the member for Bennelong spoke to last week at the ACOSS conference will understand that. The broader community may see the proposal as being attractive—it sounds like a great idea; `mediation' is a wonderful word—but when young men or women have been physically or sexually abused and are then told, `You will need to have mediation sessions,' they will not apply for financial support.

Those young people will turn to other means of income, and we heard that during the inquiry. Crime and prostitution are the alternatives that young Australians have chosen in the past and they will choose them in the future if we deny them support. The proposal put forward last week sounded benign and, on the face of it, plausible. In reality, it is a vicious, regressive move which should be condemned by all of us in this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Sunday, 8 October 1995 a friend of mine and no doubt of all who knew him, Mr Dudley Belling, passed away. Dudley was a long-time resident of Illabo, a small town close to Junee, Dirnaseer and Bethungra, and was well known and highly regarded by everyone in the district who had any contact with him—and this would have been nearly everyone.

PARA.TAB: Dudley was married to Mary and together they raised a large family—no doubt often finding it a struggle, but certainly the Belling family was never short of love and caring. Dudley was firstly a great Christian gentleman who set high moral standards for himself and therefore expected the same from those around him. He was always working for someone in the community, whether it be someone from the Illabo Show Society, the Catholic Church, the National Party, the Illabo Country and Western Stampede or, indeed, anyone who asked for his help. Anyone who required his help was never refused.

Dudley Belling's funeral service, and requiem mass said by Father Fitzgerald, was held in the small Illabo Catholic Church, which is reminiscent of many of those small Catholic churches built by the early Irish pioneers in many parts of Australia, and particularly in the Riverina. When I first saw it, I was reminded of Father Hartigan, who went under the nom de plume of John O'Brien and was author of the poems in the famous publication Around the Boree Log.

It did not surprise me to see that most of the 300-strong mourners were standing outside the church, which could not contain all those who came to mourn the passing of their friend Dudley. As we stood in the churchyard on that beautiful Riverina spring day, the grass was green and the grain crops in the distance were thriving. There were a few sprinkles from light clouds as they passed over an otherwise blue sky, and the sound of the birds singing in the nearby trees made me think of Dudley's great love for the beautiful country that he was part of.

Dudley's greatest love was for his family, and I know how proud he was of their achievements. He also loved his community. I must say how proud I was to be associated with Dudley, as were all who knew him. For those of us who are fortunate, at some time in our lives—perhaps even more than once—we meet a person with whom we have an immediate affinity and whom we quickly grow to love and admire. This is how I felt about Dudley Belling, and I am sure that I was one of many who felt this way about him. On behalf of my wife, Annie, and my staff, I offer my condolences to Mary and her family and pray that they have the courage to overcome their present grief and to face the future, receiving all of those blessings that Dudley would have wished for them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Swan Mr W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) sometimes blunders into speaking the truth. So, when on ABC radio this morning he said that the industrial strife in Western Australia was a product of politics, he was dead right. He was right because his colleagues in Western Australia in the Court-Kierath government set out from day one to politicise industrial relations in that state.

PARA.TAB: Confrontation, not consensus, is the first commandment of the Court-Kierath government. Linked with that first commandment is their law: `Thou shalt not have any trade unions before me.' Like a cockatoo screeching his few words again and again, John Howard keeps telling us that Labor is running a scare campaign against the coalition's industrial relations policy.

Let us listen to the words of his Western Australian colleague Graham Kierath when he was arguing the case for abolishing the award system in that state and getting rid of the safety net. These are his words, not the Labor Party's words. They are his own words exactly. On ABC Lateline on 23 August, Mr Kierath said:

SPEECH.PARA: Areas of the labour market that were over-priced and needed to be re-adjusted, what we would call low-skilled, low-paid starter jobs.
That is the agenda in Western Australia—to cut wages for the low skilled and the low paid. There is no sentiment in that statement for battlers, just cold words.

PARA.TAB: Then look at Mr Kierath's own action on 26 September when he rejected a recommendation of the Western Australian Industrial Relations Commission that the weekly minimum wage should be increased by $24.30. He cut that figure back by a third to $16, making a minimum wage in that state of $317.10. In Victoria recently, Mr Kennett put forward a minimum wage of $8.60 per hour without provision for loadings, penalty rates or skill increments. That was a cut of $60 a week for a minimum wage worker in that state.

The Labor Party did not invent Graham Kierath or Jeff Kennett as part of a scare campaign. Mr Kierath is the Liberal Party, the Liberal Party in government. No Labor politician made up those words about cutting the wages of the low skilled. They are all his own words. No Labor scare campaign invented his action in slashing the arbitrator's recommendation for minimum wage earners. The Western Australian government is contemptuous of low wage earners. Its first round of industrial relations legislation abolished overtime pay and penalty rates and did not allow for a no disadvantage test. It was clearly an agenda to cut wages for low income earners.

The manufactured crisis in industrial relations in Western Australia is about politics. Mr Howard was absolutely right about that; the politics of the hard, bully-boy, standover, right wing who want to slash wages and who so dominate the Liberal and National parties in this House and throughout the Australian states. Court and his hatchet man Kierath had one simple objective: to destroy the right of people to organise collectively to negotiate. When they achieve that, all low paid workers can be picked off one by one. Kicking low wage earners is what Mr Howard's cheer squad of fellow Liberals want to hear, and certainly what they in this House want to hear. That is the politics of fanatics. It is as fanatic, and more fanatic, than any old-fashioned Stalinist class warfare believer would say or do.

Last week the world celebrated the 50th anniversary of the publication of George Orwell's Animal Farm, the brilliant satire on the abuse of power by Stalin, which was just as much a satire on the abuse of words by politicians like John Howard. Orwell, were he living today, would recognise and relish the cynical abuse of words by the coalition in the discussions about industrial relations.

Take Kierath's use of the word `readjustment' when he refers to what is a cut and slash policy for low wage earners. The word `readjustment' is neutral. Mr Kierath makes it all sound like adjusting the focus on a TV screen. But the truth is that those wage earners are human beings with families, and readjustment, in the Liberal Party's parlance, means taking money out of the mouths of working families. Orwell would have appreciated the sheer, blatant cheek of the way in which John Howard repeats the word `reform' again and again, like zealots chant slogans.

The plain meaning of the word `reform' in the history of Western democracies has been change for the better—progress, whether it is for more voting rights, welfare for the aged and needy, justice for all or, more importantly, the right of people to organise. But when John Howard uses the word `reform', he does not mean progress; he means turning the clock back. In Mr Howard's good old days, nurses were not paid overtime. In Mr Howard's good old days, when school leavers presented themselves at their first job in a shop there was no nonsense about restrictions on hours and no trade union officials around to raise inconvenient questions. All they had was the right to negotiate the privilege of sleeping under the counter.

Going back a bit further in Mr Howard's golden days, governments had not yet intervened against child labour. So the logic of the Liberal position is simply to remove conditions and to go back to those bad old days. The logic of this means that, under John Howard's industrial relations policy, the teenager fresh from school would have an individual contract shoved under his or her nose with no nonsense about overtime. Mr Howard would pine for the day when trainee nurses were not even paid. John Howard camouflages his true policy by invoking the language of freedom of choice. He clearly has a policy to slash wages for workers. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The downside of the telecommunications revolution is becoming more apparent every day. The Australian people must know that we now have 2,000 mobile phone base stations, mobile phone towers, sprouting like mushrooms or toadstools all around the garden suburbs of our great cities. We might have 10,000 within a couple of years if things go on as they are. We have pay TV cable being strung willy-nilly from power poles in our suburbs, turning them into giant clotheslines. It is not just Optus that is doing it. Telstra is threatening to do the same thing.

PARA.TAB: The Australian people need to know whose fault this is. It is the fault of this government and its bodgie telecommunications law. We have to change the law, Mr Speaker. Right now you and I cannot erect a flagpole in our own backyards without getting council permission first, yet these telecommunications carriers can put up a 30-metre-high tower virtually where they want. It is not right. It is absolutely scandalous and the law must be changed. But we have got to change policy as well. Those people in my electorate who are quite rightly protesting against Optus's roll-out of cable need to know who is the real villain and what is the real solution.

At the moment, Optus cannot use Telstra's network because it does not trust Telstra, its competitor—for understandable reasons—to charge it a fair price. Nor can Optus dig its own cables, because it has got to compete, in that instance, with Telstra, which has got the cables underground already, courtesy of the Australian taxpayer. So it is government policy which means that what we are likely to end up with is the worst environmental option as well as the worst commercial option, because the only option that this government gives Optus is its cheap and nasty roll-out of pay TV cable on power poles.

Under this government's rules we are going to get a $4 billion duplication of telecommunications infrastructure. That is $4 billion which is going to be factored into the price that Optus charges consumers. That is $4 billion that Telstra could charge people over and above its prices because of the margin that Optus has to pay. In other words, $8 billion extra is what consumers in Australia could face, thanks to this government's telecommunications policy.

Duplication of telecommunications infrastructure makes no more sense than duplication of any other infrastructure. It is about as sensible as building two expressways from Sydney to Melbourne instead of just one. It is about as sensible as having two railway networks instead of just one. In other words, it makes no sense whatsoever, yet this is what we are saddled with, or likely to be saddled with, thanks to this government's policy.

The solution is for the government, which owns Telstra, to direct Telstra to make its cable and conduits available to everyone, to all comers—to everyone who wants to use the telecommunications infrastructure. At the end of the day, that infrastructure is not owned by Telstra; it is owned by the Australian taxpayer, and it should be used in ways which benefit the Australian taxpayer and which do not just allow Telstra to pay its executives outrageous salaries.

Perhaps we need to go further than that. Perhaps we need to break up Telstra. Perhaps we need to break it up into its service providing component and its infrastructure providing component. Perhaps we need one organisation providing telephones and connections, and another organisation which provides the wires—an organisation I would be happy to see as a public utility in public hands.

Telstra, at the moment, is like the old Soviet Union—it is too big to provide decent customer service and at the same time it is too big to be a fair competitor. At the moment we are seeing all Australians pay the price of keeping Telstra in this giant, cumbersome condition.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has recently been giving corporate government a lot of consideration. He has recently been giving a lot of thought to the problems of Coles Myer, a company which he does not control. It is about time he gave some consideration to the problems of Telstra, a company he is in charge of. What is good for Coles Myer may very well be good for Telstra too.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had a lot of discussion already today about industrial relations, particularly industrial relations in Western Australia where today there was a blockade which, I understand, was very successful. I watched with interest on the 7.30 Report the Premier of Western Australia talking about the blockade and saying how outrageous it was. He said, `It was only about secret ballots after all and I would not have thought that was a draconian measure.'

PARA.TAB: Quite apart from the fact that the proposal to have secret ballots for any industrial action is totally unworkable and unprecedented in this country, and pretty outrageous at that, if these proposed secret ballots were ever to go ahead, there would be a warning on the ballot paper saying something like, `If you take industrial action you could be breaking the law or breaching your contract.' That is outrageous.

I can just imagine the analogies you could make with that. Why doesn't this parliament pass a bill that says that the Australian Electoral Commission at the next federal election should put on the ballot paper, `If you vote for the coalition you could be inviting industrial mayhem.' What would people think of that? It is obviously pretty outrageous but no more outrageous than what the Western Australian government is trying to do.

We know the Western Australian government of old. I lived in Perth in the 1970s when the now premier's father was the premier. The government now, as then, hates Aboriginal people and hates workers just as much. These draconian attacks will not work at the ballot box. I do not know what they are trying to prove.

For the last five federal elections the federal coalition has tried to make industrial relations an issue. At the last election in particular, as I remember very well, although the GST and Medicare were issues, industrial relations was certainly a big issue, focused in the minds of the voters as the main difference between the two parties. I must admit that there are times when a lot of people, including myself, wonder about what differences there are between the parties on some issues. But with industrial relations, most of the time there are still pretty clear differences—differences which are shown in the various pieces of legislation put forward by state governments around the country.

We have had the New South Wales industrial relations legislation of the Fahey government—I will come back to Mr Fahey in a minute—which has been repealed by the new state government. We have Kennett's industrial relations mayhem in Victoria. Now we have this absolutely ridiculous situation in Western Australia. The coalition will never learn. They still think there are votes in union bashing. It is a wonder they do not drag out commie bashing as well and talk about reds under the beds. At the moment, it is unionists under the bed in Western Australia.

The opposition today condemned the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) because her electorate staff—who, presumably, are members of a union, probably the CPSU, my old union—actually exercised their democratic right to take industrial action in Western Australia by taking part in the blockade. That blockade was organised by the trade union movement in Western Australia and was supported by the community at large as a quite understandable protest against the outrageously draconian industrial relations legislation proposed in that state.

As I said, the coalition will never learn. People talk about the polls. They talk about how we will be thrashed at the next election and that the coalition is a shoe-in. They are saying in my electorate that, because they have chosen John Fahey as a candidate for Macarthur, it is all over, red rover. People are saying to me, `Aren't you glad you are not the candidate any more because it is all over?' I do not concede that but I agree that the candidate that has been chosen is probably a better candidate than the previous one. Nevertheless, he was the industrial relations minister and then premier in New South Wales in a failed Liberal government, so people will probably remember that as well.

As I said, the coalition never seems to learn about these divisive issues. We have a very nasty, divisive premier and divisive government in Western Australia. Equally, at the next federal election you will see these industrial relations policies rolled out and, if we ever do hear any of the other policies that the coalition has on other issues, you can be sure that if they are telling the truth they will be just as nasty and draconian as they were in 1993.

When the election is held, possibly around March next year, I believe that the people will vote the same way as they did in 1993. Forget about the polls at the moment. People will not be fooled. If the coalition is silly enough to make industrial relations an election issue, it will be on the heads of those opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —The violence and arrests in East Timor over the last week or two have once again drawn our attention to the violations of human rights that have occurred in that country. It is an uncomfortable subject for many Australians because of the fact that the dictates of realpolitik clash with what we like to see as our basic human values. We certainly feel a sense of hopelessness about our inability to influence events in East Timor—not only through the current government but through the Fraser government and the Whitlam government.

PARA.TAB: One of my own constituents, a minister of the Church of Christ, visited East Timor last year. He wrote me a lengthy letter on what he saw in that country. He said the following on his impressions of Dili:

SPEECH.PARA: My surface view of East Timor was of a very obvious and oppressive military presence, and of quiet but fearful people. Walking around the town for an hour or two after we first arrived my wife and I saw a number of trucks loaded with armed soldiers. Numerous military posts are sited throughout the town, its suburbs and outlying villages.

PARA.TAB: Our third day in Dili happened to be the anniversary of the integration of East Timor into Indonesia, and this was proclaimed by temporary monuments on many of the town's streets. The day before, we talked with a young man on the street in a country town. He said, `Tomorrow is the anniversary of the integration.' I said, `Is that a good thing or a bad thing?' He lowered his voice, even though no one else was in sight, and said, `Some people are against it.' I probed just a little further, `Are more people for it or more people against it?' Embarrassed, he hesitated before he said, `I have not counted them.'

We attended a 6:00 am mass at Bishop Belo's residence. Fifteen hundred people stood for the hour and a quarter service. Just before the conclusion of the service the Bishop gave a brief `pep talk' to the congregation asking that there be no demonstrations at the integration ceremonies, or if there were that there be no violence and no flag tearing. He had been pressured to do this . . . by the military commandant, who visited on two successive evenings.

Military observers occupy a house opposite the Bishop's residence and watch everyone who comes and goes from the residence. The Bishop runs a very fine line as he seeks to stand up for his people and also retain his ability to do that.

We were told that all the rooms in our hotel were bugged. Later, as we talked in hushed tones over dinner with another couple of Australians, I mentioned the room bugging. One of the others said, `We know. I am an electronic engineer. I have already found one in our room.'

We were approached on the street by several young people, keen to practice their English and to be friendly to some Australians. One said, `Why does not Australia support our independence?' Another said forcefully, `I do not like the Indonesians.' Yet another young person complained that he could not get a job because of the preference given to the Indonesians who were being introduced to East Timor. It seemed that, with the strength of the transmigration program, if and when Indonesia graciously decided to allow an act of self-determination for East Timor the majority of people may be Indonesians anyway.

SPEECH.PARA: Last week, security forces arrested over 120 youths during four days of unrest in Dili. The incident left at least two people dead and many injured. This morning, local sources say that 50 more pro-independence young people were arrested after a Catholic school they were sheltering in was stormed by firing Indonesian troops who wounded several youths and, after rounding them up, beat them in front of the nuns before marching them away to waiting trucks.

PARA.TAB: Last week's violence was said to have been sparked by a dispute between members of East Timor's majority Catholic population and a Muslim Indonesian official. Bishop Belo, the head of the local Catholic church, was shortlisted recently for the Nobel Peace Prize. After clashes last year, he wrote to President Suharto expressing concern over alleged human rights violations. Bishop Belo declared that the church was ready to cooperate with the government and armed forces in keeping peace in Timor, but he made it clear that the military should respect human dignity and local culture. We can only hope that Bishop Belo's message will spread.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LEE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts and Minister for Tourism)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been encouraged by the honourable member for Warringah (Mr Abbott) to come into the chamber and participate in the adjournment debate. Mr Speaker, you would remember that it was a common feature in the old days in the Old Parliament House precincts that remarks by members on both sides of the House would often encourage ministers to come down and participate in the adjournment debate. This is the second time that I have had to come down and explain to the honourable member for Warringah two fundamental mistakes that he has made in his understanding of communications policy.

PARA.TAB: The first problem that he has is that he does not yet understand that you need duplication, or the threat of it, for competition. We had this debate in Australia in the 1940s. It was actually my party that suggested that you got the best banking system by nationalising the banks and having one bank run every bank in Australia. We lost, I think, the 1949 election and no Labor government since has ever tried to head down that path—quite rightly, because we have realised you need more than one bank to have the competition on prices and services and to give people a choice.

Similarly, the honourable member for Warringah mentioned Coles Myer. We do not say that Coles Myer is the only company in Australia that is allowed to set up supermarkets because that saves on infrastructure. That is the logical extension of your argument, that we should have only one—probably government owned—store that would be the only place where we could go along and buy our groceries. Using your argument, that is the most cost efficient way that you could minimise the investment in supermarket construction.

Our party has argued since 1949 that competition is something that is healthy for consumers. It is much better to have investors deciding whether it is in the best interests of consumers to have a Coles and a Woolworths in the same town. You certainly do not have the government drawing lines on maps and saying that certain towns are reserved for Coles supermarkets and others are reserved for Woolworths supermarkets. That is really what the honourable member is arguing—that I should sit here with a map of Australia on the desk and work out which parts of the country are reserved for Telstra, for Telecom, to cable up and which half of the country is reserved for Optus Vision to cable up. It is the very threat of competition that ensures people are kept on their toes.

The honourable member says that he does not want duplication of the cable investment because that is like having two freeways or two roads or two of any other type of infrastructure. As I tried to explain to him once before, we would not have competition between Optus and Telecom for long distance calls, for STD calls, if Optus had not duplicated the fibre optic links between all the capital cities. The reason we have cheaper phone calls from Sydney to Melbourne today is that Optus duplicated Telcom's infrastructure, Telecom's cables, from Sydney to Melbourne. That has provided great discounts for consumers—for business and residential consumers. Prices are down by about $380 million a year. We have had a massive increase in investment in upgrading Australia's communications infrastructure. Exports of telecommunications equipment have gone from $200 million to almost $1 billion a year. People now have a wider choice of services and Telecom's customer services have improved dramatically. All of those things have only occurred since the Labor government introduced competition in 1991-92.

The second point I make to the honourable member is that at that time this parliament agreed to let Optus have access to Telecom's conduits. You do not seem to understand that the current Telecommunications Act does give Optus access to Telecom's conduits.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's not at a fair price.

—You say, `It's not at a fair price.' You were arguing during your speech that somehow or other we should make the conduits and the cable available. That is what the current Telecommunications Act says: that Optus is allowed to get access to those cables. For most of the calls that are made by people in the gallery who might use Optus, they use some of Telecom's cable and some of Optus's cable. Optus has to pay for the use of the elements of Telecom's cable; Optus is required to pay what they call the interconnect price. That interconnect price was initially set by the minister of the day, Kim Beazley, and it is something which has been set impartially with the help of Austel as an independent arbitrator.

PARA.TAB: Many people argue that it was set too low to give an advantage to Optus. Optus would argue that they think it is set high enough. Certainly the playing field was tilted in favour of Optus; it was tilted in favour of rolling out this infrastructure, rolling out this duplication, so that we get competition on price. That is why we tried to ensure that there was the ability for Optus to use Telstra's cable and vice versa.

More recently, as the government has announced its plans for the post-1997 rules for competition in telecommunications, we have said again that if any telephone company which is a carrier—whether it is Telstra, Optus or British Telecom—invests money in cable or if another company comes to Australia and invests money in cable they have to let other people have access to their cable. It is going to be one of the most open and competitive regimes anywhere in the world.

The choice between letting the market forces decide where telephone companies invest in cable is to have Comrade Abbott sitting up there preparing the five-year plan, telling Telstra and Optus and everyone else where they can invest in cable. I bet he would have a lot of the money spent in Warringah, too, because he knows that, if you get that duplication of the infrastructure, you get that competition for the lower prices for business and residential consumers.

I can just see Comrade Abbott or Comrade Alston, the shadow spokesman for communications, calling in Frank Blount, Bob Mansfield or Brian Inglis and pinning on them the `Howard Star' for meeting their five-year plan targets in investing in cable. It is just a return to the Soviet central planning model, Mr Speaker. You know there are a few people around this building who might still subscribe to that view, but I am staggered to know that the member for Warringah is one of the people who subscribes to the view that central planning and monopoly businesses are the only way that you can save on the costs of infrastructure investment.

I am also a little bit disappointed that he has not yet informed his constituents—all the members of the gallery who are here tonight—that it was his party which helped to vote to ensure that the telephone companies were exempted from the state planning laws—I think you were advising a minister around the place at the time—because it was a vote of both the government and the opposition that ensured that the exemption that the telephone companies now enjoy was not overturned on a resolution from some other people. It is, in fact, those areas that will get the duplication in the pay TV cable that will be getting the benefits that flow from the use of that cable. So, if you happen to be someone who wants to subscribe to Optus and get the lowest priced phone calls from Optus, you will probably want that Optus cable in your street.

Certainly, if the honourable member for Warringah wants to write to Geoffrey Cousins at Optus Vision or to the general manager at Optus and say that he does not want his electorate to have any of this overhead cable, they might oblige you, but I do not know if your constituents would be happy if they missed out on the lower prices that flow, especially for local calls.

So I challenge the honourable member for Warringah to write a letter to Geoffrey Cousins saying that he does not want his constituents to have cable in their streets, that he does not want his constituents to benefit from the local calls that go. That is the real test. He is always in here complaining about the mobile telephone towers, but he has not yet surrendered his mobile phone. I have challenged him to do that too, Mr Speaker—to surrender to you in a public ceremony his mobile telephone so that he can prove to us that he is not encouraging the use of this electromagnetic radiation that he finds so objectionable.

TALK.START.PARA: —He would not be able to ring you.

—He would not be able to ring me as well, as my colleague across the table says. The final point I make is that we have toughened the environmental regime on the telephone carriers. Now if they want to build a mobile phone tower and the local council objects, it does not just plough straight ahead. What happens now is that CEPA, the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency, ends up being the umpire if there is a proposal that the local council does not agree with. It is through these issues that we have tried to strike the right balance, in encouraging investment in infrastructure and empowering local councils to have a chance to influence the decisions that the carriers make.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 30 May 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the number of mobile telephone base stations located on high buildings in New South Wales including those subject to strata title.

(2) Is it a fact that the (a) NSW Strata Titles Act requires that the lease of a common property must be by a unanimous resolution at a general meeting of the relevant body corporate and (b) NSW Strata Titles Commissioner has advised that any other form of agreement to permit the installation of a base station in a building subject to strata title would require at least an empowering by-law passed at a general meeting by a special resolution with no more than 25 per cent voting against it.

(3) Is he able to say whether telecommunications companies installing base stations in buildings subject to strata title are advising body corporate councils of the need for unanimous consent in the case of a lease or 75 per cent acceptance in the case of a licence granted under by-law.

(4) What steps is the Government taking to ensure that (a) base stations are installed in accordance with existing law and (b) residents of buildings subject to strata title are aware of the law concerning the installation of base stations.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) There are no specific statistics available on the number of mobile telephone base stations located on high buildings.
(2) (a) Commercial leasing arrangements are a matter between the carrier and potential lessor.

(b) The Parliament decided to exempt all three carriers, Telecom, Optus and Vodafone, from certain State and Territory laws for the construction of telecommunications facilities, including mobile communications facilities. The range of laws from which carrier activities are exempt are specified in the Telecommunications (Exempt Activities) Regulations.
I am advised that this exemption probably extends to the provisions of the NSW Strata Titles Act 1973.
(3) The activities of carriers in constructing mobile base stations is governed by the Telecommunications National Code which was gazetted on 30 June 1994.
The Code specifically provides a role for local councils to receive full details of the carriers' proposed activities to enable affected communities to be consulted.

In the case of mobile towers or similar structures, if, after consultation, there is still disagreement between a carrier and a local government authority about the environmental significance of a mobile tower site, the Code provides procedures whereby the proposal must be referred to DEST if the council so requests. The carrier cannot proceed until any objections by DEST are resolved.

It is not a requirement of the Telecommunications National Code to advise body corporate councils of their obligations to their members in accord with the NSW Strata Titles Act. This is a matter for the body corporate councils.

The carriers have all agreed to guidelines complementary to the Telecommunications National Code for local community notification and consultation. These guidelines were developed in association with the Municipal Association of Victoria. It is the Government's expectation that the carriers, after consultation with Councils, will apply these guidelines nationwide.
(4)(a) The Parliament decided to exempt all three carriers from certain State and Territory laws for the construction of telecommunications facilities.

The Government has put in place the Telecommunications National Code which governs the behaviour of carriers when undertaking exempt activities including installing mobile telecommunications base stations. AUSTEL has the power to ensure compliance with the Telecommunications National Code.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 28 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: Following a general election letters and reminders are sent seeking information as to why a name was marked off a certified list more than once.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: UN Fourth World Conference on Women in Beijing

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, upon notice, on 31 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the official involvement of the Australian Government in the UN Fourth World Conference on Women in Beijing.
(2) How many Australian federal parliamentarians are attending the conference.
(3) What are the budgetary implications of the conference for Australia.
(4) How have non-government bodies been encouraged to attend the conference.
(5) Will the Government release an official post-conference report.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Australia participated in the Fourth World Conference for Women in Beijing in its capacity as a Member State of the United Nations.

(2) Five Australian federal parliamentarians attended the conference. The delegation was led by the Hon Carmen Lawrence MP, Minister for Human Services and Health, and included Senator Meg Lees, Senator the Hon Margaret Reynolds, Senator Sue West and Judith Moylan MP as advisers.

(3) The costs incurred by Government agencies involved in preparations for and participation in the conference were met within existing budgets. The costs incurred by parliamentarians attending the conference were paid for through the Parliamentary Travel Fund.

(4) The Office of the Status of Women (OSW) in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet has provided considerable assistance and encouragement to non-government organisations (NGOs) to attend the conference. OSW has been active in disseminating information about the conference through the provision of information kits and regular information sheets (nine in all) providing details for organisations intending to travel to Beijing. The Office has also assisted with pre-conference training programs and liaised with the Chinese Embassy over the provision of visas.
Representatives from NGOs have been assisted to attend the Conference through the new National Agenda for Women Grants Program (NAWGP).

The Government, through AusAID, supported the attendance at the Beijing Conference of ministerial delegates, officials and NGO representatives from a number of developing countries including Africa, Malaysia, Laos and South Pacific Forum countries through existing aid programs.

(5) No. The Government has released its commitments to the Beijing Conference. The Australian National Report to the United Nations Fourth World Conference on Women is already available through the Australian Government Publishing Service. The Platform for Action and Report of the Meeting will be published in due course by the United Nations.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: News Ltd and Telstra Business Arrangements

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 31 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has his attention been drawn by an article by Brian Toohey in the Sun-Herald of 30 July 1995 which refers to an arrangement between News Limited and Telstra.

(2) Is it a fact that (a) News Limited has entered into an arrangement in which Telstra will spend about $3.5 billion laying optical fibre cable for the delivery of pay television and other services and (b) News Limited is a 50/50 partner with Telstra in

QUESTION.PARA: Foxtel, a company formed to sell television programs via cable; if so, is News Limited placed in the highly advantageous position of having access to a cable system which no one else can use in competition with Foxtel until 1997.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The article referred to has been brought to my attention.
(2)(a) Telstra advises that its decision to invest some $3.9 billion to develop cable infrastructure to service 4 million Australian homes by mid 1999 is driven by three factors:

the need for Telstra to evolve into an information services company and to build broadband infrastructure and systems which will ensure it can offer the full range of multimedia and broadband services and products and not just pay television which it will offer in partnership with News Limited;
the revenues available to Telstra from its involvement in the pay television joint venture—revenues which are crucial in funding the rollout business plan; and
Optus Vision's decision to rollout a $3 billion broadband infrastructure and to compete in the local call market.

(b) Telstra advises that its wholly owned subsidiary, Telstra Media Pty Ltd, owns 50 per cent of shares in the Foxtel partnership. The other 50 per cent of Foxtel is owned by a subsidiary of News Corporation (Sky Cable Pty Ltd). Foxtel will provide and manage broadband video home entertainment services, including pay television.

Telstra advises that it will manage access to the cable network consistent with its traditional business. Telstra is required to comply with the access conditions for broadband cable infrastructure as provided in the Telecommunications (Service Providers Class Licence) Direction No.1 of 1995. This direction permits both Telstra and Optus Vision to restrict access to their respective broadband cable networks in relation to pay television services until at least 1997.

Telstra advises that there is no obligation for it to provide, nor is it Telstra's intention to provide, Foxtel with exclusive use of the Telstra network. Telstra intends to offer other broadband services, such as interactive multimedia, in its own right and will explore options for the delivery of other content services with other partners.
